explanations: The original French title "La Marquise" (Marchioness) is translated as "THE Countess." This change lowers the aristocratic rank of the female character, as a Marchioness is typically of higher rank than a Countess. This alteration subtly shifts the reader's perception of her social standing and may serve as an anglicization that slightly diminishes her original French aristocratic status.

The simple French "voulut" (wanted), part of "La Marquise voulut", is expanded in the translation. The addition of the phrase "was so intent upon her Notions, that" before "she would fain" introduces a specific psychological driver for her desire—her "Notions" (which could imply whimsical or ill-founded ideas in English of the period)—not explicit in the original's direct statement of will. This shapes the reader's perception by adding a layer of characterization and motivation not present in the source.

The phrase "pendant le jour" (during the day/daytime) is translated as "next day." The original suggests the Marquise's eagerness to continue discussions promptly, even outside their usual evening schedule, possibly during daylight hours of the same day. "Next day" introduces a specific delay until the following day, subtly altering the perception of the immediacy and intensity of her enthusiasm.

The original "poursuivre nos Entretiens" (to continue our Conversations/Discussions) implies a mutual, shared activity. The translation "to go on where I left off" shifts the focus to the philosopher-narrator's control over the dialogue's progression ("where *I* left off"). This subtly alters the perceived dynamic from a collaborative discussion to one more clearly led by the narrator, potentially reinforcing his authority.

The original "nous ne devions confier... qu'à..." (we should/ought to entrust... only to...) has a prescriptive tone and frames the Moon and Stars as uniquely fitting confidantes due to their thematic connection to the "chimeres" (speculations). The translation "we would trust... with no body else" softens the moral or advisory force of "devions" (ought to) to "would" and changes the emphasis from a positive selection of special confidantes to a negative exclusion of others. This subtly changes the tone from a poetic, thematic justification for their discretion to a more mundane statement about practical secrecy.

chunks.source_manual: <P040>J'ai bien des nouvelles à vous apprendre, luy dis-je, la Lune que je vous disois hier qui selon toutes les apparences êtoit habitée, pourroit bien ne l'être point; j'ay pensé à une chose qui met ses Habitants en peril. Je ne souffriray point cela, répondit-elle. Hier vous m'aviez preparée à voir ces Gens là venir icy au premier jour, & aujourd'hui ils ne seroient seulement pas au monde? Vous ne vous joüerez point ainsi de moy, vous m'avez fait croire les Habitans de la Lune; j'ay surmonté la peine que j'y avois, je les croiray. Vous allez bien vîte, repris-je, il faut ne donner que la moitié de son esprit aux choses de cette espèce que l'on croit, & en réserver une autre moitié libre, où le contraire puisse être admis, s'il en est besoin. Je ne me paie point de Sentences, répliqua-t-elle, allons au fait. Ne faut-il pas raisonner de la Lune comme de <NCE>Saint-Denis</NCE>? Non, répondis-je, la Lune ne ressemble pas autant à la Terre que <NCE>Saint-Denis ressemble à Paris</NCE>. Le soleil éleve de la Terre & des Eaux, des exhalosons & des vapeurs qui, montant en l'air jusqu'à quelque hauteur, s'y assemblent, & forment les nüages. Ces nüages suspendus voltigent irrégulierement autour de nôtre Globe, & ombragent tantôt un Païs, tantôt un autre. <UP></UP> Qui verroit la Terre de loin, remarqueroit souvent quelques changements sur sa surface, parce qu'un grand Païs couvert par des nüages seroit un endroit obscur, & deviendrait plus lumineux dès qu'il serait découvert. On verroit des taches qui changeroient de place, ou s'assembleroient diversement, ou disparoîtroient tout à fait. On verroit donc aussi ces mêmes changements sur la face de la Lune, <UP></UP> si elle avoit des nüages autour d'elle; mais tout au contraire, toutes ses taches sont fixes, ses endroits lumineux le sont toûjours, & voilà le malheur. A ce compte-là, le Soleil n'élève point de vapeurs, ny d'exhalaisons de dessus la Lune. C'est donc <UP></UP> un Corps infiniment plus dur & plus solide que notre Terre, dont les parties les plus subtiles se dégagent aisément d'avec les autres, & montent en haut dés qu'elles sont mises en mouvement par la chaleur. Il faut que ce soit quelque amas de Rochers & de Marbres, où il ne se fait point d'évaporations; d'ailleurs, elles se font si naturellement & si necessairement où il y a des Eaux, qu'il ne doit point y avoir d'eaux ou il ne s'en fait point. Qui sont donc les Habitans de ces Rochers qui ne peuvent rien produire, & de ce Païs qui n'a point d'eaux? Et quoi, s'écria-t-elle, il ne vous souvient plus que vous m'avez assurée qu'il y avoit dans la Lune des Mers que l'on distinguoit d'icy? <UP></UP> Ce n'est qu'une conjecture, répondis-je, j'en suis bien fâché; ces endroits obscurs qu'on prend pour des Mers, ne sont peut-être que <IIM>de grandes cavitez</IIM>. De la distance où nous sommes, il est permis de ne pas deviner tout à fait juste. Mais, dit-elle, cela suffira-t-il pour nous faire abandonner les Habitans de la Lune? Non pas tout à fait, Madame, répondis-je, nous ne nous déterminerons ni pour eux, ny contre eux. Je vous avouë ma faiblesse <NCP></NCP>, répliqua-t-elle, je ne suis point capable d'une si parfaite indétermination, j'ay besoin de croire. Fixez-moy promptement à une opinion sur les Habitans de la Lune; conservons les, ou aneantissons les pour jamais & qu'il n'en soit plus parlé; mais conservons les plutôt, s'il se peut, j'ay pris pour eux une inclination que j'aurois de la peine à perdre. Je ne laisseray donc pas la Lune deserte, repris-je, repeuplons là pour vous faire plaisir. A la vérité, puisque l'apparence des taches de la Lune ne change point, on ne peut pas croire qu'elle ait des nüages autour d'elle, qui ombragent tantôt une partie, tantôt une autre; mais ce n'est pas à dire qu'elle ne pousse point hors d'elle de vapeurs ny d'exhalaisons. Nos nüages que nous voïons portez en l'air ne sont que des exhalaisons & des vapeurs, qui au sortir de la Terre êtaient separées en trop petites parties pour pouvoir être veuës, & qui ont rencontré un peu plus haut une froideur qui les a resserrées, & renduës visibles par la reünion de leurs parties, aprés quoy ce sont de gros nüages qui flotent en l'air où ils sont des Corps étrangers, jusqu'à ce qu'ils retombet en pluyes. Mais ces mêmes vapeurs, & ces mêmes exhalaisons se tiennent quelquefois assez dispersées pour être imperceptibles, & ne se ramassent qu'en formant <IIM>des rosées tres subtiles</IIM>, qu'on ne voit tomber d'aucune nuée. Il se peut aussi que les vapeurs qui sortent de la Lune, (car enfin il faut qu'il en sorte, il n'est pas croyable que la Lune soit une masse dont toutes les parties soient d'une égale solidité; toutes également en repos les unes auprés des autres, toutes incapables de recevoir aucun changement par l'action du Soleil sur elles; nous ne connoissons aucun Corps de cette nature, les Marbres mêmes n'en sont pas, tout ce qui est le plus solide change & s'altere, ou par le mouvement secret & invisible qu'il a en luy-même, ou par celuy qu'il reçoit de dehors.) Il se peut donc que les vapeurs qui sortent de la Lune, ne se rassemblent point autour d'elle en nuages, & ne retomberont point sur elle en pluyes, mais seulement en rosées. Il suffit pour cela que l'air dont apparemment la Lune est environnée en son particulier, comme notre Terre l'est du sien, soit un peu different de notre Air, & les vapeurs de la Lune un peu differentes des vapeurs de la Terre, ce qui est quelque chose de plus que vraysemblable. Sur ce pied là, il faudra que la matière étant disposée dans la Lune autrement que sur la Terre, les effets soient diferens, mais il n'importe; du moment que nous avons trouvé un mouvement interieur dans les parties de la Lune, ou produit par des causes étrangeres, voilà ses Habitans qui renaissent, & nous avons le fond necessaire pour leur subsistance. Cela nous fournira des fruits, des blés, des eaux, & tout ce que nous voudrons. J'entends des fruits, des bleds, des eaux à la maniere de la Lune que je fais profession de ne pas connoître, le tout proportionné aux besoins de ses Habitans, que je ne connais pas non plus.</P040> <P041>C'est-à-dire, me dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que vous savez seulement que tout est bien, sans savoir comment il est; c'est beaucoup d'ignorance <UP></UP> sur bien peu de science; mais il faut s'en consoler; je suis encore trop heureuse que vous ayez rendu à la Lune ses Habitans. Je suis même fort contente que vous luy donniez un Air qui l'enveloppe en son particulier, il me semblerait desormais que sans cela une Planete seroit trop nuë.</P041>
chunks.target_manual: <P031>Well, Madam, said I, I have great News for you; that which I told you last Night, of the Moon's being inhabited, may not be so now: There is a new Fancy got into my Head, which puts those People in great Danger. I cannot suffer it, said she; yesterday you were preparing me to receive a Visit from 'em, and now there are no such People in Nature: Once you would have me believe the Moon was inhabited; I surmounted the Difficulty I had, and will now believe it. You are a little too nimble, I reply'd; did I not advise you never to be entirely convinc'd in things of this nature, but to reserve half of your understanding free and disengag'd, that you may admit of the contrary opinion, if there be any occasion. I care not for your Sentences, said she, let us come to matter of Fact. Are we not to consider the Moon as <NCE>Greenwhich</NCE>? No, said I, the Moon doth not so much resemble the Earth, as <NCE>Greenwich doth London</NCE>: The Sun draws from the Earth and Water, Exhalations and Vapours, which mounting to a certain height in the Air, do there assemble, and form the Clouds; these uncertain Clouds are driven irregularly round the Globe, sometimes shadowing one Countrey, and sometimes another; he then who beholds the Earth from a-far off, will see frequent alterations upon its surface, because a great Country overcast with Clouds, will appear dark or light, as the Clouds stay, or pass over it; he will see the Spots on the Earth often change their Place, and appear, or disappear as the Clouds remove; but we see none of these changes wrought upon the Moon, which would certainly be the same, were there but Clouds about her; but on the contrary, all her Spots are fix'd and certain, and her light parts continue where they were at first, which truly is a great misfortune; for by this reason, the Sun draws no Exhalations or Vapours above the Moon; so that it appears she is a Body infinitely more hard, and solid than the Earth, whose subtile parts are easily separated from the rest, and mount upwards as soon as Heat puts them in Motion: But it must be a heap of Rock and Marble, where there is no Evaporation; besides, Exhalations are so natural and necessary where there is Water, that there can be no Water at all, where there is no Exhalation; and what sort of Inhabitants must those be, whose Countrey affords no Water, is all Rock, and produceth nothing? Very fine, said she, you have forgot since, you assur'd me, we might from hence distinguish Seas in the Moon; nay, <UP>You or your Friends were Godfathers to some of 'em. Pray, what is become of your Caspian Sea, and your Black Lake? All Conjecture, Madam, I reply'd, tho' for your Ladyships sake, I am very sorry for it;</UP> for those dark places we took to be Seas, may perhaps be nothing but large Cavities; 'tis hard to guess aright at so great a distance. But will this suffice then, said she, to extirpate the People in the Moon? Not altogether, I reply'd, we will neither determine for, nor against them. I must own my weakness <NCP>(if it be one)</NCP> said she, I cannot be so perfectly undetermin'd as you would have me to be, but must believe one way, or the other; therefore pray fix me quickly in my opinion; as to the Inhabitants of the Moon; preserve or annihilate them, as you shall think fit; and yet methinks I have a strange inclination for 'em, and would not have 'em destroy'd, if it were possible to save 'em. You know, Madam, said I, I can deny you nothing; the Moon shall be no longer a Defart, but to do you service, we will repeople her. Since to all appearance, the Spots in the Moon do not change, I cannot conceive there are any Clouds about her, that sometimes obscure one part, and sometimes another; yet this doth not hinder, but that the Moon sends forth Exhalations, and Vapours. Our Clouds which we see in the Air, are nothing but Exhalations and Vapours, which at their coming out of the Earth, were separated into such minute Particles, that they could not be discern'd; but as they ascend higher, they are condens'd by the Cold, and by the re- union of their Parts, are render'd visible; after which they become great Clouds, which fluctuate in the Air, till they return back again in Rain; however these Exhalations and Vapours do sometimes keep themselves so dispers'd, that they are imperceptible; or if they do assemble, it is in forming such subtile Dews, that they cannot be discern'd to fall from any Cloud. It may likewise happen, that the Vapours which go out of the Moon (for it is incredible that the Moon is such a Mass, that all its Parts are of an equal Solidity, all at rest one with another, and all incapable of any alteration from the efficacy of the Sun; I am sure we are yet unacquainted with such a Body: Marble it self is of another Nature, and even that which is most Solid, is subject to Change and Alteration; either from the secret and invisible motion it hath within it self, or from that which it receives from without) it may so happen then, that the Vapours which issue from the Moon, may not assemble round her in Clouds, and may not fall back again in Rain, but only in Dews. It is sufficient for this, that the Air with which the Moon is environ'd, <NCP>(for it is certain that the Moon is encompassed with Air as well as the Earth)</NCP> be a little different from our Air, and the Vapours of the Moon a little different from those of the Earth, which is very probable. Hereupon the matter being otherwise dispos'd in the Moon than on the Earth, the Effects must be different; tho' it is of no great consequence whether they are or no; for from the moment we have found an inward motion in the parts of the Moon, or produced by foreign Causes, here is enough for the new birth of its Inhabitants, and a sufficient and necessary fund for their Subsistence. This will furnish us with Corn, Fruit, Water, according to the custom or manner of the Moon, which I do not pretend to know; and all proportion'd to the wants and use of the Inhabitants, with whom I pretend to be as little acquainted. That is to say, reply'd the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, you know all is very well, without knowing how it is so, which is a great deal of Ignorance <UP>upon a very little Knowledge;</UP> however I comfort my self, that you have given the Moon her Inhabitants again, and have wrap'd her in an Air of her own, without which a Planet would seem but very naked.</P031>

explanations: The French reference "Saint-Denis" (part of the phrase "comme de Saint-Denis," referring to a place near Paris with deep historical, royal, and religious significance, particularly Catholic) is replaced by "Greenwhich." This localization for an English audience changes the cultural and connotative frame of the analogy. "Greenwhich" (Greenwich), then known for its Royal Observatory, introduces a scientific connotation largely absent in the multi-layered French reference and removes the original French historical/religious layers. This alteration, potentially to neutralize a Catholic-associated reference for Protestant English readers in a period of religious tension, subtly manipulates the original's cultural context and the nature of the analogy presented by the philosopher.

The French phrase "Saint-Denis ressemble à Paris" (Saint-Denis resembles Paris) is translated as "Greenwich doth London." This substitution continues the alteration of the analogy's cultural basis. It replaces a comparison rooted in French geography and history (Saint-Denis being an ancient royal and religious site whose relationship with Paris is well-understood in France) with one rooted in English geography and contemporary scientific development (Greenwich and its observatory relative to London). This manipulation lies in altering the specific cultural, historical, and potentially religious connotations of Fontenelle's chosen analogy, thereby changing how the reader perceives the nature of the comparison being made.

The English translation significantly expands on the Marquise's original statement. While the French text has her recall being told there were distinguishable seas on the Moon ("qu'il y avoit dans la Lune des Mers que l'on distinguoit d'icy?"), the English version adds the specific and vivid details: "nay, You or your Friends were Godfathers to some of 'em. Pray, what is become of your Caspian Sea, and your Black Lake?". This addition, not present in Fontenelle's original, makes the Marquise's challenge more pointed and ties it to contemporary (possibly English) practices of lunar nomenclature. This embellishment manipulates the reader's perception by attributing more detailed prior claims to the philosopher and greater specific knowledge/recall to the Marquise than depicted in the source text.

The French word "apparemment" (apparently, seemingly) within the phrase "l'air dont apparemment la Lune est environnée" conveys a degree of conjecture regarding the Moon's atmosphere. The English translation omits this nuance of uncertainty. Instead, it inserts a parenthetical clause, "(for it is certain that the Moon is encompassed with Air as well as the Earth)," which transforms the philosopher's speculative remark into a firm assertion of fact. This shift in epistemic modality manipulates the reader's understanding by presenting the existence of a lunar atmosphere with a higher degree of certainty than in the original text, misrepresenting the philosopher's cautious scientific approach.

The original French text refers to the female interlocutor as "la Marquise" (Marchioness). The English translation changes this title to "the Countess" (as in "reply'd the Countess"). As "Marquise" denotes a higher rank in the aristocracy than "Countess" (Comtesse), this alteration inaccurately represents the character's social standing as established by Fontenelle. This change, though seemingly minor, subtly manipulates the reader's perception of the character's specific social eminence within the carefully crafted aristocratic setting of the dialogues, which was significant in the societal context of the time.

chunks.source_manual: <P042>Ces deux Airs diferens, repris-je, contribuent à empêcher la communication des deux Planetes. S'il ne tenoit qu'à voler; que savons-nous, comme je vous disois hier, si on ne volera pas fort bien quelque jour? J'avoüe pourtant qu'il n'y a pas beaucoup d'apparence. Le grand éloignement de la Lune à la Terre serait encore une difficulté à surmonter, qui est assurement considerable, mais quand même elle ne s'y rencontreroit pas, quand même les deux Planetes seroient proches, <UP></UP> il ne seroit pas possible de passer de l'Air de l'une dans l'air de l'autre. L'eau est l'air des Poissons, ils ne passent jamais dans l'Air des Oiseaux dans l'air des Poissons; ce n'est pas la distance qui les en empêche, c'est que chacun a pour prison l'air qu'il respire. Nous trouvons que le nôtre est mêlé de vapeurs plus épaisses & plus grossières que celuy de la Lune. A ce compte, un Habitan de la Lune qui seroit arrivé aux confins de notre Monde, se noyeroit dés qu'il entreroit dans notre Air, & nous le verrions tomber mort sur la Terre.</P042>
chunks.target_manual: <P032>'Tis these two different Airs, said I, that hinder the Communication of the two Planets; if it was only flying, as I told you yesterday, who knows but we may improve it to perfection, tho' I confess there is but little hopes of it; the great distance between the Moon and the Earth is a difficulty not easily to be surmounted, yet were the distance but inconsiderable, and the <UP>two Planets almost contiguous</UP>, it would be still impossible to pass from the Air of the one, into the Air of the other: The Water is the Air of Fishes, they never pass into the Air of the Birds, nor the Birds into the Air of the Fish; and yet 'tis not the distance that hinders them, but both are emprison'd by the Air they breath in; we find our Air consists of thicker and grosser Vapours than the Air of the Moon. So that one of her Inhabitants arriving at the Confines of our World, as soon as he enters our Air will inevitably drown himself, and we shall see him fall dead on the Earth.</P032>

explanations: The French 'volera pas fort bien' (will fly very well) suggests developing a practical capability. The translation 'improve it to perfection' elevates this to achieving an ultimate, idealized state for the concept of flight, subtly making the prospect sound grander and more abstract than the original.

The French 'il n'y a pas beaucoup d'apparence' (there isn't much likelihood/prospect) offers a relatively objective assessment of probability. The translation 'there is but little hopes of it' introduces a subjective emotional element ('hopes') and a more pessimistic tone, shifting the speaker's remark from an observation about probability to an expression of personal feeling.

The French conditional 'serait encore une difficulté' (would still/also be a difficulty) presents this obstacle as part of a continuing hypothetical consideration. The translation 'is a difficulty' uses the present indicative, changing the modality and omitting 'encore' (still/also). This recasts a conditional point as a more general, established fact, subtly altering the argument's flow and the perceived nature of the difficulty.

The French 'est mêlé de' (is mixed with) indicates that vapours are an admixture within the air, implying the air has other components. The translation 'consists of' suggests that these vapours are the primary or defining substance of the air, subtly altering the reader's understanding of the air's fundamental composition.

The French conditional 'se noyeroit' (would drown) describes a hypothetical consequence. The translation 'will inevitably drown himself' changes the mood from conditional to future indicative and adds the intensifier 'inevitably.' This shift makes the outcome sound more certain, definite, and dramatic than the original conditional possibility, altering the reader's perception of the consequence.

chunks.source_manual: <P043>Oh, que j'aurois d'envie, s'écria la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, <UP></UP> qu'il arrivât quelque grand naufrage <UP></UP> qui répandît icy bon nombre de ces Gens- là, dont nous irions considérer à notre aise les figures extraordinaires! Mais répliquay-je, s'ils étoient assez habiles pour naviger sur la surface exterieure de notre Air, & que de là par la curiosité de nous voir, ils nous pêchassent comme des Poissons, cela vous plairoit-il? Pourquoy non, répondit-elle en riant? Pour moy, je me mettrois de mon propre mouvement dans leurs Filets, seulement pour avoir le plaisir de voir ceux qui m'auroient pêchée.</P043>
chunks.target_manual: <P033>I should rejoyce at a Wreck, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, <UP>as much as my Neighbours on the Coast of Sussex</UP>; how pleasant would it be to see 'em lie scatter'd on the ground, where we might consider at our ease, their extraordinary Figures? But what, said I, if they could swim on the outward surface of our Air, and be as curious to see us, as you are to see them; should they Angle or cast a Net for us, as for so many Fish, would that please you? why not? said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>; For my part I would go into their Nets of mine own accord, were it but for the pleasure to see such strange Fishermen.</P033>
source_segments: Oh, que j'aurois d'envie, s'écria la Marquise,
ceux qui m'auroient pêchée.
target_segments: I should rejoyce at a Wreck, said the Countess, as much as my Neighbours on the Coast of Sussex;
such strange Fishermen.
explanations: The target text adds the clause 'as much as my Neighbours on the Coast of Sussex' to the Countess's speech. This phrase is entirely absent in the original French. Its inclusion introduces a specific, loaded English cultural reference, possibly alluding to 'wrecking' (the practice of looting shipwrecks, historically associated with some coastal communities like those in Sussex). This manipulates the reader's perception by altering the character of the Marquise (Countess). The original expresses a general, perhaps naive, curiosity, while the translation likens her joy to a potentially callous or opportunistic local custom, thereby changing the tone of her exclamation and grounding it in a culturally specific English context not found in Fontenelle's original.

The original French 'ceux qui m'auroient pêchée' (literally 'those who would have fished me') is translated as 'such strange Fishermen.' The addition of the adjective 'strange' and the use of the noun 'Fishermen' (instead of a more direct rendering of 'those who fished') subtly manipulates perception. Fontenelle's original focuses on the Marquise's curiosity about the beings performing the action, while the translation emphasizes their inherent 'strangeness' and categorizes them as 'Fishermen'. This adds a layer of explicit characterization and a slightly different nuance not present in the source, guiding the reader's interpretation of the alien beings beyond the Marquise's simpler expression of curiosity about their identity.

chunks.source_manual: <P044>Songez, répliquai-je, que vous n'arriveriez que bien malade au haut de notre Air, il n'est pas respirable pour nous dans toute son étenduê, il s'en faut bien, il ne l'est déjà presque plus au haut de certaines <UP></UP> Montagnes, & je m'étonne bien que ceux qui ont la folie de croire que des Genies corporels habitent l'air le plus pur, ne disent aussi que ce qui fait que ces Genies ne nous rendent que des visites & tres-rares & très-courtes, c'est qu'il y en a peu d'entre eux qui sachent plonger, & que ceux-là même ne peuvent faire jusqu'au fond de cet air épais, où nous sommes, que des plongeons de très peu de durée <UP></UP>. Voilà donc bien des barrieres naturelles qui nous défendent la sortie de notre Monde, & l'entrée de celuy de la Lune. Tâchons du moins pour notre consolation à deviner ce que nous pourrons de ce Monde-là. Je croy, par exemple, qu'il faut qu'on y voye le Ciel, le Soleil, & les Astres d'une autre couleur que nous ne les voyons. Tous ces objets ne nous paroissent qu'au travers d'une espèce de Lunette naturelle qui nous les change. Cette Lunette, c'est notre Air, mêlé comme il est de vapeurs & d'exhalaisons, & qui ne s'étend pas bien haut. Quelques Modernes pretendent que de luy-même il est bleu aussi bien que l'eau de la Mer, & que cette couleur ne paroît dans l'un & dans l'autre qu'à une grande profondeur. Le Ciel, disent-ils, où sont attachées les Etoiles Fixes, n'a de luy-même aucune lumière, & par conséquent il devroit paroître noir; mais on le voit au travers de l'Air, qui est bleu, & il paraît bleu. Si cela est, les rayons du Soleil & des Etoiles ne peuvent passer au travers de l'Air sans se teindre un peu de sa couleur, & prendre autant de celle qui leur est naturelle. Mais quand même l'Air ne seroit pas coloré de lui-même, il est certain qu'au travers d'un gros brouillard, la lumiere d'un flambeau qu'on voit un peu de loin paroît toute rougeâtre, quoy que ce ne soit pas sa vraye couleur, & notre Air n'est non plus qu'un gros broüillard, qui nous doit alterer la vraye couleur & du Ciel & du Soleil & des Etoiles. Il n'appartiendroit qu'à la matière céleste de nous apporter la lumiere & les couleurs dans toute leur pureté <UP></UP>, & telles qu'elles sont. Ainsi, puis que l'Air de la Lune est d'une autre nature que notre Air, ou il est teint en luy-même d'une autre couleur, ou du moins c'est un autre broüillard qui cause une autre alteration aux couleurs des Corps celestes. Enfin, à l'égard des Gens de la Lune, cette Lunette au travers de laquelle on voit tout, est changée.</P044>
chunks.target_manual: <P034>You would be very Sick, said I, when you were drawn to the top of our Air, for it is not respirable in all its extent, as may be seen on the tops of some <UP>very high</UP> Mountains; and I admire that they who have the folly to believe that our Faries, whom they alow to be Corporeal, and to inhabit the most pure and refin'd Air, do not tell us that the reason why they give us such short and seldom visits, is that there are very few among them that can dive, and those that can, if it be possible to get through the thick Air where we are, cannot stay half so long in it, <UP>as one of the worst of Sir Harry Blount's Sponge- gatherers</UP>. Here then are natural Barricades, which defend the passage out of our World, as well as the Entry into that of the Moon; so that since we can only guess at that World, let us fancy all we can of it. For Example, I will suppose that we may see there the Firmament, the Sun, and the Stars, of another colour than what they are here; all these apear to us through a kind of Natural Spectacles, which change and alter the Objects. These Spectacles are our Air, mix'd as it is with Vapours and Exhalations, and which doth not extend it self very high. Some of our Modern Philosophers pretend, of it self it is blue, as well as the Water of the Sea, and that this colour neither appears in the one nor in the other, but at a great depth; the Firmament, say they, where the fix'd Stars are fastned, hath no peculiar light of its own, and by consequence must appear black, but we see it through the Air which is blue, and therefore to us it appears blue; which if so, the Beams of the Sun and Stars cannot pass through the Air without being ting'd a little with its colour, and losing as much of their own; yet were the Air of no colour, it is very certain, that through a great Mist the light of a Flambeau at some distance appears reddish, though it be not its true natural colour. Our Air is nothing but a great Mist, which changeth the true colour of the Sky, of the Sun, and of the Stars; it belongs only to the Celestial Matter to bring us the Light and Colours as they really are in all the purity; so that since the Air of the Moon is of another nature than our Air, or is stain'd of another colour, or at least is another kind of Mist, which causeth other alterations to the Colours of the Celestial Bodies; in short, as to the People of the Moon, their Spectacles through which they see every thing are chang'd.</P034>
source_segments: des Genies corporels
que des plongeons de très peu de durée.
target_segments: our Faries
cannot stay half so long in it, as one of the worst of Sir Harry Blount's Sponge- gatherers.
explanations: The French term "Genies corporels" (corporeal spirits or genii), which could refer to a range of speculative beings from natural philosophy or occult traditions of the period, is translated as "our Faries." This substitution narrows the original, broader concept to specific folkloric beings from British tradition. It alters the tone by potentially trivializing Fontenelle's speculation, making it sound more whimsical. The possessive "our" further domesticates the text, tailoring it to an English cultural context and subtly changing the perceived nature of the beings discussed from a more general philosophical speculation to local folklore.

The original French phrase "que des plongeons de très peu de durée" (meaning 'only dives of very short duration' or 'only very short dives') is significantly expanded in the English translation by the addition of a culturally specific English reference: "as one of the worst of Sir Harry Blount's Sponge-gatherers." This is an interpolation of new information not present in Fontenelle's text. This addition domesticates the work, alters the narrative voice of the philosopher by making it sound more colloquially English, and shifts the perception by grounding a general observation in a very particular, contemporary (to the translator's era) English context, thereby manipulating the reader's understanding of the original's style and content.

chunks.source_manual: <P045>Cela me fait préférer notre sejour à celuy de la Lune, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je ne saurois croire que l'assortiment des couleurs celestes y soit aussi beau qu'il l'est icy. Mettons, si vous voulez, un Ciel rouge, & des Etoiles vertes, l'effet n'est pas si agreable que des Etoiles couleur d'or sur du bleu. On diroit à vous entendre, <UP></UP>, repris-je, que vous assortiriez un habit, ou un meuble; mais, croyez-moy, la Nature a bien de l'esprit; laissez-luy le soin d'inventer un assortiment de couleurs pour la Lune, & je vous garantis qu'il sera bien entendu. Elle n'aura pas manqué de varier le Spectacle de l'Univers à chaque point de veüe diferent <UP></UP>, & de le varier d'une manière toûjours agreable.</P045> <P046>Je reconnois son adresse, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, elle s'est épargné la peine de changer les objets pour chaque point de veûe, elle n'a changé que les Lunettes, & elle a l'honneur de cette grande diversité, sans en avoir fait la dépense. Avec un air bleu, elle nous donne un Ciel bleu, & peut-être avec un Air rouge, elle donne un Ciel rouge aux Habitans de la Lune, c'est pourtant toûjours le même Ciel. Il me paroît qu'elle nous a mis dans l'imagination certaines Lunettes, au travers desquelles on voit tout, & qui changent fort les objets à l'égard de chaque homme. Alexandre voyoit la Terre comme une belle place bien propre à y établir un grand Empire. Celadon ne la voyoit que comme <RW>le sejour d'Astrée</RW>. Un Philosophe la voit comme une grosse Planète qui va par les Cieux, toute couverte de fous. Je ne croy pas que le Spectacle change plus de la Terre à la Lune, qu'il fait icy d'imagination à imagination.</P046>
chunks.target_manual: <P035>If it be so, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, I prefer my abode before that of the Moon; for I cannot believe the Celestial Colours are so well suited as they are here; for if you will let us put green Stars on a red Sky, they cannot be so agreable as Stars of Gold on an Azure Firmament. To hear you, said I, one would think you was chusing a <UP>Petticoat, or a suit of Knots; but believe me, Nature hath as good a Fancy as Mrs. Harrison</UP>; leave it to her to chuse Colours for the Moon, and I'll engage they shall be well sorted; she will not fail to vary the Prospect of the Universe, at every different point of Sight, and always the Alteration shall be very agreable. I know very well, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, her Skill in this Point; she is not at the charge of changing the Objects, but only the Spectacles, and hath the credit of this great variety, without being at any expence; with a blue Air, she gives us a blue Firmament; and perhaps with a red Air, she gives to the Inhabitants of the Moon a red Firmament; and yet still it is but the same Firmament; nay, I am of opinion, she hath plac'd a sort of Spectacles in our Imagination, through which we see all things, and which to every particular Man change the Objects. Alexander look'd on the Earth as a fit place to establish a great Empire, it seem'd to Celadon a proper residence for Astraea, and it appear'd to a Philosopher, a great Planet in the Heavens, covered with Fools: I do not believe the Sights vary more between the Earth and the Moon, than they do between one Man's Fancy and anothers.</P035>
source_segments: dit la Marquise
sur du bleu
que vous assortiriez un habit, ou un meuble
la Nature a bien de l'esprit
target_segments: said the Countess
on an Azure Firmament
you was chusing a Petticoat, or a suit of Knots
Nature hath as good a Fancy as Mrs. Harrison
explanations: The French "Marquise" denotes a specific rank in the French nobility. The translation changes this to "Countess," a different noble title. While both are aristocratic, altering the specific title subtly changes the character's exact social standing and anglicizes her identity, which can shift the reader's perception of her within the dialogue's social dynamics.

The original French "sur du bleu" simply means "on blue" or "on a blue background," referring to the color of the sky. The translation "on an Azure Firmament" introduces "Azure," a more poetic and specific term for blue, and "Firmament," a somewhat grandiose and formal term for the heavens. This embellishment elevates the tone of the Marquise's statement, making her language more ornate than in the original and subtly altering the register of her speech.

The original French uses general examples for comparison: "un habit" (an item of clothing/an outfit) and "un meuble" (a piece of furniture). The translation replaces these with "a Petticoat" (a specifically female undergarment) and "a suit of Knots" (fashionable ribbon adornments, typically for women). This significantly narrows the comparison to items exclusively associated with contemporary feminine fashion. By doing so, the translation makes the Marquise's analogy seem more stereotypically feminine and potentially more trivial than Fontenelle's broader, more general examples, subtly manipulating the tone of the philosopher's gentle critique.

The French "la Nature a bien de l'esprit" translates to "Nature has great wit/ingenuity" or "Nature is very clever." The translation changes "esprit" (wit/intellect) to "Fancy" (imagination/caprice), altering the attribute ascribed to Nature. More significantly, the addition of "as Mrs. Harrison" introduces a specific, contemporary English cultural reference (a known London milliner or tastemaker of the period) entirely absent from Fontenelle's original. This addition domesticates the text and shifts the reader's perception by grounding Nature's abilities in a comparison to a specific human known for fashion, trivializing Fontenelle's more abstract philosophical point about Nature's inherent ingenuity and altering the original's universal tone.

chunks.source_manual: <P047>Le changement de spectacle est plus surprenant dans nos imaginations, répliquay-je, car ce ne sont que les mêmes objets qu'on voit si diferemment; du moins dans la Lune on peut voir d'autres objets, ou ne pas voir quelques-uns de ceux qu'on voit icy. Peut-être ne connaissent-ils point en ce Pays-là l'Aurore, ny les Crepuscules, avant che le Soleil se leve, ou après qu'il est couché. L 'Air qui nous environne, & qui est élevé au-dessus de nous, reçoit des rayons qui ne pourroient pas tomber sur la Terre; & parce qu'il est fort grossier, il en arrête une partie, & nous les renvoye, quoy qu'ils ne nous fussent pas naturellement destinés. Ainsi l'Aurore & les Crépuscules sont une grace que la Nature nous fait; c'est une lumiere que regulièrement nous ne devrions point avoir, & qu'elle nous donne par dessus ce qui nous est dû. Mais dans la Lune, où apparemment l'Air est plus pur, il pourroit bien n'être pas si propre à renvoyer en en bas les rayons qu'il reçoit du Soleil avant qu'il se leve, ou aprés qu'il est couché. Vous n'avez donc cette lumiere de faveur <NCP></NCP>, qui en se fortifiant peu à peu, vous prepare agreablement à l'arrivée du Soleil, ou qui en s'affoiblissant comme de nuance en nuance, vous accoûtume à sa perte. Vous êtes dans des tenebres profondes <NCP></NCP>, & tout d'un coup il semble qu'on tire un rideau, voilà vos yeux frapez de tout l'éclat qui est dans le Soleil; vous êtes dans une lumière vive & éclatante, & tout d'un coup vous voilà tombés dans des tenebres profondes. Le jour & la nuit ne sont point liez par un milieu qui tienne de l'un & de l'autre. L'Arc-en-ciel est encore une chose qui manque aux Gens de la Lune, car si l'Aurore est un effet de la grossiereté de l'air & des vapeurs, l'Arc-en-ciel se forme dans les nuages d'ou tombent les pluyes, & nous devons les plus belles choses du monde à celles qui le sont le moins. Puis <UP></UP> qu'il n'y a autour de la Lune ny vapeurs assez grossières, ny nuages pluvieux, adieu l'Arc-en-ciel avec l'Aurore, & à quoy ressembleront les Belles de ce Pays-là? Quelle source de comparaisons perduë!</P047>
chunks.target_manual: <P036>This change in our Imaginations, said I, is very surprizing; for they are still the same Objects, tho' they appear different; when in the Moon, we may see other Objects we do not see here, or at least, not see all there we do see here; perhaps in that Country they know nothing of the Dawn and the Twilight, before the Sun riseth, and after the Sun sets; the Air which encompasseth, and is elevated above us, receives the Rays, so that they cannot strike on the Earth; and being gross, stops some of them, and sends 'em to us, tho' indeed they were never naturally design'd us; so that the Day-break and the Twilight are a favour which Nature bestows on us; they are a Light which regularly we should not have, and which she gives us over and above our due; but in the Moon, where apparently the Air is more pure, and therefore not so proper to send down the Beams it receives from the Sun before his rising, and after his setting; you have not that Light of Grace <NCP>(as I may call it)</NCP> which growing greater by degrees, doth more agreably prepare you for the arrival of the Sun, and which growing weaker, and diminishing by degrees, doth insensibly prepare you for the Sun's departure: But you are in a profound darkness, where a Curtain <NCP>(as it were)</NCP> is drawn all on a sudden, your Eyes are immediately dazled with the whole light of the Sun, in all its glory and brightness; so likewise, you are on a sudden surpriz'd with utter Darkness; the Night and the Day have no medium between them, but you fall in a moment from one extreme into the other. The Rainbow likewise is not known to them in the Moon; for if the Dawn is an effect of the grossness of the Air and Vapours, the Rainbow is form'd in the Clouds, from whence the Rain falls; so that the most beautiful things in the World, are produc'd by those things which have no beauty at all. Since then there are no Vapours thick enough, nor no Clouds of Rain about the Moon, farewell Dawn, adieu Rainbow: What must Lovers do for Similies in that Countrey, when such an inexhaustible Magazine of Comparisons is taken from them?</P036>

il semble qu'on tire un rideau
de tout l'éclat qui est dans le Soleil

a Curtain (as it were) is drawn
in all its glory and brightness
the Night and the Day have no medium between them, but you fall in a moment from one extreme into the other.
which have no beauty at all

explanations: The French "lumiere de faveur" (light of favour/grace) is translated as "Light of Grace." The translator's addition of the parenthetical phrase "(as I may call it)" is not present in the original. This interjection subtly changes the tone from Fontenelle's direct, authoritative philosopher to a narrator who seems more hesitant or self-conscious about coining the phrase, thereby diminishing the assertiveness of the statement and adding a conversational flourish not in the French.

Fontenelle's original "il semble qu'on tire un rideau" (it seems that one draws a curtain) presents a metaphor. The translation renders this as "a Curtain (as it were) is drawn". The addition of "(as it were)" explicitly flags and slightly distances the speaker from the metaphor, making the language less direct and more self-aware than the original, altering the narrative style.

The French "de tout l'éclat qui est dans le Soleil" (of all the brilliance/radiance that is in the Sun) is amplified in the translation to "in all its glory and brightness." While "brightness" aligns with "éclat," the addition of "glory" introduces a more grandiose and potentially heightened connotation (e.g. divine glory, majesty) than the original "éclat," which more straightforwardly denotes intense light or splendour. This amplifies the original description, subtly shifting its qualitative feel.

The original French sentence is a concise, declarative statement: "Le jour & la nuit ne sont point liez par un milieu qui tienne de l'un & de l'autre" (The day and night are not at all linked by a medium that partakes of both). The translation accurately conveys the first part ("the Night and the Day have no medium between them") but then adds a new clause: "but you fall in a moment from one extreme into the other." This clause, while consistent with the preceding description of sudden transitions, is an addition by the translator that makes the statement more explicit and dramatic, altering the conciseness and rhetorical structure of Fontenelle's prose.

Fontenelle writes "celles qui le sont le moins" meaning "those [things] that are the least [beautiful/so]". This indicates a very low degree of beauty. The translation changes this to "which have no beauty at all." This shifts from a relative lack of beauty (least beautiful) to an absolute negation (no beauty at all). This exaggeration intensifies the paradox Fontenelle presents, making the contrast starker and less nuanced than in the original, thereby manipulating the reader's perception of the statement.

Fontenelle's text refers to "les Belles de ce Pays-là" (the Beauties [beautiful women] of that country) and laments the "source de comparaisons perduë" (lost source of comparisons). The translation significantly alters this by changing the subject from "les Belles" to "Lovers," shifting the focus from the objects of aesthetic contemplation to the (implicitly male) agents of poetic comparison. Furthermore, the simple and evocative "Quelle source de comparaisons perduë!" is expanded into the much more elaborate and metaphorically loaded "when such an inexhaustible Magazine of Comparisons is taken from them?". The term "inexhaustible Magazine" introduces a complex metaphor not present in the original's "source," and "is taken from them" adds an active sense of deprivation. These changes substantially alter the meaning, tone, and imagery of the original.

chunks.source_manual: <P048>Je n'aurois pas grand regret à ces comparaisons là, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, & je trouve qu'on est assez bien recompense dans la Lune <UP></UP>, de n'avoir ny Aurore ny Arc-en- ciel, car on ne doit avoir par la même raison ny Foudres ny Tonnerres, puisque ce sont aussi des choses qui se forment dans les nüages. On a de beaux jours toûjours serains pendant lesquels on ne perd point le Soleil de venë <NCE></NCE>. On n'a point de nuits où toutes les Etoiles ne se montrent <UP></UP>; on ne connoît ny les orages, ny les tempêtes, ny tout ce qui paroît être un effet de la colere du Ciel, trouvez-vous qu'on soit tant à plaindre? Vous me faites voir la Lune comme un séjour enchanté, répondis-je; cependant je ne say s'il est si délicieux d'avoir toûjours sur la tête, un Soleil ardent dont aucun nüage ne modère la chaleur. Peut-être aussi est-ce à cause de cela que la Nature a creusé dans la Lune des especes de Puits, qui sont assez grands pour être apperçus par nos Lunettes; car ce ne sont point des Vallées qui soient entre des Montagnes, ce sont des creux que l'on voit au milieu de certains lieux plats. Que sait-on si les Habitans de la Lune, incommodez par l'ardeur perpetuelle du Soleil, ne se refugient point dans ces grands Puits? Ils n'habitent peut-être point ailleurs, c'est là qu'ils bâtissent leurs Villes. Nous voyons icy que la Rome soûterraine êtoit presque aussi grande que la Rome qui est sur Terre. Il ne faudroit qu'ôter celle-cy, le reste seroit une Ville à la manière de la Lune. Tout un Peuple est dans un Puits, & d'un Puits à l'autre il y a des chemins soûterrains pour la communication des Peuples. Vous vous moquez de cette vision, j'y consens de tout mon cur; cependant, à vous parler tres serieusement, vous pourriez vous tromper plutôt que moy. Vous croyez que les Gens de la Lune doivent habiter sur la surface de leur Planete, parce que nous habitons sur la surface de la nôtre: c'est tout le contraire, puisque nous habitons sur la surface de notre Planete, ils pourraient bien n'habiter pas sur la surface de la leur. D'icy là il faut que toutes choses soient bien différentes. <UP></UP></P048>
chunks.target_manual: <P037>I doubt not, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, but there are those in the Moon as good at Simily as <UP>the greatest Beau in Covent-Garden</UP>; and had they neither Sun nor Stars, <NCE>Pearls nor Rubies, Roses nor Lillies</NCE>, yet could say as many fine things to <UP>a Visor-Mask, as the pertest Wit at the Puppet Show</UP>; and they are well enough recompenc'd for the loss of our Dawn and Rainbow; for by the same reason, they have neither Thunder nor Lightning, both which are formed in the Clouds; how glorious are their days, the Sun continually shining? How pleasant their Nights, not the least Star is hid from them? They never hear of Storms or Tempests, which certainly are an effect of the wrath of Heaven: Do you think then they stand in need of our pity? You are describing the Moon, I reply'd, like an enchanted Palace; but do you think it is so pleasant to have a scorching Sun always over our Heads, and not the least Cloud to moderate its Heat? Tho' I fancy 'tis for this reason that Nature hath made great Cavities in the Moon; we can discern 'em easily with our Tellescopes, for they are not Mountains, but so many Wells or Vaults in the middle of a Plain; and what do we know but the Inhabitants of the Moon, being continually broil'd by the excessive heat of the Sun, do retire into those great Wells; perhaps they live no where else, and 'tis there they build 'em Cities; for we still see in the Ruines of old Rome, that that part of the City which was under ground, <UP>was almost as large as that which was above ground. I fancy, during the late siege of Buda, they liv'd there as they do in the Moon, or 'tis but going to the Fountain Tavern Cellar, where the several Vaults are as so many high Streets, the Vats, Pipes, Hogsheads, so many different Edifices, and the Drawers and Coopers, like so many Troglodites</UP>. I perceive you laugh at me, yet if I may be so free with a fair Lady, you deserve it much better than I; for you believe the People in the Moon must live upon the surface of their Planet, because we do so upon ours; but quite contrary, since we dwell upon the Superficies of our Planet, they should not dwell upon the superficies of their Planet; if things differ so much in this World, what must they do in another?</P037>

target_segments: I doubt not, said the Countess, but there are those in the Moon as good at Simily as the greatest Beau in Covent-Garden; and had they neither Sun nor Stars, Pearls nor Rubies, Roses nor Lillies, yet could say as many fine things to a Visor-Mask, as the pertest Wit at the Puppet Show;

I fancy, during the late siege of Buda, they liv'd there as they do in the Moon, or 'tis but going to the Fountain Tavern Cellar, where the several Vaults are as so many high Streets, the Vats, Pipes, Hogsheads, so many different Edifices, and the Drawers and Coopers, like so many Troglodites.
yet if I may be so free with a fair Lady, you deserve it much better than I;
explanations: The Marquise's original brief and simple remark, 'I wouldn't have much regret for those comparisons,' is entirely replaced with a lengthy, elaborate speech. This new speech is filled with contemporary English cultural references (Covent Garden, Visor-Mask, Puppet Show), which fundamentally alters the Marquise's character from Fontenelle's sophisticated French figure to a witty London socialite. This addition manipulates the reader's perception by localizing the dialogue and changing its original tone and characterization.

Fontenelle's imaginative speculation about Moon cities built around wells with subterranean passages, inspired by subterranean Rome, is omitted. Instead, the translator inserts a completely different set of analogies drawn from contemporary English/European life: the 'late siege of Buda' and a detailed description of the 'Fountain Tavern Cellar.' This substitution replaces the original's philosophical playfulness with mundane, topical references, thereby manipulating the tone and focus of the philosopher's discourse from universal popular science to localized commentary.

The philosopher's original polite and intellectually grounded admonition, 'however, to speak to you very seriously, you could be more mistaken than I,' is transformed into a more personal, flirtatious, and condescending remark: 'yet if I may be so free with a fair Lady, you deserve it much better than I'. This change in tone manipulates the perceived relationship between the philosopher and the Marquise, shifting it from a respectful intellectual exchange to a more socially charged and less egalitarian interaction.

chunks.source_manual: <P049>Il n'importe, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je ne puis me resoudre à laisser vivre les Habitans de la Lune dans une obscurité perpetuelle. Vous y auriez encore plus de peine, répris-je, si vous saviez qu'un grand Philosophe de l'Antiquité a fait de la Lune le séjour des âmes qui ont merité icy d'être bien-heureuses. Toute leur felicité consiste en ce qu'elles y entendent l'Harmonie que les Corps Celestes font par leurs mouvements; mais comme il pretend que quand la Lune tombe dans l'ombre de la Terre, elles ne peuvent plus entendre cette Harmonie <UP></UP>; alors, dit-il, ces Ames crient comme des desesperées, & la Lune se hâte le plus qu'elle peut de les tirer d'un endroit si fâcheux. Nous devrions donc, répliqua-t-elle, voir arriver icy les Bienheureux de la Lune, car apparemment on nous les envoye aussi; & dans ces deux Planetes on croit avoir assez pourveu à la felicité des Ames, de les avoir transportées dans un autre Monde. Serieusement, repris-je, ce ne seroit pas un plaisir mediocre de voir plusieurs Mondes differens. Ce Voyage me réjoüit quelquefois beaucoup à ne le faire qu'en imagination, & que seroit-ce, si on le faisoit en effet? Cela vaudroit bien mieux que d'aller d'icy au Japon, c'est- à-dire de ramper avec beaucoup de peine d'un point de la Terre sur un autre, pour ne voir que des hommes. Eh bien, dit-elle, faisons le Voyage des Planètes comme nous pourrons; qui nous en empêche? Allons nous placer dans tous ces differens points de veuê, & de là considérons l'Univers. N'avons- nous plus rien à voir dans la Lune? Je croy que non, répondis-je du moins je vous y ay fait voir tout ce qui êtoit de ma connoissance. Au sortir de la Lune en tirant vers le Soleil, on trouve Vénus. Sur Vénus je reprens le <NCE>Saint-Denis</NCE>. Vénus tourne sur elle-même, & autour du Soleil <UP>comme la Lune</UP>, on découvre avec les <NCP><IIM>Lunettes d'approche</IIM></NCP>, que Vénus aussi bien que la Lune est tantôt en Croissant, tantôt en Décours, tantôt pleine selon les diverses situations où elle est à l'égard de la Terre. La Lune, selon toutes les apparences, est habitée, pourquoy Vénus ne le sera-t-elle pas aussi? Mais, interrompit-elle, en disant toüjours Pourquoy non, vous m'allez mettre des Habitans dans toutes les Planètes? N'en doutez pas, répliquay-je, ce Pourquoy a une vertu qui suffira pour peupler tout. Nous voyons que toutes les Planètes sont de la même Nature, toutes des Corps <IIM>opaques</IIM> qui ne reçoivent de la lumière que du Soleil, qui se la renvoyent les uns aux autres, & qui n'ont que les mêmes mouvements, jusque là tout est égal. Cependant, il faudroit concevoir que ces grands Corps auroient êté faits pour n'être point habitez, que ce seroit là leur condition naturelle, & qu'il y aurait une exception justement en faveur de la Terre toute seule. Qui voudra le croire, le croye; pour moi, je ne m'y puis pas resoudre? Je vous trouve, dit-elle, bien affermy dans vôtre opinion depuis quelques instans. <UP></UP> Je viens de voir le moment que la Lune seroit deserte, & que vous ne vous en souciîez pas beaucoup, & presentement si on osoit vous dire que toutes les Planetes ne sont pas aussi habitées que la Terre, je voy bien que vous vous mettriez en colere. Il est vray, répondis-je, que dans le moment où vous venez de me surprendre, si vous m'eussiez contredit sur les Habitans des Planetes, non seulement je vous les aurois soutenus, mais je crois que je vous aurois dit comment ils êtoient tous faits. Il y a des momens pour croire, & je ne les ay jamais si bien crûs que dans celuy là; presentement que je suis un peu plus de sens froid, je ne laisse pas de trouver qu'il seroit bien étrange que la Terre fût aussi habitée qu'elle l'est, & que les autres Planètes ne le fussent point du tout; car ne croyez pas que nous voyions tout ce qui habite la Terre; il y a autant d'espèces d'Animaux invisibles que de visibles. Nous voyons depuis l'Eléphant jusqu'au <UP></UP> Ciron; là finit notre veuë; mais au Ciron commence une multitude infinie d'Animaux, dont il est l'Eléphant, & que la simple veuë ne sauroit apercevoir. On a vu avec des <RW>Lunettes</RW> beaucoup de Liqueurs toutes remplis de petits Animaux que l'on n'aurait jamais soupçonnez d'y être, & il y a quelque apparence que le goût quelles font sentir, sont les piqueures que ces petits Animaux font à la langue & au palais. Mêlez de certaines choses dans quelques-unes de ces Liqueurs, ou exposez-les au Soleil, ou laissez-les se corrompre, voilà aussi-tôt de nouvelles especes de petits Animaux.</P049>
chunks.target_manual: <P038>'Tis no matter, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, I can never suffer the Inhabitants of the Moon to live in perpetual darkness. You will be more concern'd for 'em, I reply'd, when I tell you that one of the ancient Philosophers did long since discover the Moon to be the abode of the blessed Souls departed out of this Life, and that all their Happiness consisted in hearing the Harmony of the Spheres; <UP>that is, the Musick (I had like to have said Noise) which is made by the motion of the Celestial Bodies; if you have seen a Rar�e Show, you will easily comprehend it: But because the Philosopher pretends to know exactly all they do there, he tells you, that when the Moon is obscur'd by the shadow of the Earth, they no longer hear the Heavenly Musick, but howl like so many Souls in Purgatory</UP>; so that the Moon taking pity of 'em, makes all the haste she can to get into the Light again. Methinks then, says she, we should now and then see some of the Blessed Souls arrive here from the Moon, for certainly they are sent to us. I confess indeed, said I, it would be very pleasant to see different Worlds; such a Voyage, tho' but in Imagination, is very delightful; what would it be in effect? It would be much better certainly than to go to Japan, which at best, is but crawling from one end of the World to t' other, and after all to see nothing but Men. Well then, says she, let us travel over the Planets, as fast as we can; what should hinder us? Let us place our selves at all the different Prospects, and from thence consider the Universe. But first, have we any thing more to see in the Moon? I believe not, I reply'd; at least, you have seen all I can shew you. Coming out of the Moon, towards the Sun, we see Venus, which puts me again in mind of <NCE>Greenwich</NCE>. Venus turns upon her self, and round the Sun, as well as the Moon; they likewise discover by their Tellescopes, that Venus like the Moon, <NCP>(if I may speak after the same manner)</NCP> is sometimes new, sometimes full, and sometimes in the wain, according to the diverse situations she is in, in respect of the Earth.</P038> <P039>The Moon, to all appearance, is inhabited, why should no Venus be so too? You are so full of your Whys, and your Wherefores, says she, interrupting me, that I fancy you are sending Colonies to all the Planets. You may be certain, so I will, I reply'd, for I see no reason to the contrary; we find that all the Planets are of the same nature, all <IIM>obscure</IIM> Bodies, which receive no light but from the Sun, and then send it to one another; their motions are the same, so that hitherto they are alike; and yet if we are to believe that these vast Bodies are not inhabited, I think they were made but to little purpose; why should Nature be so partial, as to except only the Earth? But let who will say the contrary, I must believe the Planets are peopled as well as the Earth. I find, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, with some concern, <UP>a Philosopher will never make a good Martyr</UP>, you can so quickly shift your Opinion, 'twas not many minutes since the Moon was a perfect Desart, now the rest of the Planets are inhabited. Why truly, Madam, said I, there is a time for all things, and your true Philosopher believes any thing, or nothing, <UP>as the Maggot bites</UP>. Had you taken me in the <UP>sceptical Vein</UP>, I would have as soon granted a Nation in a Mustard Ball, as a living Creature in the Moon; but the tide is turn'd, and all the Planets are Peopled like an <UP>Anthill</UP>; yet, <UP>Raillery apart</UP>, this is not so very improbable as you think it; for do you believe we discover, (as I may say) all the Inhabitants of the Earth? there be as many kinds of invisible as visible Creatures; we see from the Elephant to the very Hand-worm, beyond which our Sight fails us, and yet counting from that minute Creature, there are an infinity of lesser Animals, which were they perceptible, would be as little in comparison with a Mite, as a Mite is of an Ox. How lately have our <NCE>Virtuoso's</NCE> found out the Pepper Worms, which in the least drop of <RW>Water appear like so many Dolphins, sporting in the Ocean</RW>; nay, they tell you that the sharpness of Vinegar consists in the fierceness of the little Animals that bite you by the Tongue; not to name the blue on Plums, and twenty Experiments of the like nature.</P039>

explanations: The original French 'ces Ames crient comme des desesperées' (these Souls cry out like desperate ones) describes a general state of distress. The English translation 'howl like so many Souls in Purgatory' introduces the specific theological concept of Purgatory, a doctrine rejected by Protestantism and highly sensitive in late 17th-century England. This addition frames the suffering in potentially controversial religious terms not present in the original, subtly manipulating the reader's perception by associating the scene with a specific and potentially contentious belief system.

Fontenelle refers to 'l'Harmonie que les Corps Celestes font par leurs mouvements' (the Harmony that the Celestial Bodies make by their movements). The English translation adds the parenthetical ' (I had like to have said Noise)' and the comparison 'if you have seen a Rar�e Show, you will easily comprehend it:'. These additions, absent in the original, significantly lower the tone and trivialize the grand philosophical concept of the Harmony of the Spheres, manipulating the reader's perception by making it seem less profound and more akin to common entertainment or mere noise.

The English translation omits the latter part of the Marquise's sentence: '& dans ces deux Planetes on croit avoir assez pourveu à la felicité des Ames, de les avoir transportées dans un autre Monde.' (and in these two Planets one believes to have sufficiently provided for the felicity of Souls, by having transported them to another World.). This omitted segment contains a philosophical reflection or critique on the simplistic idea that happiness for souls can be achieved merely by relocating them. Its removal simplifies the Marquise's thought and diminishes the perceptive depth of her commentary.

The original French phrase 'Sur Vénus je reprens le Saint-Denis' contains a reference to 'Saint-Denis,' a significant French royal and religious site with Catholic associations. The English translation substitutes this with 'which puts me again in mind of Greenwich,' a site known for the English Royal Observatory. This cultural substitution shifts the reference from a French, potentially religious, context to an English, scientific one, possibly to align the text with English national pride or avoid Catholic connotations in a Protestant society, thereby subtly manipulating the cultural framing.

The Marquise's French question 'vous m'allez mettre des Habitans dans toutes les Planètes?' (are you going to put Inhabitants on all the Planets for me?) is a general expression of populating. The English translation 'that I fancy you are sending Colonies to all the Planets' introduces the term 'Colonies.' This choice of word, evoking contemporary English colonial expansion, reframes the philosophical speculation with an imperialistic overtone not present in the original, thereby subtly shifting the reader's perception.

Fontenelle’s philosopher states that the question 'Pourquoy' (Why/Why not) 'a une vertu qui suffira pour peupler tout' (has a power/efficacy that will suffice to populate everything), highlighting the imaginative power of inquiry. The English translation reduces this to the bland 'for I see no reason to the contrary;'. This significantly weakens the original's philosophical and whimsical assertion about the creative force of questioning, altering the intellectual tone from inventive to merely logical.

In the French, the Marquise observes the philosopher's sudden conviction, predicting 'vous vous mettriez en colere' (you would get angry) if contradicted. The English translation replaces this specific observation of a potential emotional outburst with a general, judgmental maxim: 'a Philosopher will never make a good Martyr, you can so quickly shift your Opinion,'. This addition introduces the unrelated concept of martyrdom and critiques philosophers' steadfastness, significantly altering the nature of the Marquise's comment and imposing a different interpretive frame.

The philosopher in French describes his enthusiastic belief as 'Il y a des momens pour croire, & je ne les ay jamais si bien crûs que dans celuy là;' (There are moments for believing, and I never believed them so strongly as in that one;). The English translation recasts this as 'your true Philosopher believes any thing, or nothing, as the Maggot bites.' This colloquial and dismissive phrase portrays the philosopher as fickle and capricious, rather than someone experiencing moments of deep imaginative conviction, thereby manipulating the reader's understanding of his intellectual process and seriousness.

Fontenelle's impersonal 'On a vu' (One has seen) regarding microscopic life is translated as 'How lately have our Virtuoso's found out...', localizing discovery to English scientists. The general 'petits Animaux' in 'Liqueurs' becomes the specific 'Pepper Worms' with the added picturesque detail 'like so many Dolphins, sporting in the Ocean'. Furthermore, Fontenelle's cautious 'il y a quelque apparence que...les piqueures' (there is some likelihood that...the pricks/stings) is intensified to the more assertive and dramatic 'the sharpness of Vinegar consists in the fierceness of the little Animals that bite you.' These changes introduce an anglocentric bias, add sensationalist embellishment, and alter the original's scientific caution.

Fontenelle describes experiments suggesting the generation of new life: 'Mêlez de certaines choses...voilà aussi-tôt de nouvelles especes de petits Animaux.' (Mix certain things...and right away there are new species of small animals.), touching on spontaneous generation. The English translation replaces this with the unrelated 'not to name the blue on Plums, and twenty Experiments of the like nature.' This substitution omits Fontenelle's scientifically provocative point about the emergence of new species and replaces it with a mundane observation and a vague dismissal, potentially to avoid a controversial topic, thereby manipulating the reader by eliding a significant part of the original scientific speculation.

chunks.source_manual: <P050>Beaucoup de Corps qui paroissent solides <UP></UP>, ne sont que des amas de ces Animaux imperceptibles, qui y trouvent pour leurs mouvemens autant de liberté qu'il leur en faut. Une feüille d'Arbre est un petit Monde habité par des Vermisseaux invisibles, à qui elle paroît d'une étenduë immense, qui y connaissent des Montagnes & des Abîmes, & qui d'un côté de la feüille à l'autre, n'ont pas plus de communication avec les autres Vermisseaux qui y vivent, que nous avec nos Antipodes. A plus forte raison, ce me semble, une <RW>grosse</RW> Planete sera-t-elle un Monde habité. On a trouvé jusque dans des especes de pierres tres dures de petits Vers sans nombre, qui y étoient logez de toutes parts dans des vuides insensibles, & qui ne se nourrissoient que de la substance de ces pierres qu'ils rongeaient. Figurez-vous combien il y avoit de ces petits Vers, & pendant combien d'années ils subsistoient de la grosseur d'un grain de sable; & sur cet exemple, quand la Lune ne seroit qu'un amas de rochers, je la ferois plutôt ronger par ses Habitans que de n'y en pas mettre. Enfin tout est vivant, tout est animé <UP></UP>: mettez toutes ces especes d'Animaux nouvellement découvertes, & même toutes celles que l'on conçoit aisément qui sont encore à découvrir, avec celles que l'on a toûjours veuës, vous trouverez assurément que la Terre est bien peuplée, & que la Nature y a si liberalement répandu les Animaux, qu'elle ne s'est pas mise en peine que l'on en vît seulement la moitié. Croirez-vous qu'aprés qu'elle a poussé icy sa fecondité jusqu'à l'exces, elle a êté pour toutes les autres Planètes d'une stérilité à n'y rien produire de vivant?</P050> <P051>Ma raison est assez bien convaincuë, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, mais mon imagination est accablée de la multitude infinie des Habitans de toutes ces Planètes, & embarrassée de la diversité qu'il faut établir entre eux; car je voy bien que la Nature, selon qu'elle est ennemie des repetitions, les aura tous faits différens, mais comment se representer cela? Ce n'est pas à l'imagination à prétendre le représenter, répondis-je, elle n'êst pas propre à aller plus loin que les yeux. On peut seulement apercevoir d'une certaine veuë universelle, la diversité que la Nature doit avoir mise entre tous ces Mondes. Tous les visages sont en general sur un même modele; mais ceux de deux grandes Nations, comme des Européens, si vous voulez, & des Africains, paroissent être faits sur deux modeles particuliers, & il faudroit encore trouver le modele des visages de chaque Famille. Quel secret doit avoir eu la Nature pour varier en tant de manieres une chose aussi simple qu'un visage? Nous ne sommes dans l'Univers que comme une petite Famille, dont tous les visages se ressemblent; dans une autre Planète, c'est une autre Famille dont les visages ont un autre air. <UP></UP>.</P051> <P052>Apparemment les differences augmentent à mesure que l'on s'éloigne, & qui verroit un Habitant de la Lune, & un Habitant de la Terre, remarqueroit bien qu'ils seroient de deux Mondes plus voisins qu'un Habitant de la Terre & un Habitant de Saturne. Icy, <NCP>par exemple</NCP>, on a l'usage de la voix, ailleurs on ne parle que par signes; plus loin on ne parle point du tout. Icy, le raisonnement se forme entierement par l'experience; ailleurs l'experience y ajoûte fort peu de chose, plus loin les Vieillards n'en savent pas plus que les Enfants. Icy, on se tourmente de l'avenir plus que du passé; plus loin on se tourmente ny de l'un ny de l'autre, & ceux-là ne sont peut-être pas les plus malheureux. On dit qu'il pourroit bien nous manquer un sixiéme Sens naturel, qui nous aprendroit beaucoup de choses que nous ignorons. Ce sixiéme Sens est apparemment dans quelque autre Monde, où il manque quelqu'un des cinq que nous possedons. Peut-être même y a-t-il effectivement un grand nombre de Sens naturels; mais dans le partage que nous avons fait avec les Habitans des autres Planètes, il ne nous en est échu que cinq, dont nous nous contentons faute d'en connoître d'autres. Nos Sciences ont de certaines bornes que l'Esprit humain n'a jamais pû passer; il y a un point où elles nous manquent tout à coup, le reste est pour d'autres Mondes, où quelque chose de ce que nous savons est inconnu. <RW>Cette Planète-cy</RW> joüit des douceurs de l'Amour, mais elle est toûjours desolée en plusieurs de ses parties par les fureurs de la Guerre. Dans une autre Planète on joüit d'une Paix éternelle, mais au milieu de cette Paix on ne connoît point l'Amour, & on s'ennuye. Enfin ce que la Nature pratique en petit entre les hommes pour la distribution du bonheur où des talens, elle l'aura sans doute pratiqué en grand entre les Mondes, & elle se sera bien souvenuë de mettre en usage ce secret merveilleux qu'elle a de diversifier toutes choses, & de les égaler en même temps que les compensations.</P052>
chunks.target_manual: <P040>Nay, to shew you that they can see <UP>as far into a Milstone as Descartes himself</UP>, they have discover'd that several, even of the most solid Bodies, are nothing but an immense swarm of imperceptible Animals: Do but consider this little Leaf; why it is a great World, of a vast extent, what Mountains, what Abysses are there in it? the Insects of one side, know no more of their fellow Creatures on t' other side, then you and I can tell what they are now doing at the Antipodes; is it not reason then that a great Planet should be inhabited? In the hardest Stones, for Example, in Marble, there are an infinity of Worms, which fill up the vacuums, and feed upon the substance of the Stone; fancy then millions of living Creatures to subsist; many years on a grain of Sand; so that were the Moon but one continued Rock, she should be gnaw'd by these invisible Mites, (as <UP>if she were a green Cheese) rather than not be inhabited: In short, every thing is animated, and the Stones upon Salisbury Plain are as much alive, as a Hive of Bees</UP>; imagine then those Animals which are yet undiscovered, and add them and those which are but lately discover'd, to those we have always seen, you will find the Earth swarms with Inhabitants. Why then should Nature, which is fruitful to an excess here, be so very barren in the rest of the Planets? I must own, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, you have convinc'd my Reason, but you have confounded my Fancy, with such variety, that I cannot imagine how Nature, which hates Repetitions, should produce so many different kinds. There is no need of Fancy, I reply'd, do but trust your Eyes, and you will easily perceive how Nature diversifies in these several Worlds.</P040> <P041>All humane Faces, in general, are of the same Model, and yet the Europeans and the Africans have two particular Moulds; nay, commonly every Family have a different Form; what secret then has Nature to shew so much variety in the single Face? Our World, in respect of the Universe, is but a little Family; all whose Faces have some resemblance; in another Place, there is another Family, whose Faces have a different Air and Fashion; <UP>the difference too increaseth with the distance, for whosoever should see an Inhabitant of the Moon, and an Inhabitant of the Earth, would soon perceive they were nearer Neighbours than one of the Earth, and one of Saturn; here, for Example, we have the use of Voice, in another World, they speak by Signs, and at a greater distance they do not speak at all; here our Reason is form'd by Experience, in the next World, Experience contributes little towards it; and in the next to that, old Men know no more than Children; here we are troubled more with what is to come, than with what is past; further off, they are not concern'd with either, which by the way, I think, is much the better: Here, 'tisthought we want a sixth Sense, which would teach us many things, of which we are now ignorant; this sixth Sense, is apparently in another World, where they want one of the five which we enjoy; nay, perhaps there is a much greater number of Senses, but in the Partition we have made of 'em with the Inhabitants of the other Planets, there are but five fall'n to our share, with which we are well contented, for want of being acquainted with the rest: Our Sciences have bounds, which the wit of Man could never pass; there is a point where they fail us on a sudden, the rest is reserv'd for other Worlds, where somewhat which we know, is unknown to them. This Planet enjoys the pleasures of Love, but lies desolate in several places by the fury of War; in another Planet, they enjoy a perpetual Peace, yet in the midst of that Peace, know nothing of Love, and time lies on their hands; in a word, that which Nature practises here in little, in distributing her Gifts among Mankind; she does at large in other Worlds, where she makes use of that admirable secret she hath to diversifie all things, and at the same time makes 'em equal, by compensating for the inequality; this I confess is on the Borders of Nonsense, but a Man is ne'er the less a Philosopher for being a little obscure, if not unintelligible.</UP></P041>
