elle n'êst pas propre à aller plus loin que les yeux. On peut seulement apercevoir d'une certaine veuë universelle, la diversité que la Nature doit avoir mise entre tous ces Mondes.
& ceux-là ne sont peut-être pas les plus malheureux.
& elle se sera bien souvenuë de mettre en usage ce secret merveilleux qu'elle a de diversifier toutes choses, & de les égaler en même temps que les compensations.
Apparemment les differences augmentent à mesure que l'on s'éloigne,
target_segments: Nay, to shew you that they can see as far into a Milstone as Descartes himself, they have discover'd that several, even of the most solid Bodies, are nothing but an immense swarm of imperceptible Animals:
In the hardest Stones, for Example, in Marble, there are an infinity of Worms, which fill up the vacuums, and feed upon the substance of the Stone;
she should be gnaw'd by these invisible Mites, (as if she were a green Cheese) rather than not be inhabited:
In short, every thing is animated, and the Stones upon Salisbury Plain are as much alive, as a Hive of Bees;
you will find the Earth swarms with Inhabitants. Why then should Nature, which is fruitful to an excess here, be so very barren in the rest of the Planets?
said the Countess,
should produce so many different kinds. There is no need of Fancy, I reply'd,
do but trust your Eyes, and you will easily perceive how Nature diversifies in these several Worlds.
which by the way, I think, is much the better:

and at the same time makes 'em equal, by compensating for the inequality; this I confess is on the Borders of Nonsense, but a Man is ne'er the less a Philosopher for being a little obscure, if not unintelligible.
the difference too increaseth with the distance,
explanations: The translator interpolates 'Nay, to shew you that they can see as far into a Milstone as Descartes himself,' introducing a specific cultural reference (Descartes) and an English idiom not present in the original, altering the framing. Additionally, the original's concluding phrase 'qui y trouvent pour leurs mouvemens autant de liberté qu'il leur en faut' (in which they find for their movements as much freedom as they need) is omitted, removing a nuance.

The translation adds 'for Example, in Marble,' a specificity not in the original's 'des especes de pierres tres dures' (kinds of very hard stones), making the statement more concrete but less general. It also omits the vivid 'qu'ils rongeaient' (which they gnawed) and simplifies 'vuides insensibles' (imperceptible voids) to 'vacuums,' reducing original imagery and precision.

The original 'ses Habitans' (its Inhabitants) is changed to 'these invisible Mites.' More significantly, the translator interpolates the culturally specific English simile '(as if she were a green Cheese),' which is absent from the French text. This addition introduces a folksy, potentially trivializing image, altering the tone and cultural context.

The translator inserts the culturally specific English reference 'and the Stones upon Salisbury Plain are as much alive, as a Hive of Bees;' This is a significant addition, localizing the text and introducing a strong, almost mystical claim about animated stones tied to an English landmark, not present in Fontenelle's general statement.

The French clause, '& que la Nature y a si liberalement répandu les Animaux, qu'elle ne s'est pas mise en peine que l'on en vît seulement la moitié.' (and that Nature has so liberally spread Animals there, that she has not bothered that one sees only half of them), is omitted. It should appear after '...swarms with Inhabitants.' but the target text transitions directly to 'Why then should Nature...', removing a key part of Fontenelle's argument about Earth's unseen abundance.

The interlocutor's title is consistently changed from 'Marquise' (a French noble title) to 'Countess' (an English aristocratic title). This anglicization alters a factual detail and could subtly shift the perceived social setting for an English reader, domesticating the dialogue.

The Marquise's direct question 'mais comment se representer cela?' (but how to represent/imagine that?), which concludes her speech in French, is omitted. The target text moves from her prior statement '...so many different kinds.' directly to the philosopher's reply 'There is no need of Fancy...', altering the dialogic exchange and the problem addressed.

Fontenelle's statement that imagination 'n'êst pas propre à aller plus loin que les yeux' (is not suited to go further than the eyes) and his suggestion of perceiving diversity via a 'veuë universelle' (a certain universal view) is transformed. The translation offers a direct instruction, 'do but trust your Eyes,' and an assurance of easy perception, simplifying Fontenelle's epistemological point.

The philosopher's speculative understatement in French, 'ceux-là ne sont peut-être pas les plus malheureux' (those ones are perhaps not the most unhappy/unfortunate), is transformed into a direct, personal, and more strongly positive opinion in English: 'which by the way, I think, is much the better:'. This changes the philosopher's tone from cautious reflection to assertive judgment.

The translator appends an entire sentence: 'this I confess is on the Borders of Nonsense, but a Man is ne'er the less a Philosopher for being a little obscure, if not unintelligible.' This comment is not present in the original French text, which ends on a confident assertion about Nature's methods. The addition introduces self-deprecation or skepticism, altering the original's tone and the philosopher's perceived certainty.

The French 'Apparemment' (apparently, seemingly), which introduces a speculative nuance to the statement about differences increasing with distance, is omitted in the English translation. This makes the statement 'the difference too increaseth with the distance' more declarative and less hedged than in the original.

chunks.source_manual: <P053>Etes-vous contente, Madame, ajoûtay-je en quittant le ton serieux? Vous ay-je dubité assez de chimeres? Vrayment, répondit-elle, il me semble que j'ay presentement moins de peine à attraper les differences de tous ces Mondes. Mon imagination travaille sur le plan que vous mavez donné. Je me represente comme je puis des Caracteres & des Coûtumes extraordinaire pour les Habitans des Planetes, & je leur compose même des figures tout-à-fait bizarres. Je ne vous les pourrois pas décrire, mais je voy pourtant quelque chose. Pour ces figures-là, répliquay-je, je vous conseille d'en laisser le soin aux Songes que vous aurez cette nuit. Nous verrons demain s'ils vous auront bien servie, & s'ils vous auront appris comment sont faits les Habitants de quelque Planete.</P053>
chunks.target_manual: <P042>But is it not time, Madam, to be serious, how will you dispose of all these Notions? Trouble not your self, says she, Fancy is a great Traveller; I already comprehend these several Worlds, and represent to my self their different Characters and Customs; some of 'em, I assure you, are very extraordinary; I see at this moment, a thousand different Figures, tho' I cannot well describe 'em. Oh leave 'em, I reply'd, to your Dreams, they will represent 'em very faithfully.</P042>

Vous ay-je dubité assez de chimeres?

attraper les differences de tous ces Mondes. Mon imagination travaille sur le plan que vous mavez donné. Je me represente comme je puis
Je me represente comme je puis des Caracteres & des Coûtumes extraordinaire pour les Habitans des Planetes, & je leur compose même des figures tout-à-fait bizarres.
Nous verrons demain s'ils vous auront bien servie, & s'ils vous auront appris comment sont faits les Habitants de quelque Planete.
target_segments: But is it not time, Madam, to be serious,
how will you dispose of all these Notions?
Trouble not your self, says she, Fancy is a great Traveller; I already comprehend these several Worlds,
comprehend these several Worlds, and represent to my self their different Characters
and represent to my self their different Characters and Customs; some of 'em, I assure you, are very extraordinary; I see at this moment, a thousand different Figures,
they will represent 'em very faithfully.
explanations: The philosopher's question about the Marquise's contentment and his stated intention of "leaving the serious tone" are replaced. The translation has him ask if it's time "to be serious," reversing his expressed mood and omitting his solicitude, which alters his character and the dialogue's dynamic.

The original query "Have I recounted enough chimeras (fantasies)?" (assuming 'dubité' is 'débité') is transformed. The translation "how will you dispose of all these Notions?" shifts the focus from the philosopher's act of narrating imaginative "chimeres" to the Marquise's responsibility for more neutral "Notions," altering the question's core meaning and the perceived nature of the ideas.

The Marquise's modest "Truly... it seems to me I now have less difficulty in grasping..." is significantly altered. "Truly" (Vrayment) becomes "Trouble not your self"; the aphorism "Fancy is a great Traveller;" is inserted without source basis, changing her speech style; and her tentative understanding is replaced by the confident "I already comprehend." These changes collectively make the Marquise seem more assertive and less intellectually cautious.

The sentence "Mon imagination travaille sur le plan que vous mavez donné" (My imagination is working on the plan you have given me) is omitted from the translation. This removal eliminates the Marquise's explicit acknowledgement of the philosopher's guidance and her methodical approach to understanding, subtly shifting her portrayal towards one of more independent or innate comprehension.

The translation alters the Marquise's process of imagination. Her humble qualifier "comme je puis" (as best I can) is omitted. The term "extraordinaire" is amplified into an assertive interjection "some of 'em, I assure you, are very extraordinary." Crucially, her active creation "je leur compose même des figures tout-à-fait bizarres" (I even compose for them completely bizarre figures) is changed to a more passive, exaggerated vision: "I see at this moment, a thousand different Figures," transforming her from an active imaginer into a more passive, confident visionary.

The philosopher's original speculative statement about dreams ("We will see tomorrow if they (dreams) will have served you well, & if they will have taught you how the Inhabitants of some Planet are made") is replaced by the definitive assertion "they will represent 'em very faithfully." This transformation omits the forward-looking, inquisitive element about dreams as a potential source of knowledge, making the philosopher sound more dogmatic than exploratory, and the entire conditional aspect about what might be learned is lost.

chunks.source_manual: <P054>QUATRIEME SOIR. Particularités des mondes de Vénus, de Mercure, de Mars, de Jupiter & de Saturne.</P054>
chunks.target_manual: <P044>The Fourth Evening.</P044>
source_segments: QUATRIEME SOIR. Particularités des mondes de Vénus, de Mercure, de Mars, de Jupiter & de Saturne.
target_segments: The Fourth Evening.
explanations: The English translation of the chapter heading omits the descriptive subtitle 'Particularités des mondes de Vénus, de Mercure, de Mars, de Jupiter & de Saturne'. This removes specific details about the chapter's content (the particularities of various planets) that were present in the original. This omission withholds information from the reader that Fontenelle used to structure his work and guide expectations, subtly altering the way the chapter is introduced and impacting the popularizing intent of making scientific topics clearly signposted.

chunks.source_manual: <P055><SC>Les songes ne furent point heureux: ils representerent toûjours quelque chose qui ressembloit à ce que l'on voit iciy. J'eus lieu de reprocher à la <IIM>Marquise</IIM> ce que nous reprochent à la veüe de nos Tableaux, de certains Peuples qui ne font jamaïs que des peintures bizarres & grotesques. Bon, nous disent-ils, cela est tout fait comme des hommes, il n'y a pas là d'imagination. Il falut donc se resoudre à ignorer les figures des Habitans de toutes ces Planetes, & se contenter d'en deviner ce que nous pourrions, en continuant le Voyage des Mondes que nous avions commencé.</SC> Nous en êtions à Vénus. On est bien sûr, dis-je à la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que Venus tourne sur elle-même, <SC>mais on ne sait pas bien en quel temps</SC>, ny par consequent combien ses jours durent. Pour ses années elles ne sont que de huit mois, puis qu'elle tourne en ce temps-là autour du Soleil. Come elle est quarante fois plus petite que la Terre, la Terre de dedans Venus paroît une Planete quarante fois plus grande, que Venus ne nous paroît d'icy, & comme la Lune est aussi quarante fois petite que la Terre, elle paroît dedans Venus à peu prés de la même grandeur dont Venus nous paroît d'icy.</P055>
chunks.target_manual: <P045><UP>I Have been told of a Physician that makes his Patients dream as he pleases, by prescribing such a Specifick for their Supper, as works those impressions he would have on the Fancy; of what use he may be to the modern Poets, I leave to the curious; and return to the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, who either did not dream at all, or nothing to the purpose</UP>; so that continuing our Voyage to the other Worlds, we could only guess at their Inhabitants. We were come to Venus, and I told her, that Venus certainly turn'd on it self, tho' no body could tell in what time, and consequently were ignorant how long her Day lasted; but her Year was compos'd of eight Months, because 'tis in that time she turns round the Sun: And seeing Venus is forty times less than the Earth, the Earth appears (to them in Venus) to be a Planet, forty times bigger than Venus appears to us on the Earth; and as the Moon is forty times lesser than the Earth, so she seems to be just of the same magnitude, to the Inhabitants of Venus, as here Venus seems to us.</P045>

Il falut donc se resoudre à ignorer les figures des Habitans de toutes ces Planetes, & se contenter d'en deviner ce que nous pourrions, en continuant le Voyage des Mondes que nous avions commencé.

target_segments: I Have been told of a Physician that makes his Patients dream as he pleases, by prescribing such a Specifick for their Supper, as works those impressions he would have on the Fancy; of what use he may be to the modern Poets, I leave to the curious; and return to the Countess, who either did not dream at all, or nothing to the purpose; so that continuing our Voyage to the other Worlds, we could only guess at their Inhabitants.
just of the same magnitude
explanations: The translator replaces Fontenelle's opening discourse on the Marquise's uninspired dreams and the limits of human imagination (illustrated with an art analogy) with an unrelated anecdote about a physician. This substitution omits the original's philosophical depth. The description of the dreams is also altered from being unoriginal ('ils representerent toûjours quelque chose qui ressembloit à ce que l'on voit iciy') to potentially not happening or being 'nothing to the purpose.' Furthermore, Fontenelle's reasoned conclusion to 'ignorer les figures des Habitans' (ignore the physical forms of inhabitants) due to imaginative failure is omitted, weakened to merely 'we could only guess.' These combined changes significantly alter the passage's content, tone, and philosophical argument, manipulating the reader's perception of the work's intellectual engagement and the reasons for focusing on non-physical aspects of potential alien life.

The French phrase 'à peu prés de la même grandeur,' meaning 'approximately of the same size,' is translated as 'just of the same magnitude.' The word 'just' in this context implies exactness, subtly altering Fontenelle's statement from an approximation to a definitive assertion. This shift can manipulate the reader by presenting the astronomical comparison with a higher degree of precision than intended by the author in his work of scientific popularization, potentially affecting their understanding of the certainty of the scientific claims being discussed.

chunks.source_manual: <P056>Vous m'affligez, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Je voy bien que la Terre n'est pas pour Vénus l'Etoile du Berger, & la Mere des Amours, comme Vénus l'est pour la Terre; car la Terre de dedans Vénus paroît trop grande, mais la Lune qui y paroît de la même grandeur dont Vénus nous paroît d'icy, est justement taillée comme il faut pour y être Mere des Amours, & Etoile du Berger <NCE></NCE>. Ces noms ne peuvent convenir qu'à une Planete qui soit jolie, claire, brillante, & qui ait un air galant. <UP></UP> C'est asseurément une destinée agréable pour notre Lune que de presider aux Amours des Habitans de Vénus; ces Gens là doivent nien entendre la galanterie. Oh! sans doute, répondis-je, le menu Peuple de Vénus n'est composé que de Celadons & de Silvandres, & leurs Conversations le plus communes valent les plus belles de Clesie. <UP></UP> Le climat est très favorable aux Amours. Vénus est plus proche que nous du Soleil, & elle en reçoit une lumiere plus vive & plus de chaleur.</P056>
chunks.target_manual: <P046>I see then, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, that the Earth is not to Venus, what Venus is to the Earth; I mean, that the Earth is too bigg to be the Mother of Love, or the Shepherd's Star to Venus; but the Moon, which appears to Venus, of the same bigness that Venus appears to us, is assign'd to be the Mother of Love, and <NCE>Shepherds Star to Venus</NCE>; for such names are only proper for a little brisk airy Planet, bright, and shining as the Goddess her self. Oh, blessed Moon, how happy art thou, to preside over the Amours of those gallant People, where all they say, is soft and moving, <UP>and perfectly refin'd from the dross of our Wits, who are fitter for a Bear-Garden than a Circle? How gross is their Courtship? how mean their Raillery? without any distinction of time, place, or person; they make Love, (as they call it) but one way, and the form is the same, at a Farce, or Funeral. Be not so very severe, I reply'd, if some of our Beaux speak plain English, some of your Belles, like 'em ne're the worse for't: The art of Love is as much improv'd as the art of War, the Generals of this Age take a Town in two days, which in the last, held out as many years; and the Roses, Lillies, Pearls, and Rubies, (a whining Lovers train of Artillery)</UP> are grown as useless as Bows and Arrows: tho' after all, I must own they have another Standard in the Planet Venus; there <UP>Clelia</UP> and Parthenissa, is below the language of Grooms and Chamber Maids; and every Porter and Car-Man a perfect Sir Courtly; but then consider the difference of Climats; Venus is much nearer than the Earth is to the Sun, from whence she receives a more vigorous and active influence.</P046>

a little brisk airy Planet, bright, and shining as the Goddess her self.

Oh, blessed Moon, how happy art thou, to preside over the Amours of those gallant People, where all they say, is soft and moving, and perfectly refin'd from the dross of our Wits, who are fitter for a Bear-Garden than a Circle? How gross is their Courtship? how mean their Raillery? without any distinction of time, place, or person; they make Love, (as they call it) but one way, and the form is the same, at a Farce, or Funeral.

Be not so very severe, I reply'd, if some of our Beaux speak plain English, some of your Belles, like 'em ne're the worse for't: The art of Love is as much improv'd as the art of War, the Generals of this Age take a Town in two days, which in the last, held out as many years; and the Roses, Lillies, Pearls, and Rubies, (a whining Lovers train of Artillery) are grown as useless as Bows and Arrows: tho' after all, I must own they have another Standard in the Planet Venus; there Clelia and Parthenissa, is below the language of Grooms and Chamber Maids; and every Porter and Car-Man a perfect Sir Courtly;
but then consider the difference of Climats; Venus is much nearer than the Earth is to the Sun, from whence she receives a more vigorous and active influence.
explanations: The Marquise's expression of distress ('Vous m'affligez' - You afflict/distress me) is replaced with a neutral observation ('I see then'). This changes the emotional tone of her opening remark, making her sound less perturbed. Additionally, 'Marquise' is translated as 'Countess', altering her social standing.

The original French description of the planet as 'jolie, claire, brillante, & qui ait un air galant' (pretty, clear/light, brilliant, & which has a gallant air) is altered. 'Jolie' (pretty) becomes 'little,' 'claire' (clear/light) becomes 'airy,' and 'qui ait un air galant' (which has a gallant air) is replaced with the specific mythological comparison 'as the Goddess her self.' These changes shift the planet's perceived characteristics and introduce a divine personification not explicitly in Fontenelle's phrase.

The original concise statement about the Moon's pleasant destiny and the Venusians' understanding of gallantry is vastly expanded. The translation changes the tone to an apostrophe ('Oh, blessed Moon'), adds 'blessed', and then inserts a lengthy, entirely new passage. This addition critiques contemporary English social manners and wit (e.g., 'dross of our Wits', 'Bear-Garden'), introducing a satirical commentary absent from Fontenelle's text and thus manipulating the reader's perception of the dialogue's original content and focus.

The philosopher's original agreement and literary allusions ('Celadons', 'Silvandres', 'Clesie') are entirely replaced by a new discourse. The translation introduces a defense of contemporary English courtship ('Beaux speak plain English'), uses English-specific cultural references ('Parthenissa', 'Sir Courtly'), and employs metaphors (love as war) not found in the source. This extensive addition shifts the conversation to a commentary on the translator's societal context, manipulating the reader's understanding of the philosopher's character and the original discussion.

The direct statement 'Le climat est très favorable aux Amours' (The climate is very favorable to Loves) is omitted from the beginning of the corresponding discussion in the translation. Furthermore, 'une lumiere plus vive & plus de chaleur' (a more vivid light and more heat) is translated as 'a more vigorous and active influence.' This alteration changes concrete sensory details into a more abstract concept of 'influence,' and the omission removes the explicit link Fontenelle makes between the Venusian climate and love, subtly shifting the rationale provided.

chunks.source_manual: <P057>Je vois presentement, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, comment sont faits les Habitans de Vénus. Ils ressemblent aux Mores Grenadins; un petit Peuple noir, brûlé du Soleil, plein d'esprit & de feu, toûjours amoureux, faisant des Vers, aimant la Musique, inventant tous les jours des Fêtes, des Danses, & des Tournois. Permettez-moy de vous dire, Madame, répliquai-je, que vous ne connaissez guère bien les Habitans de Vénus. Nos Mores Grenadins n'auroient été auprés d'eux que des Lappons & des Groënlandois pour la froideur & pour la stupidité.</P057>
chunks.target_manual: <P047>I find, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, it is easie enough to guess at the Inhabitants of Venus; they resemble what I have read of the Moors of Granada, who were a little black People, scorch'd with the Sun, witty, full of Fire, very Amorous, much inclin'd to Musick and Poetry, and ever inventing Masques and Turnaments in honour of their Mistresses. Pardon me, Madam, said I, you are little acquainted with the Planet; Granada in all its Glory, was a perfect Greenland to it; and your gallant Moors, in comparison with that People, were as stupid as so many Laplanders.</P047>

Ils ressemblent aux Mores Grenadins;
inventant tous les jours des Fêtes, des Danses, & des Tournois.
que vous ne connaissez guère bien les Habitans de Vénus.
Nos Mores Grenadins n'auroient été auprés d'eux que des Lappons & des Groënlandois pour la froideur & pour la stupidité.
target_segments: it is easie enough to guess at the Inhabitants of Venus;
they resemble what I have read of the Moors of Granada,
ever inventing Masques and Turnaments in honour of their Mistresses.
you are little acquainted with the Planet;
Granada in all its Glory, was a perfect Greenland to it; and your gallant Moors, in comparison with that People, were as stupid as so many Laplanders.
explanations: The original French "comment sont faits" suggests a direct understanding or visualization by the Marquise ('how they are made' or 'what they are like'). The translation "it is easie enough to guess at" diminishes her insight, reframing her statement as mere conjecture rather than a moment of realization. This subtly alters the reader's perception of the Marquise's intellectual engagement and confidence, potentially undermining Fontenelle's aim to portray women as capable scientific interlocutors.

The translator's addition of "what I have read of" is not present in the original text. This changes the Marquise's statement from a direct imaginative comparison to one explicitly based on textual knowledge. This subtly manipulates the reader's perception of her character, making her appear more reliant on received information and less on her own imaginative or deductive reasoning, which could subtly diminish the portrayal of an intellectually curious woman engaging with new scientific ideas.

The translation omits "Fêtes" (Festivals) and "Danses" (Dances), and introduces "Masques" (a culturally specific English form of entertainment). More significantly, it adds the clause "in honour of their Mistresses." This addition, absent in the original, imposes a specific courtly love motivation onto the Venusians' activities, narrowing the scope of their cultural expressions and subtly manipulating the reader's understanding of their society by framing it through a conventional romantic and potentially patriarchal lens.

The original text has the philosopher state that the Marquise "hardly know[s] the Habitans de Vénus (Inhabitants of Venus) well." The translation changes the object of her (mis)understanding from "the Inhabitants of Venus" to "the Planet." This shift in focus subtly alters the nature of the philosopher's correction, diverting it from a discussion about the nature of extraterrestrial beings to a more general knowledge of the celestial body, thereby manipulating the thematic emphasis of the dialogue from speculative biology/sociology towards astronomy.

The translation significantly restructures and alters the philosopher's comparison. It introduces the embellished phrase "Granada in all its Glory" and compares this *place* to "Greenland" (implying coldness), whereas the original directly compares the "Mores Grenadins" (people) to "Lappons & Groënlandois" (people) for both "froideur & stupidité" (coldness and stupidity). The addition of "gallant" before "Moors" is also an insertion not present in the original. By separating the qualities of coldness and stupidity and applying them to different parts of a re-engineered analogy, and by adding embellishments, the translation manipulates the original's more direct and unified comparison, altering its rhetorical structure and potentially the reader's interpretation of the analogy.

chunks.source_manual: <P058>Mais que sera-ce des Habitants de Mercure? Ils sont encore plus proches du Soleil; il faut qu'ils soient fous à force de vivacité. <UP></UP> Je croy qu'ils n'ont point de mémoire, non plus que la plupart des Négres; qu'ils ne font jamais de reflexion sur rien, qu'ils n'agissent qu'à l'aventure, & par des mouvements subits, & <IIM>qu'enfin c'est dans Mercure que sont les Petites Maisons de l'Univers.</IIM> <NCE></NCE> Ils voyent le Soleil beaucoup plus grand que nous ne le voyons, parce qu'ils en sont beaucoup plus proches. Il leur envoie une lumière si forte, que s'ils étoient icy, ils ne prendroient nos plus beaux jours que pour de très <IIM>foibles</IIM> Crepuscules, & peut-être n'y pourroient-ils pas distinguer les objets, & la chaleur à laquelle ils sont accoûtumez est si excessive, que celle qu'il fait icy au fond de l'Afrique, suffiroit pour les glacier. Leur année n'est que de trois mois. La durée de leur jour ne nous est point encore connuë, parce que Mercure est si petit & si proche du Soleil, dans les rayons duquel il est presque toûjours perdu, qu'il échappe à toute l'adresse des Astronomes, & qu'on n'a pû encore avoir assez de prise sur lui, pour observer le mouvement qu'il doit avoir sur son centre; mais sa petitesse fait croire qu'il acheve ce tour en peu de temps; que par consequent le jour de Mercure est fort court, & que les Habitans voyent le Soleil comme un <RW>grand poële ardent</RW>, peu éloigné de leurs tête, & qui va d'une rapidité profigeuse. Cela en est mieux pour eux, car apparemment ils soûpirent après la nuit. Ils sont éclairez pendant ce temps-là de Vénus,& de la Terre, qui leur doivent paroître assez grandes. Pour les autres Planètes, comme elles sont au-delà de la <IIM>Terre vers le Firmament</IIM>, ils les voyent plus petites que nous ne les voyons, & n'en reçoivent que bien peu de lumière, peut-être n'en reçoivent-ils point du tout. Les Etoles Fixes sont aussi plus petites pour eux, & même il doit y en avoir beaucoup qui disparoissent entierement; c'est, selon moy, une perte. Je suis bien faché de voir cette <RW>grande voûte ornée de mois d'Etoiles, & de ne voir celles qui me resteroient</RW>, que plus petites, & d'une couleur plus effacée. <SC>—</SC>.</P058>
chunks.target_manual: <P048>But what do you think then of the Inhabitants of Mercury? They are yet nearer to the Sun, and are so full of Fire, <UP>that they are absolutely mad; I fancy, they have no memory at all, like most of the Negroes, that they make no reflections, and what they do is by sudden starts, and perfect hap-hazard; <NCE>in short, Mercury is the Bedlam of the Universe</NCE>; the Sun appears to them much greater than it does to us, because they are much nearer to it than we; it sends them so vast and strong a light, that the most glorious day here, would be no more with them than a declining Page 97 twilight: I know not if they can distinguish Objects, but the heat to which they are accustom'd, is so excessive, that they would be starved with cold in the Torrid Zone; their year is but three Months, but we know not the exact length of their Day, because Mercury is so little, and so near the Sun; it is, (as it were) lost in his Rays, and is very hardly discover'd by the Astronomers; so that they cannot observe how it moves on its Centre, but because it is so little, fancy it compleats its motion in a little time; so that by consequence, the day there is very short, and the Sun appears to them like <RW>a vast fiery Furnace at a little distance</RW>, whose motion is prodigiously swift and rapid; and during their Night, Venus and the Earth (which must appear considerably big) give light to them; as for the other Planets which are beyond the Earth, <RW>towards the Firmament</RW>, they appear less to them in Mercury, than they do to us here, and they receive but little light from them, perhaps none at all; the fix'd Stars likewise seem less to them, and some of 'em totally disappear, which were I there, I should esteem a very great</UP> loss. <SC>—</SC></P048>

explanations: The French 'Petites Maisons,' a general euphemism for insane asylums, is translated to 'Bedlam,' the name of a specific and notorious London asylum. This substitution localizes the reference, changing the universal tone of the original by anchoring it to a specific, charged English cultural context, thus manipulating the reader's perception.

The phrase 'au fond de l'Afrique' (deep in Africa/in the heart of Africa), an evocative geographical and cultural reference for extreme heat to a 17th-century European audience, is replaced by the more scientific and general term 'in the Torrid Zone.' This shift lessens the vivid imagery of the original and substitutes it with a more clinical, geographical descriptor, subtly altering the literary tone and the reader's imaginative engagement.

The original 'un grand poële ardent' (a large burning stove/pan) is translated as 'a vast fiery Furnace.' This intensifies the imagery significantly, as 'furnace' evokes a much larger and more intense heat source than 'poële.' This alteration changes the connotation, making the sun's appearance more dramatic and potentially more overwhelmingly intense than Fontenelle's original metaphor.

The clause 'Cela en est mieux pour eux,' (That is better for them,), which presents a mitigating aspect of the harsh conditions on Mercury (that the short, fast day is an advantage), is omitted from the translation. This omission removes the philosopher's nuanced observation, focusing the reader's perception solely on the negative aspects of Mercury's climate and altering the balance of the original statement.

The philosopher's straightforward statement of opinion, 'c'est, selon moy, une perte' (it is, in my opinion, a loss), is transformed into the more elaborate, conditional, and intensified phrase 'which were I there, I should esteem a very great loss.' This alteration changes the tone from direct reflection to a more dramatic, personal hypothetical, subtly shifting the character's mode of expression and the impact of the statement.

The entire concluding sentence of the philosopher's reflection on Mercury's sky, 'Je suis bien faché de voir cette grande voûte ornée de mois d'Etoiles, & de ne voir celles qui me resteroient, que plus petites, & d'une couleur plus effacée. —.' (I am very sorry to see this great vault adorned with fewer Stars, & to see those that would remain to me, only smaller, & of a more faded color.), is omitted from the translation. This omission removes a significant expression of the philosopher's personal sensibility and his regret, thereby altering the reader's perception of his character and the reflective mood of the passage.

chunks.source_manual: <P059>Je ne suis pas si touchée, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, de cette perte-là que sont les <IIM>Habitans de Mercure</IIM>, que de l'incommodité qu'ils reçoivent de l'excés de chaleur. Je voudrois bien que nous les soulageassions un peu. Donnons à Mercure de longues & d'abondantes pluyes qui le rafraîchissent, comme on dit qu'il en tombe icy dans les Pays chauds pendant des quatre mois entiers, justement dans les saisons les plus chaudes.</P059> <P060>Cela se peut, repris-je, & même nous pouvons rafraîchir encore Mercure d'une autre façon. Il y a des Pays dans la Chine qui doivent être très chauds par leur situation, & où il fait pourtant de grands froids pendant les mois de Juillet & d'Août, jusque-là que les Rivieres se gelent. C'est que ces contrées là ont beaucoup de Salpêtre; les exhalaisons en sont fort froides, & la force de la chaleur les fait sortir de la Terre en grande abondance. Mercure sera, si vous voulez, une petite Planete toute de <IIM>Salpêtre</IIM>, & le Soleil tirera d'elle-même le remede au mal qu'il luy pourroit faire. Ce qu'il y a de sûr, c'est que la Nature ne sauroit faire vivre les Gens qu'où ils peuvent vivre, & que l'habitude jointe à l'ignorance de quelque chose de meilleur, survient, & les y fait vivre agréablement. Ainsi on pourrait même se passer dans Mercure du <IIM>Salpêtre</IIM> & des pluies.</P060>
chunks.target_manual: <P049>What signifies the loss of a few fix'd Stars, says the <IIM>Countess?</IIM> I pity 'em for the excessive heat <SC>they </SC> endure; let us give 'em some relief, and send Mercury a few of the refreshing Showers they have sometimes four Months together in the hottest Countries during their greatest extremity. Your Fancy is good, Madam, I reply'd, but we will relieve 'em another way; In China there are Countries which are extreamly hot by their Situation: yet in July and August are so cold, that the Rivers are Frozen; the reason is, they are full of Salt-Petre, which being exhal'd in great abundance by the excessive heat of the Sun, makes a perfect Winter at Midsummer. We will fill the little Planet with Salt-petre, and let the Sun shine as hot as he pleases. And yet after all, who knows but the Inhabitants of Mercury may have no occasion either for Rain, or Salt- Petre. If it is a certain truth, that Nature never gives life to any Creature, but where that Creature may live; then thro' Custom, and ignorance of a better Life, those People may live happily.</P049>

explanations: The original French expresses the Marquise's nuanced concern, stating she is less affected by the loss of stars than by the heat, implying both are concerns but one is greater. The translation changes this to a dismissive rhetorical question, "What signifies the loss of a few fix'd Stars?", which significantly alters the Marquise's tone to be more abrupt and less considerate of the first problem. Additionally, changing the character's title from "la Marquise" (a specific French noble title) in "dit la Marquise" to "the Countess" (an English equivalent) in "says the Countess" alters her established identity from the original work and subtly anglicizes the character.

The translation diminishes the scale of the proposed relief by changing "longues & d'abondantes pluyes" (long and abundant rains) to "a few of the refreshing Showers." This subtly alters the reader's perception of the Marquise's proposed solution, making it seem less significant or grand than in the original, and consequently, potentially understating the extremity of Mercury's heat as envisioned by Fontenelle's character.

The original "comme on dit" (as they say/it is said) indicates the information about rains is common knowledge or hearsay, a nuance lost in the translation's more direct "they have". The addition of "sometimes" in the translation also reduces the definitiveness of the statement. Furthermore, "justement dans les saisons les plus chaudes" (precisely in the hottest seasons) is a specific temporal marker, whereas "during their greatest extremity" is more vague and melodramatic, subtly shifting the register and precision of the description.

The French "Cela se peut" (That is possible/That can be done) is a neutral affirmation by the philosopher. The translation "Your Fancy is good, Madam" introduces an evaluative and somewhat patronizing tone ("Your Fancy is good") which is absent in the original. This subtly shifts the perceived dynamic between the philosopher and the Marquise, making the philosopher seem more condescending and the Marquise's contribution more like a flight of "fancy" rather than a serious suggestion.

The original phrase "Mercure sera, si vous voulez, une petite Planete toute de Salpêtre" contains "si vous voulez" (if you wish/if you like), which includes the Marquise in the speculative creation and maintains a polite, collaborative tone. The translation "We will fill the little Planet with Salt-petre" omits this inclusive phrase and uses a more assertive construction ("We will fill..."), making the philosopher's statement more directive and unilateral. This change subtly alters the philosopher's conversational style by removing a nuance of his respectful engagement with the Marquise.

The French "Ce qu'il y a de sûr, c'est que..." (What is certain is that...) presents a firm assertion of fact. The translation "If it is a certain truth, that..." transforms this assertion into a conditional or hypothetical statement by introducing "If" and "then". This significantly weakens the philosopher's epistemological stance, changing a definitive pronouncement about nature and adaptation into a more speculative one. Furthermore, the original's "les y fait vivre agréablement" (makes them live there pleasantly) is more deterministic than the translation's "those People may live happily," which adds a layer of possibility ("may") not as strongly implied in the original.

chunks.source_manual: <P061>Aprés Mercure vous savez qu'on trouve le Soleil. Il n'y a pas moyen d'y mettre d'Habitans. Le Pourquoy non nous manque là. Nous jugeons, par la Terre qui est habitée, que les autres Corps de la même espece qu'elle, doivent l'être aussi; mais le Soleil n'est point un Corps de la même espèce que la Terre, ny que les autres Planètes. Il est la source de toute cette lumiere que les Planetes ne font que se renvoyer les unes aux autres, aprés l'avoir reçeüe de luy. Elles ne peuvent faire, pour ainsi dire, des échanges entre elles, mais elles ne la peuvent produire. Luy seul tire de soy-même cette precieuse substance; il la pousse avec force de tous côtez; de là elle revient à la rencontre de tout ce qui est solide, & d'une Planete à l'autre il s'épand de longues & vastes traînées de lumieres qui se croisent & se traversent, & s'entrelassent en mille façons differentes, & forment d'admirables tissus de la plus riche matiere qui soit au monde. Aussi le Soleil est- il placé dans le centre, qui est le lieu le plus commode d'où il puisse la distribuer également, & animer tout par sa chaleur <NCP></NCP>. Le Soleil est donc un Corps <UP>particulier</UP>, mais quelle sorte de Corps? On est bien embarrassé à le dire. On avoit toûjours crû que c'étoit un feu tres-pur, mais on s'en desabusa au commencement de ce <IIM>Siecle</IIM>, qu'on aperceut des taches sur sa surface. Comme on avoit découvert peu de temps auparavant de nouvelles Planetes dont je vous parleray; que tout le <IIM>Monde Philosophe</IIM> n'avoit l'esprit remply d'autre chose, & qu'enfin les nouvelles Planetes s'étoient mises à la mode, on jugea aussi-tôt que ces taches en êtoient; <UP>qu'elles avoient un mouvement autour du Soleil</UP>, & qu'elles nous en cachoient necessaairement quelque partie, en tournant leur moitié obscure vers nous. Déja les Savans faisoient leur Cour de ces pretendües Planetes à tous les Princes de l'Europe. Les uns leur donnoient le nom d'un Prince, les autres d'un autre, & peut-être il y auroit eu querelle entre-eux à qui seroit demeuré le maître des taches pour les nommer comme il eût voulu...</P061>
chunks.target_manual: <P050>After Mercury comes the Sun, but there is no possibility of peopling it, nor no room left for a wherefore. By the Earth which is inhabited, we judge that other Bodies of the same Nature may be likewise inhabited; but the Sun is a Body not like the Earth or any of the Planets, the Sun is the source or Fountain of Light, which tho' it is sent from one Planet to another, and receives several alterations by the way, yet all originally proceeds from the Sun, he draws from himself that precious substance which he emits from all sides, and which reflects when it meets with a solid Body, and spreads from one Planet to another those long and vast trains of Light which cross, strike thro', and intermingle in a thousand different fashions, and make <NCP>(if I may so say,)</NCP> the Richest Tissu's in the World. The Sun likewise is placed in the Centre, from whence with most convenience, he may equally distribute and animate by his heat; it is then a particular Body, <UP>but what sort of Body has often puzled better heads than mine</UP>. It was thought formerly a Body of pure Fire, and that Opinion passed currant till the beginning of this Age; when they perceived several spots on its surface. A little after they had discover'd new Planets, (of which, hereafter) which some said were those Spots; for those Planets moving round the Sun, when they turned their dark half to us, must necessarily hide part of it; and had not the Learned with these pretended Planets made their Court before to most of the Princes in Europe, giving the name of this Prince to one, and of that Prince to another Planet; I believe they would have quarrel'd who should be Master of these spots, that they might have nam'd them as they pleas'd.</P050>

explanations: The original French 'Le Pourquoy non nous manque là' (literally 'The why not is missing for us there,' or 'We lack the reason why not') suggests an absence of a counter-argument. The translation 'nor no room left for a wherefore' is more emphatic and conclusive, implying an exhaustion of possibilities or a stronger dismissal of objections, subtly intensifying the narrator's expressed certainty.

The translation adds the phrase 'and receives several alterations by the way,' which introduces information not present in the original French. Additionally, it largely omits the nuance of 'Elles ne peuvent faire, pour ainsi dire, des échanges entre elles' (They cannot, so to speak, make exchanges among themselves), which characterized the planets' passive role and inability to actively trade light. This combination subtly alters the scientific explanation of how light interacts with planets.

The original French 'revient à la rencontre' (literally 'returns to the encounter of' or 'comes to meet') is more evocative and general. The translation 'reflects' imposes a specific scientific interpretation (reflection). While plausible, this narrows the original's broader, more imagistic language, which Fontenelle often used for popularization, subtly shifting the tone from accessible explanation to a more direct scientific statement.

The parenthetical phrase '(if I may so say,)' is an interpolation by the translator. Fontenelle's original text does not contain an equivalent expression of rhetorical modesty or hesitation at this specific point in the sentence. The translator's addition inserts their own voice, subtly altering the authorial tone.

The original French 'On est bien embarrassé à le dire' (One is very puzzled/It is very perplexing to say) expresses a general state of difficulty or uncertainty impersonally. The translation 'has often puzled better heads than mine' personalizes this into a self-deprecating remark apparently from the narrator (or the translator), adding a subjective layer of humility and changing the impersonal, objective tone of the original.

The English translation omits the significant French clause 'que tout le Monde Philosophe n'avoit l'esprit remply d'autre chose, & qu'enfin les nouvelles Planetes s'étoient mises à la mode,' (that the whole philosophical world had its mind filled with nothing else, and that finally the new planets had come into fashion). This clause, which precedes 'on jugea aussi-tôt...', provides crucial context about the intellectual climate. Its omission removes Fontenelle's social commentary on the trendiness of scientific discoveries, thereby altering the reader's understanding of the reasons behind the subsequent judgment about sunspots.

The French 'on jugea aussi-tôt' (one judged immediately / it was immediately judged) implies a general and swift conclusion, likely referring to the 'Monde Philosophe' mentioned in the omitted preceding clause. The translation 'which some said' lessens the impact of this judgment, suggesting the idea was held by a more limited group or was less definitive, thus subtly altering the perception of how this early hypothesis about sunspots was initially received.

Fontenelle's original 'peut-être' (perhaps) expresses a possibility or speculation about a quarrel. The translation 'I believe they would have quarrel'd' changes this into a statement of personal conviction or judgment attributed to the narrator/translator. This shift alters the authorial stance from detached, witty hypothesizing to asserting a personal belief, thereby manipulating the tone of the narration.

chunks.source_manual: <P062>Je ne trouve point cela bon, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Vous me disiez l'autre jour qu'on avoit donné aux differentes parties de la Lune des noms de Savants & d'Astronomes, & j'en êtois fort contente. Puis que les Princes prennent pour eux la Terre, il est juste que les Savants se reservent le Ciel, & y dominent, mais ils n'en devroient point permettre l'entrée à d'autres. Souffrez, répondis-je, <UP></UP> qu'ils puissent, du moins en cas de besoin, engager aux Princes quelque Astre, ou quelque partie de la Lune. Quant aux taches du Soleil, ils n'en purent faire aucun usage. Il se trouva que ce n'êtoient point des Planètes, mais des nuages, des fumées, des écumes qui s'élèvent sur le Soleil. Elles sont tantôt en grande quantité, tantôt en petit nombre; tantôt elles disparoissent toutes, quelque fois elles se mettent plusieurs ensemble, quelquefois elles se séparent, quelquefois elles sont plus claires, quelquefois plus noires. Il y a des temps où l'on en voit beaucoup, il y en a d'autres, & même assez longs, où il n'en paroît aucune. Il semble que le Soleil soit une matiere liquide, quelques-uns disent de l'Or fondu, qui boüillonne incessamment <NCP></NCP>, & produit des impuretez, qui par la force de son mouvement sont rejettées sur sa surface. Elles s'y consument, & puis il s'en produit d'autres. Imaginez-vous quels Corps étrangers ce sont là. Il y en a tel qui est peut-être aussi grand que la Terre. Jugez par là quelle est la quantité de cet Or fondu, ou l'étenduë de cette grande Mer de lumiere & de feu qu'on appelle le Soleil. D'autres disent que le Soleil paroît avec des Lunettes tout plein de Montagnes qui vomissent des flâmes, & que c'est comme un million de Monts Etna mis ensemble, mais on dit aussi que ces Montagnes sont une pure vision, causée par quelque chose qui arrive dans les Lunettes. Aquoy se fiera-t-on, s'il faut se défier des Lunettes même, ausquelles nous devons la connoissance de tant de nouveaux objects. Enfin, quoi que ce puisse être que le Soleil, il ne paroît nullement propre à être habité. C'est pourtant dommage, l'habitation seroit belle. On seroit au centre de tout, on verroit toutes les Planetes tourner regulierement autour de soy, au lieu que nous voyons dans leur cours une infinité de bizarreries, qui n'y paroissent que parce que nous ne sommes pas en le lieu propre pour en bien juger, c'est à dire, au centre de leur mouvement. Cela n'est-il pas pitoyable? Il n'y a qu'un lieu dans le Monde, d'où l'étude des Astres puisse être extremément facile, & justement dans ce lieu-là, il n'y a personne. Vous n'y songez pas, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Qui seroit dans le Soleil, verroit rien, ny Planetes, ny Etoiles Fixes. Le Soleil n'efface-t-il pas tout? Ce seroient ses Habitans qui seroient bien fondez à se croire seuls dans toute la Nature.</P062>
chunks.target_manual: <P051>'Twas but t'other day, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, you were describing the Moon, and call'd several places by the names of the most famous Astronomers. I was pleased with the fancy; for since the Princes have seiz'd on the Earth; 'tis fit the Philosophers should reserve the Heavens for themselves without any Competitors. Oh! trouble not your self, said I, <UP>the Philosophers make the best advantage of their Territories; and if they part with the least Star, 'tis on very good terms; let me tell you, an Acre of Land in England, is worth ten thousand in the Moon, but the spots on the Sun are fallen to nothing; the actions of Pensilvania are not half so low</UP>, 'tis now discover'd that they are not Planets, but Clouds, Steams, or Dross, which rise upon the Sun, sometimes in great quantity, sometimes in less; sometimes they are dark, sometimes clear, sometimes they continue a great while, and sometimes they disappear as long. It seems the Sun is a Liquid Matter, some think of melted Gold, which boils over <NCP>(as it were)</NCP> continually, and by the force of its motion casts the Scum or dross on its surface, where it is consumed, and others arise. Imagine then what strange Bodies these are, when some of 'em are as big as the Earth; What a vast quantity must there be of this melted Gold, and what must be the extent of this great Sea of Light and Fire which they call the Sun? Others say, the Sun appears through their Tellescopes, full of Mountains which vomit Fire continually, and are joyn'd together like millions of Etna's. Yet there are those who say these burning Mountains are pure Vision, caus'd by a fault in the Spectacles; but what shall we trust, if we must distrust our Tellescopes to which we owe the knowledge of so many new Objects? But let the Sun be what it will, it cannot be at all proper for habitation; and what pity 'tis not, for how pleasant would it be? You might then be at the Centre of the Universe, where you would see all the Planets turn regularly about you; but now we know nothing but extravagant Page 103 fancies, because we do not stand in the proper place; there is but one place in the World where the study or knowledge of the Stars is easily obtain'd, and what pity 'tis there is no body there. You forget your self sure, says she, were you in the Sun you would see nothing, neither Planets nor fix'd Stars, doth not the Sun efface all? so that could there be any Inhabitants there, they might justly think themselves the only people in Nature.</P051>

explanations: The Marquise's initial critical remark, "Je ne trouve point cela bon," (I don't find that good/I don't approve of that) which introduces her speech in the original French, is entirely omitted in the English translation. This omission softens her initial tone, removing her immediate expression of disapproval and subtly altering the perception of her character's assertiveness in the dialogue.

The original French suggests philosophers might pledge celestial bodies to Princes out of necessity ("en cas de besoin"). The translation alters this to portray philosophers as shrewdly managing their "Territories" and profiting from such transactions ("make the best advantage", "on very good terms"). This changes the original's implication of potential reluctance or need to one of astute, opportunistic dealing, shifting the tone of the philosopher's remark.

The translator inserts a lengthy, culturally specific analogy that has no direct counterpart in the original French statement about the uselessness of sunspots ("ils n'en purent faire aucun usage."). This inserted analogy compares celestial matters to contemporary English land values and Pennsylvanian colonial stocks ("actions of Pensilvania"). This significant addition re-contextualizes the discussion within late 17th-century English economic concerns, thereby manipulating the reader's perception by adding a localized layer of meaning and commentary not present in Fontenelle's original text.

The French "bizarreries" refers to the apparent complexities or irregularities (like retrograde motion) in planetary courses when viewed from Earth, which are due to the observer's perspective. Translating this as "extravagant Page 103 fancies" changes the meaning from actual, though perspectivally deceptive, astronomical observations to wild imaginings or delusions. This significantly misrepresents Fontenelle's scientific point about the nature of observation and the importance of perspective in understanding celestial mechanics.

chunks.source_manual: <P063>J'avoüe que je m'étois trompé, répondis-je, je ne songeois qu'à la situation où est le Soleil,& non à l'effet de sa lumiere; mais vous qui me redressez si à propos, vous voulez bien que je vous dise que vous vous êtes trompée aussi; les Habitans du Soleil ne le verroient seulement pas. Ou ils ne pourroient soûtenir la force de sa lumiere, ou ils ne la pourroient recevoir, faute d'en être à quelque distance, & tout bien considéré, le Soleil ne seroit qu'un séjour d'Aveugles. Encore un coup, il n'est pas fait pour être habité; mais voulez-vous que nous poursuivions notre Voyage des Mondes? Nous sommes arrivéz au centre qui est toûjours le lieu le plus bas dans tout ce qui est rond, il faudroit presentement retourner sur nos pas, & remonter. Nous retrouverons Mercure, Vénus, la Terre, la Lune, toutes Planetes que nous avons visitées. Ensuite c'est Mars qui se presente. Mars n'a rien de curieux que je sache, ses jours ne sont pas d'une heure entiere plus longs que les nôtres; ses années valent deux de nos années. Il est cinq fois plus petit que la Terre, il voit le Soleil un peu moins grand & moins vif que nous ne le voyons; enfin Mars ne vaut pas trop la peine qu'on s'y arrête. Mais la jolie chose que Jupiter avec ses quatre Lunes ou <RW>Satellites</RW>! Ce sont quatre petites Planetes qui tournent autour de luy, comme notre Lune tourne autour de nous. Mais, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, pourquoy y a-t-il des Planetes qui tournent autour d'autres Planetes qui ne valent pas mieux qu'elles? Serieusement il me paroîtroit plus regulier & plus uniforme que toutes les Planetes, grandes & petites, n'eussent que le même mouvement autour du Soleil!</P063>
chunks.target_manual: <P052>I own said I, my mistake; I was thinking of the Situation of the Sun, and not of the effect of its Light: I thank you for your correction, but must take the boldness to tell you, that you are in an errour, as well as my self; for were there Inhabitants in the Sun, they would not see at all, either they could not bear the strength of its light, or for want of a due distance, they could not receive it; so that things well consider'd, all the People there must be stark blind, which is another reason why the Sun cannot be inhabited; but let us pursue our Voyage. We are now arriv'd at the Centre, which is always the bottom, or lowest place of what is round; if we go on, we must ascend; we shall find Mercury, Venus, the Earth, the Moon, all the Planets we have already visited; the next is Mars: Mars hath nothing curious that I know of, his Day is not quite an hour longer than ours, but his Year is twice as much as our Year; he is a little less than the Earth; and the Sun seems not altogether so large and so bright to him, as it appears to us? but let us leave Mars, he is not worth our stay: But what a pretty thing is Jupiter, with his four Moons, <UP>or Yeomen of the Guard</UP>; they are four little Planets that turn round him, as our Moon turns round us. But why, says she, interrupting me, must there be Planets to turn round other Planets, that are no better than themselves? I should think it would be more regular and uniform, that all the Planets, little and great, without any distinction, should have one and the same motion round the Sun.</P052>

target_segments: he is a little less than the Earth;
and the Sun seems not altogether so large and so bright to him, as it appears to us?

explanations: The French text provides a specific quantitative comparison, 'cinq fois plus petit' (five times smaller). The English translation changes this to the vague qualitative phrase 'a little less than the Earth'. This omits the specific numerical information, reducing the precision of the scientific description and thus subtly altering the reader's perception of the actual size difference being communicated by Fontenelle.

The original French text makes a declarative statement about Mars's view of the Sun. The English translation adds a question mark at the end of the corresponding clause, transforming an assertion into a statement of lesser certainty or a question. This change in punctuation subtly alters the tone, diminishing the authoritativeness of the scientific information being popularized.

The French text uses 'Satellites', a neutral and scientific term that Fontenelle was helping to popularize. The English translation replaces/augments this with 'Yeomen of the Guard', a term referring to bodyguards of the British monarch. This addition introduces a culturally specific English monarchical and hierarchical connotation that is absent in the original, domesticating the text and shifting the reader's perception by framing a scientific concept within a contemporary British socio-political image.

chunks.source_manual: <P064>Ah! Madame, répliquai-je, Si vous saviez ce que c'est que les <RW><NCP>Tourbillons</NCP></RW> de Descartes, ces Tourbillons dont le nom est si terrible, & l'idée si agreable, vous ne parleriez pas comme vous faites. La tête me dût-elle tourner, dit elle en riant, il est beau de savoir ce que c'est que les Tourbillons. Achevez de me rendre folle, je ne me ménage plus, je ne connois plus de retenuë sur la Philosophie; laissons parler le monde, & donnons-nous aux Tourbillons. Je ne vous connaissois pas de pareils emportements, répris-je; c'est dommage qu'ils n'ayent que les Tourbillons pour objet. Ce qu'on appelle un Tourbillon, c'est un amas de matiere dont les parties sont détachées les unes des autres, & se meuvent toutes en un même sens; permis à elles d'avoir pendant ce temps-là quelques petites mouvements particuliers, pourveu qu'elles suivent toûjours le mouvement general. Ainsi un Tourbillon de vent <UP></UP>, c'est une infinité de petites parties d'air, qui tournent en rond toutes ensemble, & enveloppent ce qu'elles rencontrent. Vous savez que les Planetes sont portées dans la matiere celeste, qui est d'une subtilité, & d'une agitation prodigieuse. Tout ce grand amas de matiere celeste, qui est depuis le Soleil <UP></UP>jusqu'aux Etoiles fixes, tourne en rond, & emportant avec soy les Planetes <UP></UP>, les fait tourner toutes en un même sens autour du Soleil, qui occupe le centre; mais en des temps plus ou moins longs, selon qu'elles en sont plus ou moins éloignées. Il n'y a pas jusqu'au Soleil qui ne tourne; mais il ne tourne que sur luy-même, parce qu'il est justement au milieu de toute cette <IIM>matiere celeste</IIM>; & vous remarquerez en passant, que quand la Terre seroit dans la place où il est, elle ne pourroit encore faire moins que de tourner sur elle- même.</P064> <P065>Voilà quel est le grand Tourbillon dont le Soleil est comme le Maître; mais en même temps les Planetes se composent de petits Tourbillons particuliers à l'imitation de celuy du Soleil. Chacune d'elles en tournant autour du Soleil, ne laisse pas de tourner autour d'elle-même, & fait tourner aussi autour d'elle en même sens une certaine quantité de cette matière céleste, qui est toûjours prête à suivre tous les mouvements qu'on luy veut donner, s'ils ne la détournent pas de son mouvement general. C'est là le Tourbillon particulier de la Planete & elle le pousse aussi loin que la force de son mouvement se peut étendre. S'il faut qu'il tombe dans ce petit Tourbillon quelque Planete moindre que celle qui y domine, la voilà emportée par la grande & forcée indispensablement à tourner autour d'elle, & le tout ensemble, la grande Planete, la petite, & le Tourbillon qui les renferme, n'en tourne pas moins autour du Soleil. C'est ainsi qu'au commencement du Monde nous nous fîmes suivre par la Lune, parce qu'elle se trouva dans l'étenduë de notre Tourbillon, & tout à fait à notre bienséance. Jupiter, dont je commençois à vous parler, fut plus heureux ou plus puissant que nous. Il y avoit dans son voisinage quatre petites Planètes, ils se les assujettit toutes quatre, & <UP></UP> nous qui sommes une Planète principale, croyez-vous que nous l'eussions êté, si nous nous fussions trouvés proches de luy? Il est quatre vingt- dix-fois plus gros que nous, il nous auroit engloutis sans peine dans son Tourbillon, & nous ne serions qu'une Lune de sa dépendance, au lieu que nous en avons une qui est dans la nôtre, tant il est vray que le seul hazard de la situation décide souvent de toute la fortune qu'on doit avoir.</P065>
chunks.target_manual: <P053>Ah, Madam, said I, if you knew what were Descartes's <RW>Whirlpools or Vortex's</RW>, <NCP>(whose Name is terrible, but their Idea pleasant)</NCP> you would not talk as you do. Must my Head, says she, smiling, turn round to comprehend 'em, or must I become a perfect Fool to understand the misteries of Philosophy? Well, let the World say what it will, go on with your Whirlpools. I will, said I, and you shall see the Whirlpools are worthy of these transports: That then which we call a Whirlpool, or Vortex, is a Mass of Matter, whose parts are separated or detach'd one from another, yet have all one uniform motion, and at the same time, every one is allow'd, or has a particular Motion of its own, provided if follows the general Motion: Thus a Vortex of Wind, or Whirlwind, is an infinity of little particles of Air, which turn round all together, and involve what ever they meet with. You know the Planets are born up by the Celestial Matter, which is prodigiously subtile and active; so that this great Mass, or <IIM>Ocean of</IIM> Celestial Matter, which flows as far as from the Sun to the fix'd Stars, turns round, and bears the Planets along with it, making them all turn after the same manner round the Sun, who possesses the Centre, but in a longer or shorter time, according as they are farther or nearer in distance to it; there is nothing to the very Sun, which does not turn, but he turns on himself because he is just in the middle of this Celestial Matter; and you must know by the way, that were the Earth in his place, it must turn on it self, as the Sun does. This is the great Vortex, of which the Sun is Lord; yet at the same time, the Planets make little particular Vortex's, in imitation of that of the Sun, each of 'em in turning round the Sun, doth at the same time turn round it self, and makes a certain quantity of Celestial Matter turn round it likewise, which is always prepar'd to follow the Motion the Planet gives it, provided it is not diverted from its general Motion; this then is the particular Vortex of the Planet, which pushes it as far as the strength of its Motion reaches; and if by chance, a lesser Planet falls into the Vortex of a greater Planet, it is immediately born away by the greater, and is indispensably forc'd to turn round it, tho' at the same time, the great Planet, the little Planet, and the Vortex which encloses 'em, all turn round the Sun: 'Twas thus at the beginning of the World, when we made the Moon follow us, because she was within the reach of our Vortex, and therefore wholly at our dispose: Jupiter was stronger, or more fortunate than we, he had four little Planets in his neighbourhood, and he brought 'em all four under his subjection; and <UP>no doubt</UP>, we, tho' a principal Planet, had had the same Fate, had we been within the Sphere of his Activity; he is ninety times bigger than the Earth, and would certainly have swallow'd us into his Vortex; we had then been no more than a Moon in his Family, when now we have one to wait on us; so that you see the advantage of Situation, decides often all our good Fortune.</P053>

target_segments: or must I become a perfect Fool to understand the misteries of Philosophy? Well, let the World say what it will, go on with your Whirlpools.
I will, said I, and you shall see the Whirlpools are worthy of these transports:

explanations: The Marquise's enthusiastic French 'Achevez de me rendre folle' (Finish making me mad/crazy [with excitement]) is translated into the questioning 'must I become a perfect Fool,' introducing a negative, self-deprecating tone not in the original's playful abandon. The addition 'to understand the misteries of Philosophy' over-intellectualizes her immediate, spirited reaction. Furthermore, her passionate declaration 'je ne me ménage plus, je ne connois plus de retenuë sur la Philosophie' (I no longer spare myself, I no longer know any restraint regarding Philosophy) is omitted, erasing her specific commitment to philosophical exploration. Her final zealous cry 'donnons-nous aux Tourbillons' (let's give ourselves to the Whirlpools) is weakened to the more mundane 'go on with your Whirlpools.' These combined changes subtly manipulate the portrayal of the Marquise, reducing her intellectual verve and passionate curiosity.

The philosopher's original French reply—observing the Marquise's unusual enthusiasm ('Je ne vous connaissois pas de pareils emportements') and making a subsequent teasing, flirtatious remark ('c'est dommage qu'ils n'ayent que les Tourbillons pour objet')—is entirely replaced. The English translation substitutes this with 'I will, said I, and you shall see the Whirlpools are worthy of these transports,' a direct affirmation of the topic's value. This omission of the original content and its replacement significantly alters the philosopher's characterization, removing his witty observation and the gallant, playful tone central to Fontenelle's work and the dynamic between the characters.

The French 'Tout ce grand amas de matiere celeste' (all this great mass/heap of celestial matter) is translated as 'this great Mass, or Ocean of Celestial Matter.' The addition of 'or Ocean' introduces a powerful and specific metaphor (implying fluidity, vastness, and a certain character) not present in Fontenelle's more general term 'amas.' While Cartesian physics described subtle matter as fluid-like, Fontenelle's choice of 'amas' is more abstract. Adding 'Ocean' makes the concept more concrete and imagistic in a way that Fontenelle did not choose, potentially shaping the reader's understanding by adding a layer of interpretation not in the original text.

The French phrase 'à notre bienséance,' meaning 'suitably for us' or 'conveniently for us' (implying the Moon's position was a matter of fortunate circumstance for Earth), is rendered as 'wholly at our dispose.' This translation shifts the meaning significantly, from a passive, opportune arrangement to an active one suggesting Earth's complete control or dominion over the Moon. This subtly alters the perception of Earth's agency and the nature of its relationship with the Moon, introducing a stronger sense of possession.

The philosopher's French rhetorical question, 'croyez-vous que nous l'eussions êté, si nous nous fussions trouvés proches de luy?' (do you believe we [Earth] would have remained a principal planet, if we had found ourselves near him [Jupiter]?), is designed to engage the Marquise directly and maintain the work's dialogic style. The English translation changes this into a declarative statement: 'and no doubt, we... had had the same Fate...'. This alteration removes the interactive element, flattens the conversational tone, and reduces the direct engagement with the Marquise, thereby subtly modifying Fontenelle's characteristic pedagogical approach.

The original French 'le seul hazard de la situation' (the mere chance/randomness of the situation) is translated as 'the advantage of Situation,'. This substitution significantly alters the philosophical thrust of the statement. 'Hazard' underscores the arbitrary, unpredictable role of chance in determining outcomes, aligning with Enlightenment perspectives that challenged notions of a preordained or divinely micromanaged universe. 'Advantage' introduces a positive connotation, implying benefit or inherent positive quality in the situation, rather than neutral randomness. This shift subtly manipulates the reader's understanding of Fontenelle's commentary on fate and cosmic order.

chunks.source_manual: <P066>Et qui nous assure, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que nous demeurerons toûjours où nous sommes? Je commence à craindre que nous ne fassions la folie de nous approcher d'une Planete aussi entreprenante que Jupiter, ou qu'il <IIM>ne vienne</IIM> vers nous pour nous absorber; car il me paroît que dans ce grand mouvement, où vous dites qu'est la matière Celeste, elle devroit agiter les Planetes irregulièrement, tantôt les approcher, tantôt les éloigner les unes des autres. <UP>Nous pourrions aussi-tôt y gagner qu'y perdre, répondis-je</UP>, peut être irions- nous soumettre à notre domination Mercure & Venus, qui sont de petites Planetes, & qui ne nous pourroient résister. Mais nous n'avons rien à esperer ny à craindre; les Planetes se tiennent où elles sont, & les nouvelles conquêtes leur sont défenduës, comme elles l'étoient autrefois aux Rois de la Chine. Vous savez bien que quand on met de l'huile avec de l'eau, l'huile surnage. Qu'on mette sur ces deux liqueurs un Corps extremement léger <UP></UP>, l'huile le soûtiendra, & il n'ira pas jusqu'à l'eau. Qu'on y mette un autre Corps plus pesant, & qui soit justement d'une certaine pesanteur, il passera au travers de l'huile, qui sera trop foible pour l'arrêter, & tombera jusqu'à ce qu'il rencontre l'eau, qui aura la force de le soûtenir. Ainsi dans cette liqueur composée de deux liqueurs qui ne se mêlent point, deux Corps inégalement pesants se mettent naturellement à deux places differentes, & jamais l'un ne montera, ny l'autre ne descendra. Qu'on mette encore d'autres liqueurs qui se tiennent separées, & qu'on y plonge d'autres corps, il arrivera la même chose. Représentez-vous que la Matiere Celeste qui remplit ce grand Tourbillon, à differentes couches qui s'enveloppent les unes les autres, & dont les pesanteurs sont différentes, comme celles de l'huile & de l'eau, & des autres liqueurs. Les Planetes ont aussi differentes pesanteurs; chacune d'elles par consequent s'arrête dans la couche qui a précisément la force necessaire pour la soûtenir, & qui luy fait équilibre, & vous voyez bien qu'il n'est pas possible qu'elle en sorte jamais.</P066>
chunks.target_manual: <P054>But pray, says she, who can assure us we shall still continue as we do now? if we should be such Fools as to go near Jupiter, or he so <IIM>ambitious</IIM> as to approach us, what will become of us? for if (as you say) the Celestial Matter is continually under this great Motion, it must needs agitate the Planets irregularly; sometimes drive 'em together, and sometimes separate 'em. <UP>Luck is all, said I; we may win as well as lose</UP>, and who knows, but we should bring Mercury and Venus under our Government; they are little Planets, and cannot resist us; but in this particular, Madam, we need not hope or fear; the Planets keep within their own bounds, and are oblig'd (as formerly the Kings of China were) not to undertake new Conquests. Have you not seen when you put Water and Oyl together, the Oyl swims a top; and if to these two Liquors, you add a very light Liquor, the Oyl bears it up, and it will not sink to the Water: But put an heavier Liquor, of a just weight, and it will pass through the Oyl, which is too weak to sustain it, and sink till it comes to the Water, which is strong enough to bear it up; so that in this Liquor, compos'd of two Liquors, which do not mingle, two Bodies of an unequal weight, will naturally assume two different Places; the one will never ascend, the other will never descend: Fancy then that the Celestial Matter which fills this great Vortex, hath several resting places, one by another, whose weight are different, like that of Oyl, Water, and other Liquors; the Planets too are of a different weight, and consequently, every Planet settles in that place which has a just strength to sustain and keep it equilibrate, so you see 'tis impossible it should ever go beyond.</P054>
