explanations: The French 'que nous ne fassions la folie de nous approcher' (that we might commit the folly of approaching) is translated as 'if we should be such Fools as to go near Jupiter'. Using 'Fools' makes the Marquise's expression more blunt and directly judgmental of the hypothetical actors, compared to the original's focus on the action ('la folie de') being foolish. This alters the tone and subtly coarsens the Marquise's refined manner of speech.

The original 'ou qu'il ne vienne vers nous pour nous absorber' (or that it might come towards us to absorb us) states a feared outcome. The translation adds the explicit question 'what will become of us?', which is not directly present in the source. This addition makes the Marquise's expression of fear more overtly dramatic and anxious, shifting the tone from a statement of potential threat to a direct expression of concern for their fate.

The French modal 'devroit' (should, ought to, would likely) indicates a reasoned expectation or probability. The English translation 'must needs agitate' conveys a stronger sense of inevitability or absolute necessity. This shift subtly alters the Marquise's statement, making her speculation on celestial mechanics sound more deterministic than in the original.

The original French 'Nous pourrions aussi-tôt y gagner qu'y perdre, répondis-je,' (We could just as easily gain by it as lose by it, I replied,) is translated with the addition of 'Luck is all,'. This phrase introduces a distinct philosophical overtone of pure chance or fatalism that is not explicitly conveyed in the original statement by the philosopher. This addition alters the tone and adds a new layer of meaning to the philosopher's response.

The French 'Corps' (body, object), in the context of Fontenelle's analogy about objects of varying densities in liquids, refers to a solid object. The translation changes 'Corps' to 'Liquor.' This substitution alters the physical basis of the scientific analogy, as introducing another liquid instead of a solid object raises different physical considerations (e.g., miscibility), potentially confusing the reader's understanding of the principle being illustrated.

Similar to the previous instance, the French 'Corps' (body, object) is translated as 'Liquor.' This consistent change from a (likely solid) object to a liquid in the analogy distorts Fontenelle's intended scientific illustration regarding density and buoyancy within layered fluids.

This entire sentence from the source text, which translates to 'Let one put still other liquids that remain separate, & let one plunge other bodies into them, the same thing will happen,' is omitted from the English translation. The target text transitions directly from the preceding sentence ('...the other will never descend:') to the subsequent one ('Fancy then that the Celestial Matter...'). This omission removes a generalizing step in Fontenelle's analogy, which served to reinforce the concept of complex stratification, thereby simplifying the explanation and potentially shifting the reader's perception of the robustness of the model.

The French 'differentes couches qui s'enveloppent les unes les autres' (different layers that envelop/wrap around one another) provides a clear visual of continuous, concentric stratification. The translation 'several resting places, one by another' is more vague and suggests discrete, possibly separated locations rather than continuous, enveloping layers. This change in imagery reduces the precision of Fontenelle's analogy for Descartes' vortex theory, potentially altering the reader's understanding of the described celestial structure.

chunks.source_manual: <P067>Je conçois, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que ces pesanteurs-là reglent fort bien les rangs. Plût à Dieu qu'il y eût quelque chose de pareil qui les reglât parmi nous, & qui fixât les Gens dans les places qui leur sont naturellement convenables. Me voilà fort en repos du côté de Jupiter. Je suis bien aise qu'il nous laisse dans notre petit tourbillon <SC>avec notre Lune unique</SC>. Je suis bien-aise qu'il nous laisse dans notre petit Tourbillon avec notre Lune unique. Je suis d'humeur à me borner aisément, & je ne lui envie point les quatre qu'il a.</P067> <P068>Vous auriez tort de les luy envier, repris-je, il n'en a point plus qu'il ne luy en faut. Dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil, les Lunes ne reçoivent & ne luy renvoient, qu'une lumière assez faible. Il est vray que comme il tourne sur luy- même en dix heures, & que ses nuits, qui par consequent <IIM>n'en durent que cinq</IIM>, sont fort courtes, quatre Lunes ne paroîtroient pas si necessaires, mail il y a autre chose à considerer. Icy sous les Pôles, on a six mois de jour, & six mois de nuit. C'est que les Pôles sont les deux extremitez de la Terre les plus éloignées des lieux où le Soleil donne à plomb, & sur lesquels il paroit faire sa course. La Lune ne tient, ou paroït tenir la même route à peu prés que le Soleil, & si les Habitans des Pôles voyent le Soleil pendant toute une moitié de sa course d'un an, & pendant toute l'autre moitié ne le voyent point, ils voyent aussi la Lune pendant toute une moitié de sa course d'un mois, c'est à dire, pendant quinze jours, & ils ne la voyent point pendant toute l'autre moitié. Les années. <IIM>Les années de Jupiter</IIM> en valent douze des nôtre, & il doit y avoir dans cette Planete deux extremitez opposées, où l'on ait des jours & des nuits de six ans. <IIM>Des nuits</IIM> de six ans sont bien longues, aussi est ce principalement pour elles que je crois que le quatre Lunes sont faites. Celle qui à l'egard de Jupiter est la plus élevée, fait son cercle autour de luy en dix-sept jours, la seconde en septe, la troisième en trois jours & demi, la quatrième en quarante-deux heures. Leurs courses êtant coupées justement par la moitié pour ces malheureux <UP></UP> Pays qui ont six ans d nuit, il ne se peut passer vingt & heures, qu'on ne voye paroître au mois la derniere Lune. C'est quelque consolation pendant des tenebres d'une durée si ennuyeuse, mais quelque lieu que l'on habite dans Jupiter, ces quatre Lune vous y donnent les plus jolis Spectacles <UP></UP> du monde. Tantôt elles se lèvent toutes quatre ensemble, & puis se separent selon l'inégalité de leur cours; tantôt elles sont toutes à leur Midy, rangées l'une au dessus de l'autre, tantôt <RW>on les</RW> voit toutes quatre sur l'Horizon à des distances égales; tantôt quand deux se levent, deux autres se couchent; sur tout j'aimerois à voir ce jeu perpétuel d'Eclipses qu'elles font, car il ne se passe point de jour qu'elles ne s'éclipsent les unes les autres, ou qu'elles n'éclipsent le Soleil, & assurément, les Eclipses s'êtant renduës si familières en ce Monde-là, elles y sont un sujet de divertissement, & non pas de frayeur, comme en celui-ci.</P068> <P069><SC>Gens de nôtre Lune</SC>, me fait douter que Jupiter en ait beaucoup sur le Habitans de siennes, & jr croy qu'un des avantages ausquels ils puissent le plus raisonablement pretendre, c'est de leur faire peur. <UP>Par exemple, dans celle qui est la plus proche de luy, ils le voyent trois cents soixante fois plus gros que nôtre Lune ne nous paroît, car il la surpasse autant en grosseur. Il est, jr croy, beaucoup plus proche d'eux, qu'elle n'est de nous, sa grosseur en augmente encore. Ils fent comme des Colonies de Jupiter; qu'elles eussent receu de luy, s'il êtoit possible, leurs Loix & leurs Coûtumes; que par consequent elles luy redissent quelque sorte d'hommage, & ne regardassent la grande Planete qu'avec rêspect. Ne faudroit-il point aussi, luy dis-je, que les quatre Lunes en- voyassent de temps en temps des Députez dans Jupiter, pour luy prêter ferment de fidelité? Pour moy, je vous avoüe que le peu de superiorité que nous avons sur les Gens.</UP></P069>
chunks.target_manual: <P055>Would to God, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, our World were as well regulated, and every one among us knew their proper Place. I am now in no fear of being over-run by Jupiter; and since he lets us alone in our Vortex, with our Moon, I do not envy him the four which he hath. Did you envy him, I reply'd, you would do him wrong, for he has no more than what he has occasion for; at the distance he is from the Sun, his Moons receive, and send him but a very weak light; it is true, that as he turns upon himself in ten hours, his nights, by consequence, are but five hours long; so one would think there is no great occasion for four Moons; but there are other things to be considered. Here under the Poles, they have six Months Day, and six Months Night, because the Poles are the two extremities of the Earth, the farthest removed from those places where the Sun is over 'em in a perpendicular line. The Moon seems to keep almost the same course as the Sun, and if the Inhabitants of the Poles see the Sun during one half of his course of a Year, and during the other half, do not see him at all; they see the Moon likewise during one half of her course of a Month; that is, she appears to 'em fifteen days, but they do not see her during the other half. Jupiter's Year is as much as twelve of ours, so that there must be two opposite extremities in that Planet, where their Night and their Day are six Years each. A Night six Years long, is a little disconsolate, and 'tis for that reason, I suppose, they have four Moons; that which (in regard to Jupiter) is uppermost, finisheth its course about him in seventeen days, the second in seven, the third in three days and an half, and the fourth in two and forty hours; and tho' they are so unfortunate as to have six years Night, yet their course being exactly divided into halves, they never pass above one and twenty hours, wherein they do not see at least the last Moon, which is a great comfort in so tedious a darkness; so that be where you will, these four Moons are sometimes the prettiest sight imaginable; sometimes they rise all four together, and then separate according to the inequality of their course; sometimes they are all in their Meridian, rang'd one above another, sometimes you see 'em at equal distances on the Horizon, sometimes when two rise, the other two go down. Oh, how I should love to see this pleasant sport of Eclipses; for there is not a Day passes but they Eclipse the Sun, or one another; and they are so accustom'd to this diversion in Jupiter, <UP>that the late Duke of B-m in his Rehersal, brought the dance of Eclipses from that Planet, as now most of our modish Dances come out of France</UP>.</P055>

explanations: The original French text refers to the female interlocutor as "la Marquise." The English translation changes this specific aristocratic title to "the Countess." While both denote nobility, altering the title changes a detail of the character as presented by Fontenelle. This could subtly shift the English reader's perception or associations with the character, potentially making her seem more aligned with English aristocratic archetypes if "Countess" carried different connotations than "Marquise" (or its direct English equivalent "Marchioness") in the target socio-cultural context of late 17th-century England.

The original French expresses a wish for something to "regulate" society and "fix" people into their naturally suitable places, implying an external mechanism of control. The English translation softens this to a wish that the world "were as well regulated" and that "every one among us knew their proper Place." This shifts the focus from an imposed order to an internalized understanding or acceptance of social hierarchy, subtly altering the tone of the speaker's statement and making it less overtly authoritarian, a relevant shift given the political sensitivities about authority in contemporary England.

The original "Me voilà fort en repos" (I am very much at ease/peace) concerning Jupiter is translated as "I am now in no fear of being over-run by Jupiter." The translation introduces a specific and dramatic threat ("being over-run") not explicit in the original. This alters the tone from calm reassurance to a more vivid negation of a potential danger, possibly to heighten engagement by implying Jupiter's menace.

The translation omits the initial clause "Je suis d'humeur à me borner aisément" ("I am of a temperament to limit myself easily" or "I am easily content with my lot") from the original French sentence. This clause reveals a key aspect of the speaker's character—her philosophical contentment. Its omission deprives the reader of this nuance, subtly altering the character's portrayal by removing her expression of personal philosophy.

The French "quelque consolation" (some consolation) is translated as "a great comfort." This intensification exaggerates the degree of solace described. By amplifying the positive aspect, the translation subtly alters the original's more measured tone, potentially making the conditions on Jupiter appear more providentially arranged or less harsh, a nuance that could resonate with audiences navigating scientific and theological shifts.

The translation replaces Fontenelle's general observation—that eclipses on Jupiter are a source of amusement rather than fear as on Earth ("comme en celui-ci")—with a lengthy, specific, and contemporary English cultural interpolation regarding "the late Duke of B-m in his Rehersal" and French dances. This addition fundamentally changes the philosopher's remark by domesticating the text, inserting anachronistic English-centric details, and shifting the focus from a philosophical comparison to light social commentary, thereby manipulating the reader's experience of Fontenelle's original point.

chunks.source_manual: <P070>Et vous ne manquerez pas, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, à faire habiter ces quatre Lunes, quoy que ce ne foient que de petites Planetes subalternes, destinées seulement à en éclairer une autre pendant ces nuits? N'en doutez nullement, répondis-je. Ces Planees n'en sont pas moins dignes d'être habitées pour avoir le malheur d'être asservies à tourner autour d'une autre plus importante.</P070> <P071>Je voudrais donc, reprit-elle, que les Habitans des quatre Lunes de Jupiter <UP></UP>, fussont donc toûjours cette monstrueuse Planete sûspedüe sur leurs têtes à une distance assez petite. En verité, si les Gaulois craignaient anciennement que le ciel ne tombât sur eux, les Habitans de cette Lune auroient bien plus de sujet de craindre une chute de Jupiter <UP></UP>. C'est peut-être là aussi la frayeur qu'ils ont, dit- elle, au lieu de celle des Eclipses, dont vous m'avez assurée qu'ils sont exempts, & qu'il faut bien remplacer par quelque autre sottise? Il le faut de necessité absolue, répondis-je. L'inventeur du troisième Système dont je vous parlois l'autre jour, le celebre Tycho Brahé <UP></UP>, un des plus grands Astronomes qui furent jamais, n'avoit garde de craindre les Eclipses, comme le Vulgaire les craint, il passoit sa vie avec elles. Mais croiriez-vous bien ce qu'il craignoit en leur place? Si en sortant de son logis la premiere personne qu'il rencontroit êtoit une Vieille, si un Lievre traversoit son chemin, Tycho Brahé croyoit que la journée devoit être malheureuse, & retournoit promptement se renfermer chez luy, sans oser commencer la moindre chose.</P071>
chunks.target_manual: <P056>Well, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, I hope you will People these four Moons, tho' you say they are but little secondary Planets, appointed to give light to another Planet during its Night. Do not doubt it, I reply'd; these Planets are not a jot the worse to be inhabited, for being forc'd to turn round another Planet of greater consequence. I would have then, says she, the People of these four Moons, to be so many Colonies under Jupiter's <UP>Government</UP>; they should receive their Laws and Customs from him. Would it not be convenient too, said I, that they should send Deputies with Addresses to him; for he hath cetainly a more absolute command over his Moon, than we have over ours; tho' his Power <UP>after all, is but imaginary</UP>, and consists chiefly in making 'em afraid; for that Moon which is nearest to him, sees that he is <UP>three hundred and sixty times bigger than our Moon appears to us</UP>; for in truth, he is so much bigger than she; he is also much nearer to them, than our Moon is to us, the which makes him appear the greater, so that this <UP>formidable</UP> Planet hangs continually over their Heads, at a very little distance and if the Gauls were afraid heretofore that the Heavens would fall on 'em, I think the Inhabitants of that Moon may well be apprehensive that Jupiter will at some time or other overwhelm 'em. They are, says she, I fancy, possess'd with that fear, because they are not concern'd at Eclipses: Every one has their due folly; we are afraid of an Eclipse, and they, that Jupiter will fall on their Heads. It is very true, said I, the Inventer of the third Systeme, I told you t'other night, the famous Ticho Brahe, <NCP>(one of the greatest Astronomers that ever was,)</NCP> <UP>did not apprehend the least danger from an Eclipse, when every body else was under the greatest consternation; yet this great Man had as an unaccountable a fear, did a hare cross him, or were the first Person he met in a morning an old Woman, home presently went Ticho Brahe, he shut himself up for that day, and would not meddle with the least Business</UP>.</P056>

explanations: The French "le malheur d'être asservies" (the misfortune of being subjugated/enslaved) conveys a strong sense of inherent servitude and suffering. The translation "being forc'd" significantly softens this, reducing it to an external compulsion and omitting "le malheur" (the misfortune). This alteration downplays any implied critique of fated subservience or hierarchical power structures, potentially sensitive in the era's political climate.

Fontenelle's Marquise muses on the constant, imposing visual presence of Jupiter for its moon-dwellers (described in the source segment). The English translation replaces this with the entirely new idea of the inhabitants being "Colonies under Jupiter's Government" receiving "Laws and Customs from him." This substantial addition introduces political themes of colonialism and hierarchical rule absent in Fontenelle's original, potentially reflecting contemporary English political concerns.

Following the Marquise's original statement (ending with the source segment "...distance assez petite."), the translator inserts this lengthy speech attributed to the philosopher. This entire speech, discussing "Deputies with Addresses" and Jupiter's "absolute command," is an addition not found in the source. It significantly alters the dialogue by injecting extensive political commentary, possibly to resonate with English discussions on governance and authority.

The Marquise's original insightful and confident comparison (source segment) is reattributed in the translation to the philosopher ("I think..."). Her strong assertion "auroient bien plus de sujet de craindre" (would have much more reason to fear) is also softened to the more tentative "may well be apprehensive." This shift diminishes the Marquise's intellectual agency, contrary to Fontenelle's intent of portraying women as capable of engaging with scientific ideas.

The Marquise's witty, rhetorical question about one folly needing replacement by "quelque autre sottise?" (some other foolishness/nonsense?) is transformed into a didactic, proverbial statement "Every one has their due folly," followed by specific examples. This change alters her tone from playfully philosophical to declarative and removes the generality of her original comment on human irrationality.

The French "le Vulgaire les craint" (as the common/uneducated people fear them) specifically contrasts the astronomer with the "Vulgaire." The translation "when every body else was under the greatest consternation" broadens this to "every body else," neutralizing the social distinction important to Fontenelle's popularizing aim. It also intensifies the reaction from "fear" (craint) to "greatest consternation."

The French phrase "il passoit sa vie avec elles" (he spent his life with them [eclipses]), which should follow the description of common fear (ending "...consternation;") and precede the mention of Tycho's other fear (starting "yet...") as shown in the target segment, is omitted in the translation. This omission removes a detail that underscores Tycho Brahe's deep familiarity with eclipses, thereby weakening the irony of his unrelated superstitious fears.

The translator adds "in a morning" to the superstition about meeting an old woman. The original French (source segment) means "on leaving his dwelling, the first person he met was an Old woman," without specifying the time of day. This addition introduces a detail not present in the source, subtly altering the conditions of the described superstition.

chunks.source_manual: <P072>Il ne seroit pas juste, reprit- <IIM>elle</IIM>, après que cet homme-là n'a pû se delivrer impunément de la, que les Habitans de cette <UP></UP> Lune de Jupiter, dont nous parlions, en fussent quittes à meilleur marché. Nous ne leur ferons pas de quartier, ils subiront la Loy commune <UP></UP>, & donneront dans quelque autre erreur, mais comme je ne me pique pas de la pouvoir deviner, éclaircissez-moy, je vous prie, une autre difficulté qui m'occupe depuis quelques moments. Si la Terre est si petite à l'égard de Jupiter, Jupiter nous voit-il? Je crains que nous ne luy soyons inconnus.</P072> <P073>De bonne foy, je croy que cela est, répondis-je. Il faudroit qu'il vît la Terre quatre-vingt-dix fois plus petite que nous ne le voyons. C'est trop peu, il ne la voit point. Voicy seulement ce que nous pouvons croire de meilleur pour nous. Il y aura dans Jupiter des Astronomes, qui aprés avoir bien pris de la peine à composer des Lunettes excellentes, aprés avoir choisy les plus belles Nuits pour observer, auront enfin découvert dans les Cieux une petite Planete qu'ils n'avoient jamais veüe. D'abord le <NCE>Journal des Savants</NCE> de ce Pays-là en parle; le Peuple de Jupiter, ou n'en entend point parler, ou n'en fait que rire. Les Philosophes dont cela détruit les opinions, forment le dessein de n'en rien croire, il n'y a que les Gens tres raisonnables qui en veulent bien douter. On observe encore, on revoit la petite Planete, on s'assure bien que ce n'est point une vision; on commence même à soupçonner qu'elle a un mouvement autour du Soleil; on trouve au bout de mille observations, que ce <RW>mouvement</RW> est d'une année; & enfin, grâce à toutes les peines que se donnent les Savats, <NCP></NCP> on sait dans Jupiter que notre Terre est un Monde. Les Lurieux vont la voir au bout d'une Lunette, & la veüe à peine peut-elle encore l'attraper.</P073>
chunks.target_manual: <P057>Let us go on with ours tho', says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, and leave Ticho Brahe to defend his Superstition. Pray tell me, if the Earth be so little in comparison of Jupiter, whether his Inhabitants do discover us? Indeed, said I, I believe not; for if we appear to him ninety times less than he appears to us; judge you if there be any possibility: Yet this we may reasonably conjecture, that there are Astronomers in Jupiter, that after they have made the most curious Telescopes, and taken the clearest Night for their observations, they may have discover'd a little Planet in the Heavens, which they never saw before; if they publish their discovery, most People know not what they mean, or laugh at 'em for Fools; nay, the Philosophers themselves will not believe 'em, for fear of destroying their own opinions; yet some few may be a little curious; they continue their observations, discover the little Planet again, and are now assur'd it is no Vision; then they conclude it hath a motion round the Sun, which it compleats in a year, and at last, <NCP>(thanks to the Learned,)</NCP> they know in Jupiter our Earth is a World, every body runs to see it at the end of the Telescope, tho' 'tis so little, 'tis hardly discover'd.</P057>

explanations: The translation omits the Marquise's entire reflection on the potential errors of inhabitants of Jupiter's moon and the concept of shared fallibility, which she links to a prior discussion. Instead, it inserts an abrupt, dismissive remark: "Let us go on with ours tho', says the Countess, and leave Ticho Brahe to defend his Superstition." This alters the Marquise's character from a nuanced thinker to someone more brusque, and introduces the loaded term "Superstition" to describe Tycho Brahe's views. This addition and omission significantly change the tone and content, potentially aligning Fontenelle's work with stronger contemporary English anti-traditional or anti-Catholic sentiments by harshly framing an alternative scientific model.

The French "ou n'en fait que rire" translates to "or only laugh at it/them." The English translation "or laugh at 'em for Fools;" intensifies the public's reaction by explicitly adding the judgment that the discoverers are "Fools." This makes the popular resistance to new scientific ideas seem more derisive and scornful than the original's implication of simple dismissal or amusement, subtly shifting the perception of the societal challenges faced by scientific pioneers.

The original French states that philosophers whose opinions are contradicted by a new discovery "forment le dessein de n'en rien croire" (form the intention/plan not to believe it), indicating a deliberate, conscious decision. The English translation alters this by adding the motivation "for fear of destroying their own opinions." By introducing "fear" as the explicit driver, the translation portrays these philosophers as reacting out of emotional defensiveness and self-preservation rather than making a calculated, albeit misguided, intellectual choice. This subtly manipulates the reader's understanding of intellectual resistance to scientific progress.

The French phrase "il n'y a que les Gens tres raisonnables qui en veulent bien douter" translates to "there are only very reasonable People who are willing to doubt it," emphasizing reason and an active, virtuous intellectual stance of openness. The English translation "yet some few may be a little curious;" significantly diminishes this. "A little curious" is a much more passive and less intellectually weighty characteristic than being "very reasonable" and "willing to doubt." This change downplays the Enlightenment ideal of reasoned skepticism that Fontenelle champions, subtly altering the perceived qualities necessary for embracing new scientific truths.

chunks.source_manual: <P074>Si ce n'êtoit, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, qu'il n'est point trop agreable de savoir qu'on ne nous peut découvrir de dedans Jupiter qu'avec des Lunettes d'approche, je me représenterois avec plaisir ces Lunettes de Jupiter dressées vers nous, comme les nôtres le sont vers luy, & cette curiosité mutuelle avec laquelle les Planetes s'entre-considèrent & demandent l'une de l'autre, Quel monde est-ce là? Quelles gens l'habitent?</P074> <P075><IIM>Cela ne va pas si vite que vous pensez</IIM>, répliquay-je. Quand on verroit nôtre Terre de dedans Jupiter, quand on l'y connoîtroit, nôtre Terre ce n'est pas nous; on n'a pas le moindre soupçon qu'elle puisse être habitée. Si quelqu'un vient à se l'imaginer, Dieu sait comme tout Jupiter se moque de luy. Peut-être même sommes-nous cause qu'on y <UP>a fait le procés</UP> à des Philosophes qui ont voulu soûtenir que nous êtions. Cependant je croirois plus volontiers que les Habitans de Jupiter sont assez occupez à faire des découvertes sur leur Planete, pour ne songer point du tout à nous. Elle est si grande, que s'ils navigent, assurément <UP>leurs Christophe Colombs ne sauroient manquer d'employ</UP>. Il faut que les Peuples de ce Monde-là ne connoissent pas seulement de réputation la centiéme partie des autres Peuples, au lieu que dans Mercure, <NCP>qui est fort petit</NCP>, ils sont tous voisins les uns des autres, ils vivent familierement ensemble, & ne comptent que pour une promenade de faire le tour de leur Monde. Si on ne nous voit point dans Jupiter, vous jugez bien qu'on y voit encore moins Venus & Mercure, qui sont des Mondes, & plus petits, & plus éloignez de luy. En récompense ses Habitans voyent Mars, & leurs quatre Lunes, & Saturne <RW>avec les siennes</RW>. Voilà assez de Planetes pour embarrasser ceux d'entre eux qui sont Astronomes; la Nature a eu la bonté de leur cacher ce qui en reste dans l'Univers.</P075> <P076>Quoy, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, vous comptez cela pour une grâce? Sans doute, répondis-je. Il y a dans tout ce grand <RW>Tourbillon</RW> seize Planetes. La Nature qui veut nous épargner la peine d'étudier tous leurs mouvemens, ne nous en montre que sept, n'est-ce pas là une assez grande faveur? Mais nous, qui n'en sentons pas le prix, nous faisons si bien que nous attrapons les neuf autres qui avoient êté cachées; aussi en sommes-nous punis par les grands travaux que l'Astronomie demande presentement.</P076>
chunks.target_manual: <P058>It must be pleasant, says she, to see the Astronomers of both Planets, levelling their Tubes at one another, like two files of Musqueteers, and mutually asking, What World is that? What People inhabit it? Not so fast neither, I reply'd, for tho' they may from Jupiter discover our Earth, yet they may not know us; that is, they may not have the least suspicion it is inhabited; and should any one there chance to have such a fancy, he might be sufficiently ridicul'd, if not prosecuted for it; for my part, I believe they have work enough to make discoveries on their own Planet, not to trouble their Heads with ours; <UP>and had Sir Francis Drake and Columbus been in Jupiter, they might have had good employments</UP>; why, I warrant you, they have not yet discover'd the hundredth part of their Planet; when Mercury is so little, they are all <NCP>(as it were)</NCP> near Neighbours, and 'tis but taking a walk, to go round that Planet. But if we do not appear to 'em in Jupiter, they cannot certainly discover Venus and Mercury, which are much less than the Earth, and at a greater distance; but in lieu of it, they see Mars, their own four Moons, and Saturn, with his; this I think is work enough for their Astronomers; and Nature hath been so kind to conceal from 'em the rest of the Universe. Do you think it a favour then, says she? Yes, certainly, said I, for there are sixteen Planets in this great Vortex: Nature saves us the trouble of studying the Motions of 'em all, and shows us but seven, which I think is very obliging, tho' we know not how to value the kindness, for we have recover'd the other nine which were hid from us, and so render'd the Science of Astronomy much more difficult than Nature design'd it.</P058>

explanations: The original French expresses a conditional pleasure from the Marquise ('If it weren't... that it's not very pleasant to know... I would imagine with pleasure...'). The English translation changes this to an unqualified assertion ('It must be pleasant...'), which alters the Marquise's tone from nuanced and reflective to more direct and certain, subtly changing her characterization.

The original French presents a poetic image of 'les Planetes s'entre-considèrent' (the Planets consider each other), personifying the planets themselves as the agents of curiosity. The translation changes the agents to 'the Astronomers of both Planets' and the action to 'levelling their Tubes,' making the observation explicitly human-driven and technical, thereby losing the original's more abstract and imaginative personification.

The English translation describes the telescopes as 'levelling their Tubes at one another' (a fair rendering of the French 'Lunettes... dressées vers nous, comme les nôtres le sont vers luy') but then adds the simile 'like two files of Musqueteers.' This militaristic image is an embellishment not present in the original French. The addition significantly alters the tone of the scene, injecting a confrontational or regimented feel into what was a depiction of mutual telescopic observation, potentially clashing with Fontenelle's intended 'literary charm'.

The original French 'Dieu sait comme tout Jupiter se moque de luy' (God knows how all of Jupiter mocks him) conveys a strong sense of widespread and intense ridicule. The English translation 'he might be sufficiently ridicul'd' significantly tones this down, presenting the mockery as merely adequate or 'sufficient' rather than emphatic. This alteration lessens the perceived societal pressure or condemnation against such a thinker on Jupiter.

The original French text uses 'leurs Christophe Colombs' (their Christopher Columbuses) as a generic term for explorers. The English translation introduces 'Sir Francis Drake,' a prominent English historical figure, alongside Columbus. This addition serves to anglicize the reference, potentially to resonate more with an English audience of the time, but in doing so, it subtly injects a nationalistic element not present in Fontenelle's original phrasing, which could be significant in the given English socio-political context.

The French text states that humanity is 'punished' ('punis') by the 'great labors' astronomy now demands due to new discoveries. The English translation omits the explicit concept of 'punishment' and reframes the consequence as rendering astronomy 'much more difficult than Nature design'd it.' This alteration softens the original's potentially cautionary tone regarding human hubris and introduces a different philosophical nuance about acting against a perceived natural design, which might reflect a shift in emphasis during the early Enlightenment or an attempt to avoid interpretations of divine retribution.

chunks.source_manual: <P077>Je voy, reprit-elle, par ce nombre de seize Planetes qu'il faut que Saturne ait cinq Lunes. Il les a aussi, répliquay-je, & de ces cinq Lunes, il y en a deux bien fraîchement découvertes; mais il ya a quelque chose qui est encore bien plus remarquable. Comme son année est de trente des nôtres, & que par consequent il a <IIM>des Pays</IIM>, où une seule nuit dure quinze ans entiers, devinez ce que la Nature a inventé pour éclaires des nuits si affreuses. Elle ne s'est pas contentée de donner cinq Lunes à Saturne, elle a mis autour de luy un grand Cercle, ou un grand Anneau qui l'environne entierement, & qui êtant assez élevé pour être hors de l'ombre du Corps de cette Planete, refléchit perpetuellement la lumiere du Soleil <RW>dans les lieux qui ne le voyent point</RW>.</P077>
chunks.target_manual: <P059>If there are sixteen Planets, says she, Saturn must have five Moons. 'Tis very true, said I, and two of these five, are but lately discover'd; but there is somewhat that is more remarkable, since his Year is thirty of ours, there are consequently in him some Countreys, where their Night is fifteen years long; and what can you imagine Nature hath invented to give light, during so dreadful a Night? Why, she hath not only given Saturn five Moons, but she hath encompass'd him round with a great Circle or Ring, the which being plac'd beyond the reach of the shadow which the Body of that Planet casts, reflects the light of the Sun continually on those places where they cannot see the Sun at all.</P059>
source_segments: encore bien plus remarquable
hors de l'ombre
Elle ne s'est pas contentée de donner cinq Lunes à Saturne
target_segments: more remarkable
beyond the reach of the shadow
Why, she hath not only given Saturn five Moons
explanations: The French "encore bien plus remarquable" (meaning 'even much more remarkable' or 'still far more remarkable') has its intensity significantly reduced by being translated simply as "more remarkable." This omission of the intensifiers "encore bien" tones down the original emphasis on the exceptional nature of the phenomenon, subtly altering the reader's perception of its significance.

The French phrase "hors de l'ombre" literally means "out of the shadow" or "outside the shadow," a simple positional description. The English translation "beyond the reach of the shadow" introduces a more dynamic concept, implying the shadow has a "reach" that is overcome. This subtly alters the original by suggesting a more active or designed quality to the ring's placement relative to the shadow, rather than a simple positional state.

The English translation introduces the interjection "Why," at the beginning of the sentence describing Nature's actions, which is absent in the French original "Elle ne s'est pas contentée..." (She was not content...). This addition changes the tone from a straightforward declarative statement to a more exclamatory or emphatic one, subtly manipulating the reader by altering the narrative voice and emphasis when presenting Nature's ingenuity.

chunks.source_manual: <P078>En verité, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, <IIM>de l'air d'une personne qui rentroit en elle-même avec étonnement</IIM>, tout cela est d'un grand ordre; il paroît bien que la Nature a eu en veüe les besoins de quelques Etres vivans, & que la distribution des Lunes n'a pas êté faite au hazard. Il n'en est tombé en partage qu'aux Planetes éloignées du Soleil, à la Terre, à Jupiter, à Saturne, car ce n'êtoit pas la peine d'en donner à Vénus & à Mercure, qui ne reçoivent que trop de lumiere, dont les nuits sont fort courtes, & qui les comptent apparemment pour de plus grands bienfaits de la Nature que leurs jours mêmes. Mais attendez, il me semble que Mars, qui est encore plus éloigné du Soleil que la Terre, n'a <IIM>point de Lune</IIM>. On ne peut pas vous le dissimuler, répondis-je, il n'en a point, & il faut qu'il ait pour ses nuits des ressources que nous ne savons pas. Vous avez veu des <SC>Phosphores</SC>, de ces matières liquides ou seches, qui en recevant la lumiere du Soleil, s'en imbibent, & s'en penetrent, & ensuite jettent un assez grand éclat dans l'obscurité. <SC>Peut-être Mars a-t-il</SC> de grands Rochers fort élevés, qui sont des <SC>Phosphores</SC> naturels, & qui prennent pendant le jour une provision de lumière qu'ils rendent pendant la nuit. Vous ne sauriez rier que ce ne fût un Spectacle assez agreable, de voir tous ces Rochers s'allumer de toutes parts dé que le Soleil seroit couché, & faire sans aucun art des illuminations magnifiques. Vous savez encore qu'il y a en Amérique des Oiseaux qui sont si lumineux dans les tenebres, qu'on s'en peut servir pour lire. Que savons-nous si Mars n'a point un grand nombre de ces Oiseaux, qui dés que la nuit est venuë, se dispersent de tous côtés, & vont répandre un nouveau jour?</P078>
chunks.target_manual: <P060>I protest, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, this is very surprizing, and yet all is contriv'd in such great order, that it is impossible not to think but Nature took time to consider the necessities of all animate Beings, and that the disposing of these Moons was not a work of Chance, for they are only divided among those Planets which are farthest distant from the Sun, the Earth, Jupiter, Saturn; indeed it was not worth while to give any to Mercury or Venus, they have too much light already; and they account their nights (as short as they are) a greater blessing than their day. But pray, why has not Mars a Moon too? It seems he has none, tho' he is much further than the Earth from the Sun. It is very true, said I; no doubt but he hath other helps, tho' we do not know 'em: You have seen the Phosphorus, both liquid and dry, how it receives and imbibes the rays of the Sun, and what a great light it will cast in a dark Place: Perhaps Mars hath many great high Rocks, which are so many natural Phosphorus's, which in the day take in a certain provision of light, and return it again at night. What think you, Madam, is it not very pleasant when the Sun is down to see those lighted Rocks, like so many Illuminations at a Birth day night? Besides, there is a kind of Bird in America, that yields such a light, you may read by it in the darkest night; and who knows but Mars may have great flocks of these Birds, that as soon as it is night, disperse themselves into all parts, and spread from their wings another day.</P060>

explanations: The French "En verité" (Indeed, Truly) is translated to "I protest," which carries a stronger, more formal, and potentially more assertive or even slightly objectory tone. This alters the Marquise's voice and the connotation of her statement, potentially making her sound more emphatic or dramatic than the original.

The French "quelques" (some) is mistranslated as "all." This significantly broadens the scope of Nature's providence from being considerate of "some" living beings to "all" animate beings, altering the philosophical implication by suggesting a more universally encompassing design by Nature than stated in the original, thus shifting the reader's perception.

The French "éloignées" (distant, remote) is translated as the superlative "farthest distant." This exaggeration of distance subtly intensifies the described condition, potentially making the planets seem more extremely situated and thus heightening the perceived necessity for moons, a nuance not present in the original.

The Marquise's original reflective statement, "Mais attendez, il me semble que Mars... n'a point de Lune" (But wait, it seems to me that Mars... has no Moon), indicating a dawning realization, is restructured into a direct question, "But pray, why has not Mars a Moon too? It seems he has none...". This changes the mode of her discourse from gentle speculation to active interrogation, subtly altering the portrayal of her intellectual engagement. The addition of "pray" further shifts the tone of her utterance.

The translation adds the culturally specific English reference "at a Birth day night," which is absent in the French phrase "faire sans aucun art des illuminations magnifiques" (make without any art/artifice magnificent illuminations). This addition shifts perception by comparing a natural, "artless" cosmic phenomenon to a familiar, human-made celebration, domesticating the wonder and potentially grounding it in a specific English social context not intended by Fontenelle, while also diminishing the emphasis on the natural, unadorned ("sans aucun art") quality of the spectacle.

The translation adds the specific descriptive detail "from their wings," which is not present in the original French "vont répandre un nouveau jour?" (go to spread a new day?). This addition introduces a concrete visual element chosen by the translator, embellishing the original text and guiding the reader's imagination in a more specific way than Fontenelle’s more general phrasing, thus subtly altering the imagery.

chunks.source_manual: <P079>Je ne me contente, reprit-elle, ny de vos Rochers, ni de vos Oiseaux. Cela ne laisseroit pas d'être joly, mais puis que la Nature a donné tant de Lunes à Saturne & à Jupiter, c'est une marque qu'il faut des Lunes. J'eusse êté bien-aise que tous les Mondes éloignez du Soleil en eussent eu, si Mars ne nous fût point venu faire une exception desagreable. Ah! vraiment, répliquay-je, si <LS><IIM>vous vous mêliez de Philosophie plus que vous ne faites</IIM></LS>, il faudroit bien que vous vous accoûtumassiez à voir des exceptions dans les meilleurs Sistêmes. Il y a toûjours quelque chose qui y convient le plus juste du monde, & puis quelque chose aussi qu'on y fait convenir comme on peut, ou qu'on laisse-là, si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout. Usons-en de même pour Mars, puis qu'il ne nous est point favorable, & ne parlons point de luy. Nous serions bien étonnez, si nous êtions dans Saturne, de voir sur nos têtes pendant la nuit ce grand Anneau qui iroit en forme de demiy Cercle d'un bout à l'autre de l'Horizon, & qui nous renvoyant la lumiere du Soleil feroit l'effet d'une Lune continuë. Et ne mettrons-nous point d'Habitans dans ce grand Anneau, interrompit-elle en riant? Quoy que je sois d'humeur, répondis-je, à en envoyer par tout assez hardiment, je vous avoüe que je n'oserois en mettre là, cet Anneau me paroît une Habitation trop irregulière. Pour les cinq petites Lunes, on ne peut pas se dispenser de les peupler. Si cependant l'Anneau n'êtoit, comme quelques-uns le soupçonnent, qu'un Cercle de Lunes qui se suivissent de fort prés, & eussent un mouvement égal, & que les cinq petites Lunes fussent trois échappées de ce grand Cercle, que de Mondes dans le Tourbillon de Saturne! Quoy qu'il en soit, avec le secours même de l'Anneau, les Gens de Saturne sont assez misérables. Il leur donne la lumiere, mais quelle lumiere, dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil! Le Soleil même n'est pour eux qu'une petite Etoile blanche & pâle, qui n'a qu'un éclat & une chaleur bien foible, & si vous les mettiez dans nos Pays les plus froids, dans le Groënland, ou dans la Laponie, vous les verriez suër à grosses gouttes & expirer de chaud.</P079>
chunks.target_manual: <P061>I am not at all contented, says she, with your Rocks, or your Birds; 'tis a pretty fancy indeed, but 'tis a sign that there should be Moons in Mars, since Nature hath given so many to Saturn, and Jupiter; and if all the other Worlds that are distant from the Sun, have Moons, why should Mars only be excepted? Ah, Madam, said I, when you are a little more dip'd in Philosophy, you will find exceptions in the very best Systemes; there are always some things that agree extream well, but then there are others that do not accord at all; those you must leave as you found 'em, if ever you intend to make an end: We will do so by Mars, if you please, and say no more of him; but return to Saturn. What do you think of his great Ring, in the form of a semy Circle, that reaches from one end of the Horizon to the other, which reflecting the light of the Sun, performs the office of a continual Moon. And must we not inhabit this Ring too, says she? I confess, said I, in the humour I am in, I could almost send Colonies every where; and yet I can't well plant any there, it seems so irregular an habitation; but for the five little Moons, they cannot chuse but be inhabited; tho' some think this Ring is a Circle of Moons, which follow close to one another, and have one equal Motion; and that the five little Moons fell out of this Circle; how many Worlds are there then in the <UP>Vortex of Saturn</UP>? But let it be how it will, the People in Saturn live very miserably: 'Tis true, this Ring gives light to 'em, but it must be a very poor one, when the Sun seems to 'em but a little pale Star, whose light and heat cannot but be very weak at so great a distance; they say Greenland is a perfect Bagnio in comparison of that Planet, and that they would expire with heat in our coldest Countreys.</P061>

explanations: The original French presents a general deduction by the Marquise: 'c'est une marque qu'il faut des Lunes' (it's a sign that Moons are needed/necessary). The translation alters this by making her deduction prematurely specific to Mars: ''tis a sign that there should be Moons in Mars,'. This changes the Marquise's logical progression, where in the original she first makes a general point about the necessity of moons and then laments Mars as an exception.

The French expresses a past subjunctive of regret and a hypothetical condition: 'J'eusse êté bien-aise que... en eussent eu, si Mars ne...' (I would have been very pleased if... had had them, if Mars hadn't...). The translation changes this into a present conditional followed by a direct, somewhat challenging question: 'and if all the other Worlds... have Moons, why should Mars only be excepted?'. This shifts the tone from wistful regret about a known fact (Mars lacking moons) to a more inquisitive or argumentative stance.

The French explains leaving problematic scientific elements aside 'si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout' (if one despairs of being able to overcome it/resolve it), emphasizing intellectual limits or the sheer difficulty of the problem. The translation alters the motivation to a more pragmatic one: 'if ever you intend to make an end:', suggesting a practical choice made for the sake of completing the work rather than an admission of unsolvable difficulty. This subtly shifts the perception of the scientific process.

The French text has the philosopher conclude his point about Mars with '& ne parlons point de luy' (and let's not speak of him at all). The translation, 'and say no more of him; but return to Saturn.', adds the phrase 'but return to Saturn.' This addition, not present in the original at this juncture, makes the transition smoother but alters the philosopher's abruptness and preempts the narrative flow by introducing the next topic.

The original French presents a shared, imaginative hypothetical experience: 'Nous serions bien étonnez, si nous êtions dans Saturne, de voir' (We would be very astonished, if we were on Saturn, to see). This phrasing invites the reader into a sense of collective wonder. The translation changes this to a direct question posed by the philosopher to the Marquise: 'What do you think of'. This alters the narrative style from a descriptive, imaginative projection to a dialogic inquiry, changing the dynamic between the characters and the mode of engaging the reader.

The French 'interrompit-elle en riant' (she interrupted, laughing) provides key details about the Marquise's manner and the dynamic of the conversation. The translation reduces this to the bland 'says she'. This omission removes the information that the Marquise interrupted and, crucially, that she was laughing, thereby losing her playful tone and a nuance of her personality and engagement.

The French 'à en envoyer par tout assez hardiment' (to send [inhabitants/them] everywhere quite boldly) is a general, abstract philosophical speculation about populating other worlds. The translation renders this as 'I could almost send Colonies every where'. The introduction of the term 'Colonies', particularly in the late 17th-century English socio-political context of active colonial expansion, grounds the philosopher's musings in a specific, politically charged contemporary practice not implied by Fontenelle.

The French text details a specific scientific hypothesis regarding Saturn's moons: 'que les cinq petites Lunes fussent trois échappées de ce grand Cercle' (that three of the five little Moons were escapees from this great Circle). The translation, 'that the five little Moons fell out of this Circle', inaccurately implies that all five moons originated from the circle, rather than a specific number (three) of them. This alters the specific details of the scientific speculation being popularized.

The French describes a direct hypothetical scenario: '& si vous les mettiez dans nos Pays les plus froids... vous les verriez suër...' (and if you put them [Saturnians] in our coldest countries... you would see them sweat...). The translation transforms this into 'they say Greenland is a perfect Bagnio in comparison of that Planet,'. This manipulation involves: 1. Attributing the comparison to an impersonal 'they say,' distancing the philosopher from it. 2. Introducing 'Bagnio' (a bath-house, sometimes with risqué connotations), a culturally specific English term not in the original, changing the imagery. 3. Reversing the directness of the comparison, focusing on Greenland's state relative to Saturn rather than the Saturnians' reaction to Earth's cold.

chunks.source_manual: <P080>Vous me donnez une idée de Saturne qui me gele, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, au lieu que tan tôt vous m'échauffiez en me parlant de Mercure. Il faut bien, répliquay-je, que les deux Mondes qui sont aux extrémitez de ce grand Tourbillon, soient opposées en toutes choses.</P080> <P081>Ainsi, reprit-elle, on est bien sage dans Saturne, car vous m'avez dit que tout le monde êtoit fou dans Mercure. Si on n'est pas bien sage dans Saturne, repris- je, du moins, selon toutes les apparences, on y est bien flegmatique. Ce sont Gens qui ne savent ce que c'est que de rire, qui prennent toûjours un jour pour répondre à la moindre question qu'on leur fait, & qui eussent trouvé Caton d'Utique <IIM>trop badin & trop folâtre</IIM>. <NCE></NCE>.</P081>
chunks.target_manual: <P062>You give me, says she, such an Idea of Saturn, that makes me shake with cold, and that of Mercury, puts me into a feaver. It cannot be otherwise, I reply'd, for the two Worlds, which are the extremities of this great Vortex, must be opposite in all things. They must then, says she, be very wise in Saturn, for you told me they were all Fools in Mercury. If they are not wise, said I, yet they have all the appearances of being very Flegmatick: They are People that know not what 'tis to laugh, they take a days time to answer the least question you can ask 'em; and are so very grave, that were Cato living among 'em, they would think him <NCE>a merry Andrew</NCE>.</P062>
source_segments: tan tôt vous m'échauffiez en me parlant de Mercure
& qui eussent trouvé Caton d'Utique trop badin & trop folâtre..
target_segments: that of Mercury, puts me into a feaver
that were Cato living among 'em, they would think him a merry Andrew.
explanations: The French "vous m'échauffiez en me parlant de Mercure" (you were warming/exciting me by speaking of Mercury) describes an ongoing effect where the philosopher's words animated the Marquise. The English translation "that of Mercury, puts me into a feaver" shifts the agency from the philosopher ("vous") to the abstract "Idea of Mercury" ("that of Mercury"). More significantly, it intensifies the Marquise's reaction from being 'warmed' or 'excited' ("m'échauffiez") to being put "into a feaver," suggesting a more extreme, uncontrolled, and potentially negative state of agitation or illness. The tense also shifts from the French imperfect (past continuous) to the English present, making the reaction seem more immediate and dramatic. This alters the tone of the Marquise's statement, making her sensibility appear more pronounced and less gracefully composed than the original French implies.

The original French states that the Saturnians "eussent trouvé Caton d'Utique trop badin & trop folâtre.." (would have found Cato the Younger too playful and too frolicsome..). Cato was a Roman statesman famed for his stern morality and seriousness. The French implies the Saturnians are so exceedingly grave that even Cato would seem insufficiently serious to them. The English translation changes this to "that were Cato living among 'em, they would think him a merry Andrew." A "merry Andrew" was a contemporary English term for a clown, jester or buffoon. This substitution subtly manipulates the reader's understanding by: 1. Altering the perceived flaw in Cato: from being merely 'too playful' (a matter of degree relative to Saturnian gravity) to being misidentified as a 'merry Andrew' (a specific, low-status comedic role). 2. Introducing a culturally specific, colloquial English term, which changes the tone and makes the Saturnians' judgment seem less about a philosophical stance on seriousness and more like a crude mischaracterization. 3. Shifting the dynamic: instead of the Saturnians simply having a higher standard of gravity, they are portrayed as mistaking classical Roman seriousness for common buffoonery, which could make them appear less discerning or more absurdly judgmental than in the original.

chunks.source_manual: <P082>Il me vient une pensée, dit-elle. Tous les Habitans de Mercure sont vifs, tous ceux de Saturne sont lents. Parmy nous les uns sont vifs, les autres lents; cela ne viendroit-il point de ce que nôtre Terre étant justement au milieu des autres Mondes, nous participons des extrémitez? Il n'y a point pour les hommes de Caractère fixe & déterminé; les uns sont faits comme les Habitans de Mercure, les autres comme ceux de Saturne, & nous sommes un mélange de toutes les especes qui se trouvent dans les autres Planetes. J'aime assez cette idée, repris- je, nous formons un assemblage si bizarre, qu'on pourroit croire que nous serions ramassez de plusieurs Mondes différents. A ce compte, il est assez commode d'être icy, on y voit tous les autres Mondes en abregé.</P082>
chunks.target_manual: <P063>It is odd to consider, says she, that the Inhabitants of Mercury are all life, and the Inhabitants of Saturn quite contrary; but among us, some are brisk, and some are dull; it is, I suppose, because our Earth is plac'd in the middle of the other Worlds, and so we participate of both extreams, there is no fix'd or determin'd Character; some are made like the Inhabitants of Mercury, some like those of Saturn; we are a mixture of the several kinds that are found in the rest of the Planets. Why, said I, do you not approve of the Idea? Methinks it is pleasant to be compos'd of such a fantastical Assembly, that one would think we were collected out of different Worlds; we need not travel, when we see the other Worlds in Epitome at home.</P063>
