explanations: The translation shifts the Marquise's strong intellectual appreciation ('J'aime fort ces Idées-là' - I greatly like these ideas) to a more effusive, romanticized engagement ('I am in love with these Fancies'). 'Fancies' also diminishes the intellectual weight of 'Idées' (ideas), altering the tone and the perception of the Marquise's intellectual curiosity.

The original text's 'Marquise,' a specific French noble title, is changed to 'Countess.' This alteration changes a factual detail of the character, subtly shifting the reader's perception of her specific social standing as originally depicted by Fontenelle, and potentially anglicizing the character.

The French 'Ballons' (balloons, or large general-purpose balls) is translated to the very specific and mundane 'Foot-balls.' This narrows the scope of the metaphor, making it less abstract or grand and more commonplace, thus altering the imagery and potentially trivializing the analogy used to explain cosmic phenomena.

The French 'se combattent' (fight/combat each other) implies a direct and strong conflict. The translation 'striving and pushing one another' significantly softens this, reducing the intensity and drama of the described interactions between worlds, thereby altering the original's more forceful imagery.

The original 'combat' (fight, struggle) denoting the interaction between worlds is translated as 'justling' (jostling, pushing roughly). This substantially weakens the concept, changing a significant, forceful interaction into a more minor, almost trivial disturbance, thereby altering the reader's understanding of the cosmic mechanism being described.

chunks.source_manual: <P099>Non, non, repris-je, ce n'est pas le seul. Les Mondes voisins nous envoyent quelquefois visiter, & même assez magnifiquement. Il nous en vient des Cometes, qui sont toûjours ornées, ou d'une chevelure éclatante, ou d'une barbe venerable, ou d'une queüe majestueuse.</P099> <P100>Ah! quels Deputez dit-elle en riant! On se passeroit bien de leur visite, elle ne sert qu'à faire peur. Ils ne font peur qu'aux <UP></UP> enfants, repliquay-je, à cause de leur équipage extraordinaire, mais <RW>les enfants sont en grand nombre</RW>. Les Cometes ne sont que des Planetes qui appartiennent à un Tourbillon voisin. Elles avoient leur mouvement vers ses extremitez, mais ce Tourbillon êtant peut-être differemment pressé par ceux qui l'environnent, est plus rond par en haut, & plus plat par en-bas, & c'est par en-bas qu'il nous regarde. Ces Planetes <UP></UP> qui auront commencé vers le haut à se mouvoir en Cercle, ne prévoyoient pas qu'en bas le Tourbillon leur manqueroit, parce qu'il est là comme écrasé, & pour continuer leur mouvement circulaire, il faut nécessairement qu'elles entrent dans un autre Tourbillon, que je suppose qui est le nôtre, & qu'elles en coupent les extremitez. Aussi sont-elles toûjours fort élevées à notre égard, elles marchent beaucoup au dessus de Saturne. Il est nécessaire dans nôtre Sistême, pour des raisons qui ne sont rien à nôtre suijet present, que depuis Saturne jusqu'aux deux extremitez de nôtre Tourbillon, il y ait un grand espace vide, & sans Planetes. Nos Ennemis nous reprochent sans cesse inutilité de ce grand espace. Qu'ils ne s'inquietent plus, nous en avons trouvé l'usage, c'est l'appartement des Planetes étrangeres qui entrent dans nôtre Monde.</P100>
chunks.target_manual: <P079>No, no, Madam, said I; Light is not their sole commerce; the Neighbouring Worlds sometimes send visits to us, and that in a very magnificent and splendid manner: There come Comets to us from thence, adorn'd with bright shining Hair, Venerable Beards, or Majestick Tails; these said the <IIM>Countess</IIM> are Embassadors, whose Visits may be well spared, since they serve onely to affright us. They scare only Children, said I, with their extraordinary train; but indeed, the number of such Children is now a days very great. Comets are nothing but Planets, which belong to a Neighbouring Vortex, they move towards the out-side of it; but perhaps this Vortex being differently press'd by those Vortex's which encompass it, it is rounder above than it is below, and it is the lower part that is still towards us. These Planets which have begun to move in a Circle above, are not aware that below their Vortex will fail 'em, because it is as it were broken. Therefore to continue the Circular Motion, it is necessary that they enter into another Vortex, which we will suppose is ours, and that they cut through the outsides of it. They appear to us very high, and are much higher than Saturn, and according to our System, it is absolutely necessary they should be so high, for Reasons that signifie nothing to our present subject. From Saturn downwards to the outsides of our Vortex, there is a great void space without any Planets. Our Adversaries often ask us, to what purpose this void space serves? but let them not trouble themselves any more, I have found an use for it. 'Tis the Apartment of those strange Planets, which come into our World.</P079>

explanations: The translation specifies 'Light' as the subject (which is not explicit in the French clause 'it is not the only one') and introduces the word 'commerce'. 'Commerce' carries more formal, potentially transactional connotations than Fontenelle's simpler implication of 'visits' or 'arrivals' from other worlds, subtly altering the nature of the described interplanetary interaction.

The translation omits the Marquise's exclamation 'Ah!' and her emotional/tonal cue 'en riant' (laughing). This removal of expressed surprise and playfulness makes her subsequent statement ('these...are Embassadors') sound more serious or matter-of-fact, thereby altering the portrayal of her character and the tone of the dialogue. The change from 'Deputez' (Deputies) to 'Embassadors' also slightly elevates the status of the comets.

The addition of 'now a days' to the philosopher's general statement 'mais les enfants sont en grand nombre' (but children are numerous) anachronistically anchors the observation to the translator's own time. This subtly shifts the remark into a potential social critique of contemporary (late 17th-century English) society's perceived gullibility or irrational fears, a layer not specified by Fontenelle.

The French 'écrasé' (crushed, squashed, flattened) is translated as 'broken.' 'Écrasé' aligns with the Cartesian model of vortices being compressed or flattened, particularly at their extremities. 'Broken' suggests a different type of defect (e.g., a rupture or discontinuation), thereby altering the reader's understanding of the physical mechanics of the vortex as described by Fontenelle's philosopher.

The translation adds the lengthy clause 'and according to our System, it is absolutely necessary they should be so high, for Reasons that signifie nothing to our present subject' after translating 'elles marchent beaucoup au dessus de Saturne' (they travel far above Saturn). This substantial addition, not present in the original French, attributes a specific justification and a dismissive aside to the philosopher regarding the height of comets, altering his argumentative style and adding unauthored content.

The translation omits the initial clause 'Il est nécessaire dans nôtre Sistême, pour des raisons qui ne sont rien à nôtre suijet present,' (It is necessary in our System, for reasons that are irrelevant to our present subject,) from the original French sentence. This clause provided Fontenelle's framing for the existence of the void space beyond Saturn. Its omission (material from it having been repurposed and altered in the preceding sentence) means the philosopher's explicit reasoning and characteristic narrative aside for this specific astronomical point are lost.

The translation changes 'Nos Ennemis nous reprochent sans cesse inutilité de ce grand espace.' (Our Enemies ceaselessly reproach us for the uselessness of this large space.) to 'Our Adversaries often ask us, to what purpose this void space serves?'. This alteration significantly softens the adversarial dynamic: 'Ennemis' (Enemies) becomes the milder 'Adversaries'; a 'reproach for uselessness' (an accusation of fault) becomes an 'ask to what purpose it serves' (an inquiry); and 'sans cesse' (ceaselessly) becomes 'often'. This manipulates the tone and perceived intensity of the scientific disagreement Fontenelle describes.

The translation changes the French 'nous en avons trouvé l'usage,' (we have found its use,) to 'I have found an use for it.' The shift from the collective pronoun 'nous' (we) to the singular 'I' alters the attribution of the discovery. Instead of a shared or general scientific understanding, the insight is presented as a personal achievement of the philosopher, subtly manipulating the reader's perception of his role and the nature of scientific progress.

chunks.source_manual: <P101>J'entends, dit-elle. <NCP></NCP>. Nous ne leur laissons pas d'entrer jusque dans le cur de nôtre Tourbillon, & avec nos Planetes, nous les recevons comme le Grand Seigneur reçoit les Ambassadeurs qu'on luy envoye. Il ne leur fait pas l'honneur de les loger à Constantinople, mais seulement dans un Fauxbourg de la Ville. <IIM>Nous avons encore cela de commun avec les Ottomans</IIM>, repris-je, qu'ils reçoivent des Ambassadeurs sans en renvoyer, & que nous ne renvoyons point de nos Planetes aux Mondes voisins.</P101>
chunks.target_manual: <P080>I understand you, says she, <UP>we do not suffer them to come</UP> into the heart of our Vortex, among our own Planets, but we receive them as the Grand Signior doth the Embassadours that are sent to him; he will not shew them so much respect as to let 'em Lodge in Constantinople, but Quarters 'em in one of the Suburbs of the City: Madam, said I, we, and the Ottomans agree likewise in this, that as they receive Embassadours, but never send any, so we never send any of our Planets into the Worlds that are next us.</P080>
source_segments: & avec nos Planetes, nous les recevons
Il ne leur fait pas l'honneur de les loger à Constantinople
target_segments: among our own Planets, but we receive them
he will not shew them so much respect as to let 'em Lodge in Constantinople
explanations: The original French '& avec nos Planetes, nous les recevons' ('and with our Planets, we receive them') suggests planets are co-participants with 'us' (the Solar System/Vortex) in receiving celestial visitors. The translation 'among our own Planets, but we receive them' changes 'avec' (with) to 'among,' making planets a passive location, and 'et' (and) to 'but,' which separates 'us' as the primary actors. This subtly alters the meaning by diminishing the collective agency of the solar system, potentially shifting perception towards a more Earth-centric view of these interactions.

The French 'Il ne leur fait pas l'honneur de les loger à Constantinople' ('He does not do them the honour of lodging them in Constantinople') states the non-performance of a specific, formal 'honour.' The translation 'he will not shew them so much respect as to let 'em Lodge in Constantinople' reframes this as not showing a certain *degree* ('so much') of 'respect.' This subtly changes the connotation, portraying the Grand Signior's action as a more deliberate, quantified withholding of respect rather than adherence to a protocol concerning a specific honour, which can alter the perceived tone of the analogy.

chunks.source_manual: <P102>A en juger par toutes ces choses là, répliqua-t-elle, <UP></UP>. nous sommes bien fiers. Cependant je ne sais pas trop encore ce que j'en dois croire. Ces Planetes étrangeres ont un air bien menaçant avec leurs queües & leurs barbes, & peut- être on nous les envoye pour nous insulter, au lieu que les nôtres, qui ne sont pas faites de la même manière, ne seroient pas si propres à se faire craindre, quand elles iroient dans les autres Mondes.</P102>
chunks.target_manual: <P081>By this, says she, it appears that we are very proud, however I do not yet very well know what I am to believe. These forreign Planets with thei Tails and their Beards have a terrible Countenance, it may be they are sent to affront us; but ours that are of another make, if they should get into other Worlds, are not so proper to make people afraid.</P081>
source_segments: répliqua-t-elle,.
nous sommes bien fiers.
ont un air bien menaçant
ne seroient pas si propres à se faire craindre,
target_segments: says she,
it appears that we are very proud,
have a terrible Countenance
are not so proper to make people afraid.
explanations: The French "répliqua-t-elle,." (she replied/retorted,.) implies a more active and responsive tone from the Marquise. The translation "says she," is more neutral and generic, diminishing the dynamic quality of her speech and subtly reducing the perception of her as an assertive participant in the dialogue.

The original "nous sommes bien fiers." (we are very proud.) is a direct statement of self-awareness by the Marquise. The translation "it appears that we are very proud," introduces a degree of detachment ("it appears that"), transforming her direct admission into a more distanced observation. This subtly alters the portrayal of the Marquise's candor and the immediacy of her reflection.

The French "ont un air bien menaçant" (have a very menacing air/look) is intensified and specified in the translation "have a terrible Countenance." "Terrible" is stronger than "bien menaçant" (very menacing), and "Countenance" (face/facial expression) personifies the comets (implied by the context of 'tails and beards') more directly than the general "air" (appearance/demeanor). This shift can evoke greater fear and portray the celestial bodies as more monstrous or malevolent entities than implied by the original's description of a threatening appearance.

The French "ne seroient pas si propres à se faire craindre," uses the conditional mood ("would not be as suitable to inspire fear,"), indicating the Marquise's statement is speculative or hypothetical. The translation "are not so proper to make people afraid." uses the present indicative, presenting her thought as a more definitive or factual assertion. This change in modality removes the speculative nuance, making the Marquise's reasoning seem less like a thoughtful conjecture and more like an established opinion.

chunks.source_manual: <P103>Les queües & les barbes, répondis-je, ne sont que de pures apparences. <UP></UP>. Les Planetes étrangères ne diffèrent en rien des nôtres, mais en entrant dans nütre Tourbillon, elles prennent la queüe ou la barbe par une certaine sorte d'illumination qu'elles reçoivent du Soleil, & qui entre nous n'a pas encore êté trop bien expliquée; mais toûjours on est sûr qu'il ne s'agit que d'une espèce d'illumination <UP></UP>; on la devinera quand on pourra. Je voudrois donc bien, reprit- elle, que nôtre Saturne allât prendre une queuë ou une barbe dans quelque autre Tourbillon, & y répandre l'effroy, & qu'en suite ayant mis bas cet <IIM>accompagnement</IIM> terrible, il revint se ranger ici avec les autres Planetes à ses fonctions ordinaires. Il vaut mieux pour luy, répondis-je, qu'il ne sorte point de nôtre Tourbillon. Je vous ay dit le choc qui se fait à l'endroit où deux Tourbillons se poussent & se repoussent l'un l'autre; je croy que dans ce pas là une pauvre Planete est agitée assez rudement, & que ses Habitans ne s'en portent pas mieux. Nous croyons nous autres être bien malheureux quand il nous paroît une Comete elle-même qui est bien malheureuse. Je ne le crois point, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, elle nous apporte tous ses Habitans en bonne santé. Rien n'est si divertissant que de changer ainsi de Tourbillon. Nous qui ne sortons jamais du nôtre, nous menons une vie assez ennuyeuse. Si les Habitans d'une Comete ont assez d'esprit pour prévoir le temps de leur passage dans notre Monde, ceux qui ont déjà fait le voyage, annoncent aux autres par avance ce qu'ils y verront. Vous découvrirez bien-tôt une Planete qui a un grand Anneau autour d'elle, disent-ils peut-être en parlant de Saturne. Vous en verrez une autre qui en a quatre petites qui la suivent. Peut-être même y a-t-il des Gens destinés à observer le moment où ils entrent dans notre Monde, & qui crient aussi-tôt._Nouveau Soleil, Nouveau Soleil, comme ces Matelots qui crient, Terre, Terre. <UP></UP>.</P103>
chunks.target_manual: <P082>Their Beards and their Tails Madam, said I, are not real, they are <UP>Phaenomena</UP>, and but meer Appearances. These forreign Planets differ in nothing from ours, but entring into our Vortex, they seem to us to have Tails or Beards, by a certain sort of Illumination which they receive from the Sun, and which hath not been yet well explain'd. But certain it is, that 'tis but a kind of illumination, and when I am able I will tell you how 'tis done. I wish then, says she, that our Saturn would go take a Tail or a Beard in another Vortex, and affright all the Inhabitants of it. That done, I would have him come back again, leaving his terrible <IIM>Accoutrements</IIM> behind him, and taking his usual place amongst our other Planets, fall to his ordinary business. 'Tis better for him, said I, not to go out of our Vortex. I have told you how rude and violent the Shock is, when two Vortex's justle one another, a poor Planet must needs be terribly shaken, and its Inhabitants in no better condition. We think our selves very unhappy when a Comet appears, but 'tis the Comet that is in an ill case. I do not believe that, say she, it brings all its Inhabitants with it in very good health; there can be nothing so diverting as to change Vortex's. We that never go out of our own, lead but a dull Life; if the Inhabitants of a Comet had but the wit to foresee the time when they are to come into our world, they that had already made the Voyage, would tell their Neighbours beforehand what they should see, they would tell them, that they would discover a Planet with a great Ring about it, meaning our Saturn, they would also say, you shall see another Planet which hath four little ones to wait on it; and perhaps some of them, resolv'd to observe the very Moment of their entring into our World, would presently cry out A New Sun, a New Sun, as Sailors use to cry Land, Land.</P082>
source_segments: on la devinera quand on pourra.
le choc qui se fait à l'endroit où deux Tourbillons se poussent & se repoussent l'un l'autre
une pauvre Planete est agitée assez rudement
une Comete elle-même qui est bien malheureuse.
elle nous apporte tous ses Habitans en bonne santé.
disent-ils peut-être en parlant de Saturne.
Vous en verrez une autre qui en a quatre petites qui la suivent.
Peut-être même y a-t-il des Gens destinés à observer le moment où ils entrent dans notre Monde
target_segments: and when I am able I will tell you how 'tis done.
how rude and violent the Shock is, when two Vortex's justle one another
a poor Planet must needs be terribly shaken
'tis the Comet that is in an ill case.
it brings all its Inhabitants with it in very good health;
meaning our Saturn,
you shall see another Planet which hath four little ones to wait on it;
and perhaps some of them, resolv'd to observe the very Moment of their entring into our World
explanations: The French "on la devinera quand on pourra" (one/people will figure it out when able) attributes future understanding to a general, impersonal discovery process. The translation "when I am able I will tell you how 'tis done" shifts this agency to the philosopher ("I"), making him the personal future purveyor of this specific knowledge to the Marquise, subtly elevating his authority beyond merely explaining current science.

The original French describes the mechanics of the vortexes ("se poussent & se repoussent l'un l'autre" – push and repel each other), from which the nature of the shock is inferred. The translation adds the explicit adjectives "rude and violent" to "the Shock," intensifying the description and altering the tone to be more dramatic than the original's more neutral phrasing.

The French "assez rudement" (quite roughly/rudely) is intensified in the translation to "terribly shaken." Furthermore, the simple statement of fact "est agitée" (is shaken) is changed to "must needs be...shaken," which adds a strong sense of inevitability and heightened severity not equally present in the original, thus amplifying the perceived violence of the event.

The French "bien malheureuse" (very unhappy/miserable) attributes a strong emotional state or severe misfortune to the comet. The translation "'tis the Comet that is in an ill case" lessens this emotional weight, describing the comet's situation as a predicament or difficulty ("ill case") rather than a state of suffering, thereby subtly changing the tone and reducing the anthropomorphic pathos.

The French "elle nous apporte" (it brings to us) includes the indirect object "nous" (us), indicating that the comet is bringing its inhabitants into the experiential world of the Earth-bound observers. The translation "it brings all its Inhabitants with it" omits this dative, changing the focus from an event impacting "us" to a more general statement about the comet's transport of its inhabitants, subtly shifting the reader's perception of the event's direct relevance.

The French "disent-ils peut-être" (they say perhaps) explicitly frames the philosopher's identification of Saturn as a speculative suggestion about what comet dwellers might say. The translation "meaning our Saturn," by omitting "peut-être" (perhaps), transforms this speculation into a definite assertion made by the narrator to the reader, thus removing the original's nuance of uncertainty.

The French "quatre petites qui la suivent" (four little ones that follow it) provides a neutral description of the moons' movement. The translation "four little ones to wait on it" significantly alters the connotation by anthropomorphizing the moons as attendants or servants. This introduces a hierarchical, almost courtly, image not present in the original's more objective astronomical description, shifting the reader's perception of the relationship between the planet and its moons.

The French "des Gens destinés à observer" suggests individuals who are appointed, assigned, or fated for this role ("destinés"). The translation "some of them, resolv'd to observe" changes this to an act of personal will or determination ("resolv'd"). This shift alters the perceived motivation and nature of the observers' role from one potentially imposed by duty or fate to one driven by individual agency.

chunks.source_manual: <P104>Il ne faut donc plus songer, luy dis-je, à vous donner de la pitié pour les Habitans d'une Comète, mais j'espère du moins que vous plaindrez ceux qui vivent dans un Tourbillon dont le Soleil vient à s'éteindre, & <SC>qui demeurent dans une nuit éternelle</SC>. Quoi? s'écria-t-elle, des Soleils s'éteignent? Oüi, sans doute, répondis-je. Les Anciens ont vû dans le Ciel des Etoiles Fixes que nous n'y voyons plus. Ces Soleils ont perdu leur lumière; grande desolation assurément dans tout le Tourbillon; mortalité generale sur toutes les Planetes; car que faire sans Soleil? Cette idée est trop funeste, reprit-elle. N'y auroit-il pas moyen de me l'épargner? Je vous diray, si vous voulez, répondis je, ce que disent de fort habiles Gens, que les Etoiles Fixes qui ont disparu ne sont pas pour cela éteintes, que ce sont des Soleils qui ne le sont qu'à demy, c'est-à-dire qui ont <IIM>une moitié obscure</IIM>, & l'autre lumineuse; que comme ils tournent sur eux-mêmes, tantôt ils nous présentent la moitié lumineuse, & qu'alors nous ne les voyons, tantôt la moitié obscure, & qu'alors nous ne les voyons plus. Je prendray bien pour vous obliger cette opinion-là, qui est plus douce que l'autre, mais je ne puis la prendre qu'à l'égard de certaines Etoiles qui ont des temps reglez pour paroître & pour disparoître, ainsi qu'on a commencé à s'en apercevoir, autrement les demy Soleils ne peuvent pas subsister. Mais que dirons nous des Etoiles qui disparoissent & ne se remontrent pas aprés le temps pendant lequel elles auroient dû assurément achever de tourner sur elles-mêmes? Vous êtes trop équitable pour vouloir m'obliger à croire que ce soient des demy Soleils: cependant je feray encore un effort en votre faveur. Ces Soleils ne se seront pas éteints, ils se seront seulement enfoncez dans la profondeur immense du Ciel, & nous ne pourrons plus les voir. En ce cas le Tourbillon aura suivy son Soleil, & tout s'y portera bien. Il est vray que la plus grande partie des Etoiles Fixes n'ont pas ce mouvement par lequel elles s'éloignent de nous, car en d'autres temps elles devroient s'en rapprocher, & nous les verrions tantôt plus grandes tantôt plus petites, ce qui n'arrive pas. Mais nous supposerons qu'il n'y a que quelques petits Tourbillons plus légers & plus agiles qui se glissent entre les autres, & font de certains tours, au bout desquels ils reviennent, tandis que le gros des Tourbillons demeure immobile; mais voicy un étrange malheur. Il y a des Etoiles Fixes qui viennent se montrer à nous, qui passent beaucoup de temps à ne faire que paroître & disparoître, & enfin disparoissent entièrement, des demi-Soleils reparoîtraient dans des temps reglez. Des Soleils qui s'enfonceroient dans le Ciel ne disparoîtroient qu'une fois pour ne reparoître de longtemps. Prenez votre resolution, Madame, avec courage; il faut que ces Etoiles soient des Soleils qui s'obscurcissent assez pour cesser d'être visibles à nos yeux, & en suite se rallument, & à la fin s'éteignent tout à fait. Comment un Soleil peut-il s'obscurcir & s'éteindre, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, luy qui est en lui-même une source de lumière? Le plus aisément du Monde, selon Descartes, notre Soleil a des tâches. Que ce soient ou des écumes, des brouillards ou tout ce qu'il vous plaira, ces tâches peuvent s'épaissir, se mettre plusieurs ensemble, s'accrocher les unes aux autres, en suite elles iront jusqu'à former autour du Soleil une croûte qui s'augmentera toûjours, & adieu le Soleil <UP></UP>. Nous l'avons déja même échepée, dit-on. Le Soleil a été très pâle pendant des années entières, pendant celle, par exemple, qui suivit la mort de Cesar. C'étoit la croûte qui commençoit à se faire; la force du Soleil la rompit & la dissipa, mais si elle eût continué, nous étions perdus. Vous me faites trembler, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Presentement que je say les consequences de la pâleur du Soleil, je crois qu'au lieu d'aller voir les matins à mon miroir si je ne suis point pâle, j'iray voir au Ciel si le Soleil ne l'est point luy même. Ah! Madame, répondis-je, rassurez-vous, il faut du temps pour ruiner un Monde. Mais enfin, dit-elle, il ne faut que du temps? Je vous l'avouë, repris- je. Toute cette masse immense de matiere qui compose l'Univers, est dans un mouvement perpétuel, dont aucune de ses parties n'est entierement exempte; & dés qu'il y a du mouvement quelque part, ne vous y fiez point, il faut qu'il arrive des changements, soit lents, soit prompts, mais toûjours dans des temps proportionnez à l'effet. Les Anciens êtaient <IIM>plaisants</IIM> de s'imaginer que les Corps celestes étoient de nature à ne changer jamais, parce qu'ils ne les avoient pas encore vû changer. <IIM>Avoient-ils eu le loisir de s'en assurer par l'expérience?</IIM> Les Anciens étoient jeunes auprés de nous. Si les Roses qui ne durent qu'un jour faisoient des Histoires, & se loissent des Memoires les unes aux autres, les premieres auroient fait le portrait de leur Jardinier d'une certaine façon, & de plus de quinze mille áges de Rose, les autres qui l'auroient encore laissé à celles qui les devoient suivre, n'y auroient rien changé. Sur cela, elles diroient nous avons toûjours vû le même Jardinier <UP></UP>, de memoire de Rose on n'a vû que luy, il a toûjours êté fait comme il est, assurément il ne meurt point comme nous, il ne change seulement pas. Le raisonnement des Roses seroit-il bon? Il auroit pourtant plus de fondement que celuy que faisoient les Anciens sur les Corps celestes; & quand même il ne seroit arrivé aucun changement dans les Cieux jusqu'à aujourd'huy, quand ils paroîtroient marquer qu'ils seroient faits pour durer toûjours sans aucune alteration, je ne les en croirois pas encore, j'attendrois une plus longue experience. Devons-nous établir notre durée, qui n'est que d'un instant, pour la mesure de quelque autre? Seroit-ce à dire que ce qui auroit duré cent mille fois plus que nous, dût toûjours durer? On n'est pas si aisément éternel. Il faudroit qu'une chose eût passé bien des âges d'homme mis à bout pour commencer à donner quelque signe d'immortalité. Vrayment, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je voy les Mondes bien éloignez d'y pouvoir pretendre. Je ne leur ferois seulement pas l'honneur de les comparer à ce Jardinier qui dure tant à l'égard des Roses; ils ne sont que comme les Roses même qui naissent & qui meurent dans un Jardin les unes aprés les autres; car je m'attends bien que s'il disparoît des Etoiles anciennes, il en paroît de nouvelles, il faut que l'espce se repare. Il n'est pas à craindre qu'elle perisse, répondis-je. Les uns vous diront que ce ne sont que des Soleils qui se rapprochent de nous aprés avoir eté long- temps perdus pour nous dans la profondeur du Ciel. D'autres vous diront que ce sont des Soleils qui se sont démefez de cette croûte obscure qui commençoit à les environner. Je crois aisément que tout cela peut être, mais je croy aussi que l'Univers peut avoir êté fait de sorte qu'il s'y formera de temps en temps des Soleils nouveaux. Pourquoy la matiere propre à faire un Soleil ne pourra-t'elle pas, aprés avoir êté dispersée en plusieurs endroits différents, se ramasser à la longue en un certain lieu, & y jetter les fondements d'un nouveau Monde? J'ay d'autant plus d'inclination à croire ces nouvelles productions, qu'elles répondent mieux à la haute idée que j'ay des ouvrages de la Nature. N'auroit-elle le secret que de faire naître & mourir des herbes ou des plantes par une revolution continuelle? Je suis persuadé, & vous l'êtes déja aussi, qu'elle pratique ce même secret sur les Mondes, & qu'il ne luy en coûte pas davantage. De bonne foy, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je trouve à present les Mondes, les Cieux, & les Corps celestes si sujets au changement, que m'en voila tout à fait revenuë. Revenons encore mieux, si vous m'en croyez, répliquai-je, n'en parlons plus, aussi bien vous voila arrivée à la derniere voûte des Cieux; & pour vous dire s'il y a encore des Etoiles au-delà, il faudroit être plus habile que je ne suis. Mettez-y encore des Mondes, n'y en mettez pas, cela dépend de vous. C'est proprement l'Empire des Philosophes que ces grands païs invisibles qui peuvent être ou n'être pas si on veut, ou être tels que l'on veut, il me suffit d'avoir mené vôtre esprit aussi loin que vont vos yeux.</P104>
chunks.target_manual: <P083>You have no reason then, said I, to pity the Inhabitants of a Comet, yet I suppose you will think their Condition lamentable, who inhabit a Vortex whose Sun comes in time to be quite extinguished, and consequently live in Eternal Night. How? cry'd the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, can Suns be put out? Yes, without doubt said I, for People some thousand years ago saw fix'd Stars in the Sky, which are now no more to be seen; these were Suns which have lost their Light, and certainly there must be strange Desolation in their Vortex's, and a general Mortality over all the Planets, for what can People do without a Sun? This is a dismal Fancy, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, I would not if I could help it, let it come into my head. I will tell you if you please, I reply'd, what in this particular is the Opinion of Learned Astronomers. They think that the fix'd Stars which have disappear'd, are not quite extinguish'd, but that they are <UP>half Suns</UP>, that is, they have one half Dark, and the other half Light, and turning round upon their own Axis or Centre, they sometimes shew us their Light side, and afterwards turning to us their Dark side, we see them no more. To oblige you Madam, I will be of this Opinion, because it is not so harsh as the other, but I cannot make it good, but in relation to some certain Stars, because as some have lately observed, those Stars have their Regulated times of appearing, and disappearing, otherwise there could be no such thing as half Suns. But what shall we say of Stars, which totally disappear, and never shew themselves again after they have finish'd their Course of turning round upon their own Axis? you are too just Madam to oblige me to believe that such Stars are half Suns. However I will try once more what I can do in favour of your Opinion; the Suns are not extinct, they are only sunk so low into the immense depth of Heaven, that we cannot possibly see them, in this Case the Vortex follows his Sun and all's well again. 'Tis true, that the greatest part of the fix'd Stars have not this motion, by which they remove themselves so far from us, because at other times they might return again nearer to us, and we should see them sometimes greater, and sometimes less, which never happens. But we will suppose that none but the Little, Light, and most Active Vortex's which slip between the others make certain voyages, after which they return again, while the main body of Vortex's remain unmov'd. 'Tis likewise very strange that some fix'd Stars shew themselves to us, spending a great deal of time in appearing, and disappearing, and at last, totally and entirely disappear. Half Suns would appear again at their set and regulated time. Now Madam, boldly declare your Opinion; Must not these Stars of necessity be Suns which are so much darkned as not to be visible to us, yet afterwards shine again, and at last are wholly extinct? How can a Sun said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, be darkned, and quite extinguish'd, when it is in its own Nature a Fountain of Light? It may be done Madam, said I, with all the ease in the world, if Desc�rtes Opinion be true, that our Sun hath Spots; now whether these Spots be Scum or thick Mists, or what you please, they may thicken and unite, till at last they cover the Sun with a Crust, which daily grows thicker, and then Farewell Sun. We have hitherto scap'd pretty well; but 'tis said, that the Sun for some whole years together hath look'd very pale; for Example, the year after Caesar's death; it was this Crust that then began to grow, but the force of the Sun broke and dissipated it; had it continued, we had been all lost People. You make me tremble, reply'd the <IIM>Countess</IIM>; and now I know the fatal consequences of the Sun's paleness, I believe, instead of going every morning to my Glass, to see how I look, I shall cast my Eyes up to Heaven, to see whether or no the Sun looks pale. Oh, Madam, said I, there is a great deal of time required to ruine a World. Grant it, said she, yet 'tis but time that is required. I confess it, said I; all this immense mass of Matter that composes the Universe, is in perpetual motion, no part of it excepted; and since every part is moved, you may be sure that changes must happen sooner or later; but still in times proportioned to the Effect. The Ancients were <UP>pleasant Gentlemen</UP>, to imagine that the celestial Bodies were in their own nature unchangeable, because they observed no change in them; but they did not live long enough to confirm their opinion by their own experience; they were Boys in comparison of us. <UP>Give me leave, Madam, to explain my self by an Allegory</UP>: If Roses, which last but a day, could write Histories, and leave Memoirs one to another; and if the first Rose should draw an exact Picture of their Gardiner, and after fifteen thousand Rose-Ages, it should be left to other Roses, and so left still to those that should succeed, without any change in it; should the Roses hereupon say, we have every day seen the same Gardiner, and in the memory of Roses, none ever saw any Gardiner but this; he is still the same he was, and therefore certainly he will never die, as we do; for there is no change at all in him. Would not these Roses, Madam, talk very foolishly? and yet there would be more reason in their discourse, than there was in what the Ancients said concerning celestial Bodies; and tho' even to this very day there should appear no visible change in the Heavens, and the matter of which they are made, should have all the signs of an eternal duration without any change; yet I would not believe 'em unchangeable, till I had the experience of many more Ages. Ought we, who last but a moment, make our continuance the measure of any other things duration; 'tis not so easie a matter to be eternal. To have lasted many Ages of Men, one after another, is no sign of Immortality. Truly, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, I find the Worlds are far from being able to pretend to it; I will not do 'em so much honour, as to ompare 'em to the Gardiner that lived so much longer than the Roses: I begin to think 'em like the Roses themselves, which blow one day, and die the next: For now I understand, that if old Stars disappear, new ones will come in their room, because every species must preserve it self. No species, Madam, said I, can totally perish; some perhaps will tell you, that such new Stars are Suns, which return to our sight again, after they have been a long time hid from us, in the profundity of Heaven: Others may tell you, they are Suns cleared from that thick crust, which once covered them: If I should think all this possible, yet I likewise believe that the Universe may be framed in such a manner, that from time to time it may produce new Suns; why may not that matter which is proper to make a Sun, be dispers'd here and there, and gather it self again at long run, into one certain place, and lay the foundation of a new World? I am very much inclin'd to believe such new productions, because they suit with that glorious and admirable Idea which I have of the works of Nature. Can we think that wise Nature knows no more than the secret of making Herbs and Plants live and die by a continual revolution? I am verily perswaded, and are not you so too, Madam? that Nature, without much cost or pains can put the same secret in practice, upon the Worlds. I now find, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, the Worlds, the Heaven, and celestial Bodies so subject to change, that I am come to my self again. To come the better again to our selves, I reply'd, let us say no more of these Matters. We are arrived at the very roof and top of all the Heavens; and to tell you whether there be any Stars beyond it, you must have an abler Man than I am; you may place Worlds there, or no Worlds, as you please: 'Tis the Philosopher's Empire to describe those vast invisible Countries, which are, and are not, or are such as he pleases to make 'em: It is enough for me, to have carried your mind as far as you can see with your Eyes.</P083>

explanations: The French 's'éteignent' (extinguish themselves/go out) suggests a natural, intrinsic process for suns. The English 'be put out' implies an external agent or action, subtly altering the reader's understanding of solar phenomena from a self-driven process to one potentially caused by an outside force.

The French 'Les Anciens' specifically refers to classical authors of Greek and Roman antiquity, figures of established authority. The English 'People some thousand years ago' is a much vaguer, generalized term that diminishes this specific reference, potentially downplaying the unique status of these classical authorities.

The French 'Cette idée est trop funeste' (This idea is too fatal/disastrous/gloomy) conveys strong gravity. The English 'This is a dismal Fancy' significantly softens this; 'Fancy' in particular reduces the 'idée' (idea/concept) to something more whimsical or less serious, altering the perceived weight of the Marquise's reaction.

The French 'de fort habiles Gens' (some very skilled/clever people) is a general term. The English 'Learned Astronomers' is more specific, elevating these individuals to recognized scientific experts. This specificity lends a more formal scientific authority to the explanation than the original phrasing implied.

The French phrase 'mais voicy un étrange malheur' (but here is a strange misfortune/unhappiness) is a distinct, reflective comment by the philosopher. The translation omits this comment as a separate utterance; the adjective 'étrange' (strange) is absorbed into the subsequent clause to describe the stars' behavior, and the philosopher's observation on 'malheur' (misfortune) is lost, altering the rhetorical structure.

The Marquise's French comment 'si je ne suis point pâle' (if I am not pale) specifically links her own potential paleness (a sign of fear or ill health) to the Sun's paleness (a sign of cosmic danger). The English translation 'how I look' is general and loses this witty, thematic connection, diminishing the sharpness of her remark.

The direct comforting imperative 'rassurez-vous' (reassure yourself) from the French philosopher to the Marquise is omitted in the English translation. This omission removes an element of personal reassurance from the philosopher's tone, making his statement more a detached observation than a direct comfort.

The Marquise's French question 'Mais enfin, dit-elle, il ne faut que du temps?' (But in the end, she said, only time is needed?) expresses a dawning, perhaps troubled, realization. The English 'Grant it, said she...' incorrectly casts her as conceding a point, changing her role from one of active, concerned inquiry to passive agreement and altering the conversational dynamic.

The French 'Les Anciens êtaient plaisants de s'imaginer' (The Ancients were amusing/funny/quaint to imagine) carries a tone of mild condescension towards their outdated beliefs. The English 'The Ancients were pleasant Gentlemen, to imagine' is an overly polite rendering that neutralizes Fontenelle's subtle critique of the Ancients' naivety.

The introductory phrase 'Give me leave, Madam, to explain my self by an Allegory:' is added by the translator; Fontenelle's philosopher launches directly into the allegory. This addition makes the philosopher's discourse more formal and ceremonious, altering the original's more spontaneous conversational flow.

The second rhetorical question from the French, 'Seroit-ce à dire que ce qui auroit duré cent mille fois plus que nous, dût toûjours durer?' (Would that be to say that what has lasted a hundred thousand times longer than us, must always last?), which serves as a critical step in Fontenelle's argument about scale and eternity, is entirely omitted in the English translation. This omission significantly weakens the original argument by removing this illustrative example.

The French 'Je crois aisément que tout cela peut être' (I readily/easily believe that all that can be/is possible) is a clear statement of the philosopher's belief. The English 'If I should think all this possible' changes this into a hypothetical condition, significantly weakening the philosopher's expressed conviction and making him sound more doubtful or speculatively detached.

The French philosopher's assertion about the Marquise's understanding, '& vous l'êtes déja aussi' (and you are [persuaded] already too), is changed in English to a question: 'and are not you so too, Madam?'. This shift makes the philosopher less assertive about her agreement and more solicitous, altering the dynamic between them.

The French 'C'est proprement l'Empire des Philosophes que ces grands païs invisibles...' (It is properly the Empire of Philosophers, these great invisible countries...) suggests their empire *is* these realms. The English ''Tis the Philosopher's Empire to describe those vast invisible Countries...' shifts their role to *describing* these realms. This alters the nature of the philosophers' power from ontological (related to the being of these realms) to discursive (related to their description).

explanations: The pronoun 'elle' (she) in the phrase 's'écria-t-elle' refers to the Marquise, the female protagonist of Fontenelle's work. The translation introduces 'the Countess' in 'says the Countess,' incorrectly altering her established title and identity.

The French interjection 'Quoi!' (What!) expresses strong surprise and excitement at the beginning of the Marquise's speech. The translation 'Well' is significantly more subdued and commonplace, diminishing the character's expressed astonishment and altering the original tone.

The French verb 's'écria' (from 's'écria-t-elle', meaning she exclaimed/cried out) conveys a high degree of emotion and vivacity in the Marquise's speech. The translation 'says' is a neutral verb of speaking, which flattens her emotional expression and reduces the intensity of her reaction.

The original French 'avec la commodité de pouvoir ne rien croire ... dés que l'envie vous en prendra.' (with the convenience/ease of being able to believe nothing ... as soon as the whim/desire takes you) highlights a playful, capricious freedom granted to the Marquise. The translation 'with the advantage of believing, or not believing any thing I have said:' omits the specific nuance of 'dés que l'envie vous en prendra,' simplifying the terms of her intellectual freedom and altering the philosopher's original lighthearted, permissive tone towards her learning.

The French 'Je vous demande seulement' (I only ask you) is a straightforward and relatively neutral request from the philosopher. The translation 'I only beg this favour' intensifies the verb 'demande' (ask) to 'beg,' making the philosopher's tone more supplicating or dramatic than in the original, which can subtly shift the perceived power dynamic or his characterization.

source_segments: FIN
target_segments: FINIS.
explanations: The French original uses "FIN", a simple and direct term in the vernacular, consistent with Fontenelle's aim of popularizing science in everyday language as highlighted in the cultural context. The English translation uses "FINIS.", a Latin term. While "FINIS" also means "THE END" and was a common convention in English books of the period, its use here introduces a classical and more formal connotation that is absent in the original's straightforward French closure. This subtly shifts the tone, potentially distancing the work slightly from the purely vernacular and accessible register Fontenelle championed for his work on scientific popularization.
